content: Some recent economic indicators hint that the Korean economy may recover soon, but it is still too early to tell if the economy is making a turnaround, experts said yesterday.The National Statistical Office said on Tuesday that the contraction of industrial output slowed to minus 10.3 percent in February from a 25.5 percent decline in the previous month, raising optimism that the economy may be gaining momentum for a turnaround.The leading composite index, which predicts the turning point of economic trends, rose 0.5 percent in February from the previous month, marking a positive figure for the first time in 15 months. A record $4.6 billion March trade surplus reported on Wednesday by the Knowledge Economy Ministry added more optimism.However, those latest figures are "technical rebounds" from a drastic contraction in the fourth quarter, analysts said. The economy shrank 5.1 percent in the fourth quarter from the previous three months."The latest improvements in economic indicators are mostly technical rebounds, meaning that the fourth-quarter performance was very bad. The economy is nearing the bottom though," said Seo Cheol-soo, an analyst with Daewoo Securities."A quick recovery is unlikely even though the deterioration of economic trends has slowed." Seo said that an economic recovery means recovery in consumer spending, investment and net exports leading to a rise employment.However, such a scenario will not appear until at least the fourth quarter this year and the economy will keep losing jobs for some time, he said.The optimistic view on the economic recovery also resulted from recently-stabilized financial markets.The benchmark KOSPI did not fall below the 1,100 level in the past three weeks and even rose to near 1,260 during intra-trading yesterday. The won gained 12 percent to mark 1,379.50 won against the dollar on Wednesday from 1,568 won on March 5.Industry data showed that foreigner investors net bought 2.1 trillion won worth of Korean bonds and 1.1 trillion won worth of local shares in March, both up from 1.8 trillion won and 1.12 trillion won in February.Continued improvement in the financial market would surely help the real economy recover quickly but that link is quite weak now, Seo said.Daniel Melser, senior economist with Moody`s Economy.com, said it is uncertain how long the economic slump will persist, given that the world economy is still slowing."The unemployment rate in Europe and the United States is rising and will likely continue to rise for some time yet. This implies that we are yet to see a bottom in consumer demand," Melser said."Business spending could pick up but this is very unlikely to happen before the final quarter of 2009. This paints a very bleak picture of the next six months for exports and industrial production." Lee Sang-jae, economist with Hyundai Securities, predicted that the economy would bottom out in the first quarter with a lower growth rate than that of the fourth quarter, gradually make recovery in the second and third quarters and swing to a plus growth rate in the fourth quarter of the year."A recovery in exports is crucial, which can alleviate the overall jittery sentiment," Lee said.The Federation of Korean Industries said half of 18 economists at major local think tanks projected the economy would hit the bottom in the second half.By Kim Yoon-mi (yoonmi@heraldm.com)

title: [NEWS ANALYSIS Lee fails to convince audience
content: President Lee Myung-bak`s first televised town hall meeting on Tuesday appears to have failed to score good marks with many Koreans disgruntled with his lack of leadership in easing their economic hardships.Critics say that Lee has not come up with any substantial measures dealing with problems like high unemployment among young adults and household debt.The president tried to clarify his housing policy and send the clear message that Korea will not face another financial crisis.A significant portion of the 100-minute meeting was dedicated to his assessment of the property market and various solutions to structural market problems."Many people are facing economic hardships, but I`m confident that our fundamentals are not as weak as a decade ago," Lee said.His repeated expression of confidence in his economic policy team, led by Finance Minister Kang Man-soo, will give momentum to the administration`s supply-oriented housing policy and deregulation programs, market observers say.So far, much of the government`s economic policy focus has been on stabilizing consumer prices and giving tax cuts so as to diminish the burden on businesses and households."It`s time for officials to focus on more substantial policy measures to turn around corporate investment, rather than only seeking to improve investor sentiment," said Hwang In-seong, a chief researcher with the Samsung Economic Research Institute.Minister Kang, the architect of Lee`s growth-oriented economic policy, has largely been blamed for the recent foreign currency policy, which many believe caused the won`s steep decline. Also, his interventionist stance has been criticized as outmoded."The won`s decline is largely due to the overall strength of the U.S. dollar around the world," Lee said, dismissing calls that Finance Minister Kang be replaced.His determination to bolster housing reconstruction in inner city areas and forge ahead with a supply-focused housing policy will translate to major economic policy measures to be unveiled soon, industry watchers say.The Finance Ministry is expected to reveal its blueprint for revising the comprehensive property tax and to announce additional measures to expand the housing supply later this month.The government is also working on the second phase of deregulation and follow-up measures to advance the nation`s cloistered services industry.Lee said that "the activation of reconstruction and redevelopment projects should help young couples in inner city areas buy homes."  He also emphasized that the current property tax scheme distorts the property market by suppressing real demand.Soaring inflation and political turmoil have restrained economic officials from taking bold steps to deregulate the housing sector and revamping tax schemes instituted by the Roh Moo-hyun administration. His housing policy is the centerpiece of the Lee`s growth-focused economic policy.Earlier in the month, the Finance Ministry proposed reforming the real estate market`s capital gains tax and comprehensive property tax scheme.Many view such moves as insufficient, in terms of revitalizing home sales and addressing the glut of apartments outside the capital.Additional policy measures would include the exemption of construction company capital gains tax on reconstruction and redevelopment projects, as well as the partial easing of rules which restrict the acquisition of newly built apartments, industry watchers say.Lee also stressed his determination to pursue the overhaul of public corporations and the national pension scheme, but did not provide details.By Kim Jung-min  (jungmin@heraldm.com)

title: [NEWS ANALYSIS] Housing stimulus short of expectations
content: Amid rising credit risk, the government yesterday announced supply-focused housing policy measures. Experts say that without a major revamp in tax and home financing rules, the package of measures may not have significant effects on the slowing economy.Yesterday`s housing market stimulus package outlined increasing housing supply and easing restrictions on apartment resale and housing construction permits.The announcement does not appear to excite many participants as it did not include key tax and home financing issues - which many regard as real hurdles to reviving the construction sector."This time, we had limitations in tax and credit policies, because they could affect the housing market directly," said Koo Bon-jin, director general of the Finance Ministry`s policy coordination bureau in a news briefing yesterday.Many industry watchers had expected that the deregulation plan would include capital gains tax waivers and debt-to-income ratio restrictions that limit the housing demand in Seoul and its neighboring areas.Investors` disappointment was reflected in the stock market. The construction index tumbled 6.42 percent.The good news is that policy uncertainty will be partly lifted as many view the latest housing market package as a strong signal of policymakers` determination to rescue the ailing construction industry, a key growth engine of the economy.In recent months, home sales have tumbled as a delay in the housing deregulation policy prompted many people to put off home purchase plans. Many home builders are facing financial distress with the number of unsold apartments reaching 130,000 across the nation. More than 200 local builders went out of business between January and July, according to the Finance Ministry."Uncertainty over the government`s deregulation policy hurt sentiment toward the industry," said Lee Sun-il, an analyst at Goodmorning Shinhan Securities Co. The inclusion of the capital region in the housing market deregulation will have profound effects for the home building industry, he added. Yet, it may take at least six months before the policy changes have an impact on the market, as seen in the previous cases, he noted."The deregulation level did not live up to our expectations. However, we believe it`s an encouraging sign that policymakers may start shifting their focus toward stagflation away from inflation," said Huh Moon-wook, a construction analyst at Samsung Securities Co. The Finance Ministry plans to unveil its plans to revamp the nation`s real estate taxation in September.Officials are hoping that the deregulation policy would help revive confidence in the lackluster housing market. The construction industry, making up 18 percent of the gross domestic product, is not only a crucial component of an economic turnaround but it also has far-reaching effects on the job market. The sector generated 8 percent of total employment last year.Construction investment, which has been in the doldrums since the second quarter of 2007, declined 0.9 percent year-on-year in the first half of this year, the state data showed."A decline in the number of jobs created in the construction sector has affected low-income families," said the Finance Ministry`s director general Koo.However, unfavorable macroeconomic environments and growing unease at financial markets would make it tougher for policymakers to fix the demand side of the housing market problems, analysts said.A credit crunch may occur in some areas as financial institutions have begun to curtail loans. The asset quality of some non-banking financial institutions that have heavily extended real estate project financing could deteriorate."The real problem in Korea`s economy lies in the financial sector not in the real economy," said Jung Yong-taek, an economist at Eugine Investment Securities Co. Too much liquidity has been channeled into the financial markets, prompting a surge in asset prices in recent months. With rising interest rates and credit risks, the financial sector is likely to enter a more drastic correction phase than the real economy, he said.Both the Financial Services Commission and the Financial Supervisory Service have reaffirmed their official stance that home financing rules will not be scrapped anytime soon, although the regulations could suppress the real housing demand.By Kim Jung-min  (jungmin@heraldm.com)

title: [NEWS ANALYSIS] Summit ends without drama
content: The new president of Korea and the outgoing president of the United States held what may have been their last summit talks yesterday in Seoul, as they affirmed their alliance and shared basic principles regarding various global issues.But Lee Myung-bak of Korea and George W. Bush of the United States fell short of endorsing any blueprint for the future-oriented alliance which they had agreed to at their April summit.While echoing each other in urging North Korea to denuclearize and improve its human rights situation, the two leaders sidestepped thorny issues such as the redeployment of troops to Afghanistan.It was originally hoped that Lee and Bush would be able to adopt a joint agreement on the new strategic alliance."First, it was too ambitious a plan to prepare the blueprints of the future alliance in just four months, (just as it was to chart) how Seoul would adapt to the position of the next U.S. government," said professor Yoon Duk-min of the Institute of Foreign Affairs and National Security."Both countries need more time to prepare the details of the alliance based on the consideration of long-term views, public consensus and others," Yoon said.A diplomatic source, speaking on condition of anonymity said, "The outcome, or lack thereof, of this summit is not surprising, considering the political timetable of the United States." The United States is slated to elect a new president in November, following national conventions of the Democrats and Republicans to formally appoint their candidates this month and next month.This round of summit talks, indeed, was considered more of an opportunity to refresh the alliance which has suffered from huge anti-government rallies in Seoul this spring following Lee`s decision to resume imports of U.S. beef.The spreading anti-U.S. sentiment over the beef debacle had also forced the two governments to delay Bush`s visit by several weeks.Lee and Bush, instead, reiterated their consensus regarding how the alliance should shape up in a joint statement released after their meeting at Cheong Wa Dae.The alliance would be developed by enhancing the combined defense capabilities, implementing the transition of wartime operational control, and relocating U.S. Forces here, the statement said."They further agreed to develop the alliance in a way that will also contribute to peace and prosperity at the regional and global levels," it said.While this basic position indicates the direction of the new alliance, it was apparent that Bush decided to leave it at that, and shelve the sensitive issue of asking for Seoul`s redeployment of troops to Afghanistan. Korean troops withdrew from the war-stricken country in exchange for the release of 21 Korean hostages last year."The fact that the joint statement omits the part about the redeployment shows that the two countries have yet to agree on how the broader alliance on a global level should turn out," the source said.Predictably, Lee and Bush were united in urging North Korea to change.The two presidents reaffirmed their commitment to improving the human rights situation in North Korea and reiterated that the process of normalizing relations with North Korea would come with meaningful progress in its human rights record.This demonstrated once again the determination of the Lee Myung-bak administration to be more stern with the reclusive regime. Upon the inauguration of the Lee government, inter-Korean relations rapidly deteriorated. All government-level dialogue is suspended, and private-level exchanges dropped after the July 11 fatal shooting of a South Korean tourist by a North Korean soldier.Bush expressed condolences to the family of the 53-year-old housewife and urged the North to cooperate with the South on the investigation.With regard to the six-party talks on North Korea`s nuclear program, Bush said that the North must make the decision before Aug. 12.Washington and Pyongyang are currently wrangling over the draft of the verification-mechanism plan. The members of the six-party talks had agreed on July 12 to set up the mechanism to verify the declaration submitted by the North in June.But the North and the other members still differ over the scope and method of the verification.Washington has been intent on getting the verification mobilized before it removes Pyongyang from the list of states which sponsor terrorism, which is slated for Aug. 11.No progress on the verification negotiations would mean that the North would stay on the list past Aug. 11.Lee and Bush also reaffirmed their cooperation in the civic sphere, including the Work, English Study and Travel program, which would allow about 5,000 Korean students per year to study and work in the United States for up to 18 months.They reaffirmed that Korea would join the U.S. Visa Waiver Program within this year; join efforts to fight global climate change; and maintain close discussions concerning how to counter terrorism, weapons of mass destruction, pan-national crimes and energy threats.By Lee Joo-hee (angiely@heraldm.com)

title: [NEWS ANALYSIS] High interest rates weigh on local market
content: The recent interest rate hike by the Bank of Korea is weighing on the faltering stock market as concerns over the U.S. subprime debacle turned out to be legitimate, experts said yesterday.The benchmark KOSPI fell nearly 7 percent on Thursday alone, the largest one day drop among the world`s major stock markets, which also suffered from big losses."In retrospect, the BOK`s decision was inappropriate," Sung Jin kyung, an analyst at Daishin Securities Co., said in a telephone interview. "The BOK did not seem to expect the subprime problem to turn out to be a significant crisis."  The central bank unexpectedly raised the benchmark interest rate last week by a quarter point to 5 percent, in a move to cap the country`s fast expanding money supply and ease inflationary pressures.The increase, the second in a row and the seventh in the current rate hike rally, pushes borrowing costs to the highest level since July 2001.Central bankers said the rate hike was "a preventative measure" to deflate a possible bubble in the economy.Critics say it now poses too much a burden on investors and the equity market.Concerns are not limited to falling stock prices.Analysts also worry that the staggering bourse could lead to widespread credit defaults, damaging the real estate market and industrial activities as well.In this case, high interest rates can fuel downward pressures of the economy, which has recently started recovering.But market analysts said the central bank is unlikely to inject cash into the Seoul bourse as other major central banks have done to calm concerns."The subprime crisis has a limited impact on the Korean economy. I don`t think the BOK will do something to calm anxieties," Sung said.Bureaucrats and financial regulators have been consistently playing down the subprime ripple effect on the Korean economy. "Local financial firms invested some $850 million (in the American subprime mortgage loan market), and the loss is estimated at around 10 percent," Financial Supervisory Commission Vice Chairman Yun Yong ro said in a television interview yesterday."It is a marginal loss compared to the size of the local capital market." But skeptics point out that the real impact tends to become visible in a long term period.If the ongoing global credit crisis continues to corrode investor trust and consumer sentiment, the global economy could suffer an economic dip in the coming months.This could deal a harsh blow to Korea`s exports, which account for some 40 percent of the total national output.Economists are concerned that this possible downturn could be aggravated by the reckless interest rate hike by the BOK."The subprime mortgage crisis has the potential of doing damage to advanced economies such as America and Europe," Yun also warned."The government is cautiously watching the market at all times."   By Ko Kyoung tae (kkt@heraldm.com)

title: [번역][NEWS ANALYSIS] China rate hike has short-term impact:experts 중국...
content: China`s interest rate hike, its third in 11 months will not have a lasting impact on the local equities market, although a short correction may be likely, experts said yesterday.The People`s Bank of China raised its benchmark lending rate by 27 basis points to 6.39 percent from 6.12 percent on Saturday. It also raised the one-year deposit rate to 2.79 percent from 2.52 percent.Local experts said the interest rate hike will cause a short-term correction in the market, as investor sentiment could worsen on concerns that China may be taking serious steps to cool its hyper economy.Some also pointed out that the interest rate hike has already been factored in as the rate jump had long been expected."The rate increase was a direct response to Premier Wen Jiabao`s recent warnings on the growth at which the investments and loans were being made in China," Hong Seung-pyo, an analyst at Hanyang Securities Co., said."We are expecting a stronger yuan and additional rate hikes in the second quarter this year, so this first one will definitely weigh on the Seoul market," he said.Hong added that Chinese equities will be the hardest hit as the market is already overheated.Daewoo Securities said in a report that while China`s overall economy will be little affected by the rate hike, the equities market will feel its effect the most and for the worse, possibly sparking an extended correction through the second quarter this year.However some analysts argued the rate hike is unlikely to cause an extended correction, saying its impact would be short at the most."The rate hike was necessary to avoid the market overheating. This will be no more than a short-term factor," Kim Hak-kyun, analyst at Korea Investment & Securities Co., said.The Chinese central bank`s recent decision is consistent with China`s long-held goal of tightening, he said."The central bank`s tightening has been expected for quite some time, so its impact will be limited," Shim Jae-yeop, senior market strategist at Meritz Securities Co., said.Statistics compiled by Korea Investment showed that there had been market corrections after seven of 10 rate increases since 2004, but the market rebounded within a 30-day period."If investors overreact, this may well be an opportunity to pick up bargains," Kim said.The Korea Composite Stock Price Index jumped 15.51 points or 1.09 percent to close at 1,443.49 yesterday.(jpark731@heraldm.com) By Park Jung-youn 11개월 만에 3번째로 단행한 중국의 금리인상은 단기 조정은 있을 수 있겠지만 국내 증시에 장기적인 영향을 주지는 않을 것이라고 전문가들은 어제 밝혔다.중국인민은행은 기준대출금리를 지난 토요일 6.12%에서 6.39%로 27베이시스포인트 인상했다. 이 은행은 또한 1년만기 예금금리를 2.52%에서 2.79%로 인상했다.국내 전문가들은 중국이 지나치게 과열된 경제를 진정시키기 위해 중대한 조치를 취할지 모른다는 우려 때문에 투자심리가 악화되면서 이번 금리인상이 국내 주식시장의 단기조정을 가져올 것이라고 말했다.일부에서는 이번 금리인상이 오랫동안 예견돼 왔었기 때문에 이미 주식시장에 반영됐다고 지적했다.한양증권 홍승표 애널리스트는 "이번 금리인상은 중국에서 이뤄지고 있는 투자 및 대출 증가에 대한 원자바오 총리의 최근 경고에 직접적으로 반응한 것"이라고 분석했다.그는 "우리는 올해 2/4분기에 위엔화 강세와 추가금리인상을 예상하고 있으며, 따라서 이번과 같은 첫번째 조치는 분명히 국내 증시에 충격을 줄 것"이고 말했다.홍 애널리스트는 시장이 이미 과열돼 있으므로 중국 주식은 큰 타격을 입을 것이라고 덧붙였다.대우증권은 보고서를 통해 중국의 전반적인 경제가 금리인상으로 인해 거의 영향을 받지는 않을 것인 반면, 주식시장은 가장 영향을 받을 것으로 예상되며, 심할 경우 중국 주식시장이 아마도 올 2/4분기까지 장기적인 조정국면을 가져올 수도 있을 것이라고 밝혔다.그러나 일부 애널리스트들은 영향이 기껏해야 단기에 그칠 것이라고 언급하면서 중국 금리인상이 장기간 조정을 가져오지는 않을 것이라고 주장했다.한국투자증권의 김학균 애널리스트는 "중국금리인상은 증시가 과열되는 것을 막기위해서는 반드시 필요했다. 이것은 단기적인 요인에 불과할 것이다"라고 말했다.중국 중앙은행의 최근 결정은 중국의 오랜 목표인 긴축정책과 일치한다고 그는 말했다.메리츠증권의 심재엽 투자전략팀장은 "중국 중앙은행의 긴축정잭은 오랜 시간 예견된 것이므로 그 영향은 제한적일 것이다"고 말했다.한국투자증권이 집계한 통계자료에 따르면 2004년 이후 10번의 금리인상 중 7차례 시장 조정이 있어왔지만 증시는 30일 이내에 반등했음을 보여주었다.김 애널리스트는 "만약 투자가들이 과잉반응을 보인다면 주식을 헐값에 살 수 있는 기회가 될 수도 있다"고 말했다.코스피(KOSPI)지수는 어제 15.51 포인트(1.09%) 상승하면서 1443.39로 마감했다.

title: [NEWS ANALYSIS]Concerns about the yen overblown
content: Experts forecast Japan currency to rebound By Ko Kyoung-tae The Japanese yen fell to a nine-year-low of 802.61 won per 100 yen on Monday, down nearly 7 percent from May.This stoked concerns that the weaker yen would make Korean-made products less competitive against their Japanese rivals in overseas markets.But experts largely downplay such an anxiety, saying that the Japanese yen will rebound against the won on the back of a resilient Japanese economy."Since indicators showing an upturn in the Japanese economy are scheduled to be released this week, the yen is highly likely to gain value," said David Kim, an economist at Woori Securities Co.Observers expect that the economic indicators would encourage Japan`s central bank to further raise its interest rate, which would prompt global investors to buy more yen.The better-than-expected business confidence in Japan released on Monday clearly backed such an outlook.The quarterly Tankan survey, Japan`s most closely watched gauge of business sentiment, climbed to 24 points from 21 in June, according to the Bank of Japan.A figure above zero indicates that entrepreneurs who are optimistic about future economic conditions outnumber those who are not.Japan`s Finance Minister Koji Omi also said that Japan can declare an end to a seven-year-long deflation."Judging from the current state of the economy, we can declare Japan`s deflation is over," he said at a press conference in Tokyo yesterday."I think it`s a bit unnatural not to do so now." His remarks imply that Abe`s new administration would let the BOJ further raise the interest rate.Experts believe this will lead to a stronger yen against the dollar and the won.Moody`s Investors Service also forecast that Japan will probably be more creditworthy as Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledges to balance the country`s budget in five years and cut spending to reduce the world`s largest national debt."Policy continuity with former Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, together with stronger macroeconomic performance, including avoiding a relapse into deflation, are necessary to further shrink the budget deficit and to reduce the government`s exceptionally large debt," the U.S.-based credit rating agency said in a statement.The report noted Tokyo would not jeopardize the nation`s economic growth or the emergence from more than seven years of deflation through reform measures."The new administration unexpectedly stressed the independence of the central bank, and stepped back from controlling interest rate hikes," Woori`s Kim said.This would give more leeway to Japan`s inflation fighters who are eager to raise borrowing costs to curb the looming inflationary pressure.Shinyoung Securities Co.`s Ju Lee-hwan also predicts that the Japanese government would let its currency gain more value.He pointed to Japan`s massive current account surplus, which amounts to nearly 4 percent of the country`s annual output."It is justifiable for Washington and Europe to demand a stronger yen. Japan would find it increasingly hard to remain uncooperative (about the currency policy) while it declares an end to deflation," Ju said.The yen rose only about 10 percent against the greenback over the past five years, compared to nearly 50 percent of the euro and 27 percent of the won.But concerns still remain despite the rising expectations over the yen`s looming upturn.Market observers warn that the Korean won could further gain against the dollar, if the stronger yen triggers the upward rally of Asian currencies.As the Chinese government recently pledged to allow more flexibility in its foreign exchange market and let its currency further appreciate, Asian currencies are largely climbing against the dollar.The Chinese yuan has been trading below 7.9 renminbi per dollar in recent weeks, up about 5 percent from July 2005.Experts are worried that the Korean won would be put under mounting pressure for further appreciation, if both the yuan and yen rapidly gain against the U.S. dollar."The most positive foreign exchange move for the Korean economy and stock market is that the yuan slows down its rally and the yen continues to gain value," Woori`s Kim said."In this case, the yen will become stronger against the won while the won-dollar rate remains steady." (kkt@heraldm.com)a

title: [NEWS ANALYSIS]President ponders his options
content: President Roh Moo-hyun began pondering Prime Minister Lee Hae-chan`s offer to resign yesterday, leaving the political community speculating on his options and their ramifications for the current political situation.Prime Minister Lee, under pressure to resign for playing golf with "inappropriate partners" on March 1, the first day of a disruptive railway strike, relayed his intention to step down from the Cabinet chief post but Roh did not show any immediate response.Officials at Cheong Wa Dae suggested the president may take some time before making a decision on the fate of his trusted prime minister."The president would likely decide after hearing a full report on the matter from his chief of staff Lee Byung-wan," Roh`s spokesperson Kim Man-soo said.Roh has a number of options - ranging from turning down Lee`s resignation to retaining him in the office - which political experts say present bumper-to-bumper problems for Roh.A widespread opinion is that the president, despite his strong support for Lee, would have to let go of the premier. The ruling Uri Party, not to mention the opposition parties, deems the departure of Lee inevitable saying it would be very hard for Lee to regain public confidence. Opinion polls show over 60 percent of the public think Lee should quit, the party said."I personally don`t think the president will turn down the premier`s resignation," predicted Uri Rep. Rhee Mok-hee.Some speculate that Roh, who has a record of flying in the face of public sentiment which he says is influenced by the often biased local media, may wait until a clear answer is provided by the prosecution over the culpability of the prime minister. The prosecution launched an investigation to clarify corruption suspicions surrounding the now infamous golf round which Lee played with local businessmen in Busan.Another scenario has Roh making his embattled ally handle state affairs until the May 31 local elections and replace him only after the crucial event.While keeping Lee would mean a face-off with his political opponents ahead of the elections, losing him would point to a major adjustment of his plan for the rest of his term.Roh laid out his plans for the remaining two years in office with Lee in mind. Entering his fourth year in office last month, Roh said he will focus on two key objectives while the prime minister handles regular state affairs - easing socioeconomic polarization between the rich and the poor and pushing for a free trade agreement with the United States.The main opposition Grand National Party, having seized an opportunity to assail the ruling camp ahead of the crucial local elections, is threatening a parliamentary motion in cooperation with minor parties to oust Lee. Furthermore, the Uri Party, racing toward the upcoming local elections and later the 2007 presidential election, is likely to seek a separate path from the unpopular Roh.(milaya@heraldm.com)  By Lee Sun-young

title: [번역][NEWS ANALYSIS]Sloppy screening system causes `domino resignations...
content: Construction Minister Kang Dong-suk`s resignation demonstrates how lax the presidential office appointment system was and underlines public demand for higher moral standards of top public officials, experts say.Kang became the third Cabinet member under the Roh Moo-hyun government to resign following allegations of dubious real-estate deals.So far in 2005, four top government officials - Kang, former Education Minister Lee Ki-jun, former Finance Minister Lee Hun-jai and National Human Rights Commission Chairman Choi Young-do - have resigned due to accusations of real-estate speculation involving their relatives.The opposition parties asserted that it was the government`s "sloppy" appointment system that caused the situation and prompted it to set tighter inspections on officials."People want officials that can match the moral standard they have in their minds. This won`t be the last case unless Cheong Wa Dae improves its appointment system immediately," said main opposition Grand National Party floor leader Kang Jae-sup."Hopefully this is not a sign of growing corruption in Roh`s government, which had the slogan of reform and anticorruption in the 2002 presidential elections. To prove it untrue, Cheong Wa Dae must set up measures for thorough inspections," said minor opposition Democratic Labor Party lawmaker Sim Sang-jung.Acknowledging the severity of the situation, the presidential office is speeding up the modification of its appointment system with President Roh emphasizing the need of a full-scale reform.Cheong Wa Dae is to push for measures, such as holding parliamentary confirmation sessions on government officials, tighter inspections on candidates` assets, and entrusting organizations such as Korea Independent Commission Against Corruption to carry out separate investigations before the appointment.Also, the ruling Uri announced a push to reform the public officials ethics law in the April parliamentary extra session in order to seek tighter inspections of public officials assets.But while pushing for such goals, the officials at Cheong Wa Dae spoke of their difficulties."It is getting harder and harder to pick people these days. Officials here (in Cheong Wa Dae) worry that no one would want to accept official positions and take the risk of their past being exposed to the public," an official at Cheong Wa Dae told a local newspaper Sunday."Sometimes, officials get hurt and destroyed with no proper basis due to the irrational suspicions lodged by the press and civic groups," said another official. "It is no longer rules and principles but the `public sentiment law` that judges the officials."  Experts say that it is not only the government`s faulty appointment system but the public`s growing ability to gather information and the higher expectations for public officials that led to the present situation."With easier access to information, especially on the Internet, the public can easily inspect the officials themselves, leaving no secrets," said Professor Park Ho-rae of Tamna University. "Even things that would have been unknown or ignored in the past are no longer tolerated by the public now." And with the public`s higher standard, the officials can no longer keep their seats after their faults have been revealed, added Park. "It seems the main problem is that the government`s appointment system cannot match the growing social awareness any longer."  A politics professor told The Korea Herald on the condition of anonymity that he thinks it is nearly impossible to come up with a system that would completely put a stop to the vicious circle of public suspicion and officials` resignations."I personally think it would be impossible for the presidential office to verify everything before appointing a person," he said. "If the government focuses too much on finding a morally `spotless` person, and disregards a person`s ability and experience, then government affairs would be seriously harmed." (hayney@heraldm.com)  By Shin Hae-in   이번 강동석 건설부 장관의 사퇴에서 청와대의 임명체제가 얼마나 허술한 지가 드러난 동시에 고위공직자에 대해 국민이 요구하고 있는 높은 도덕수준을 다시 한번 일깨워 주었다.강 장관은 노무현 정부가 들어선 이래 부동산 거래 의혹으로 사퇴한 세 번째 각료가 되었다.2005년 들어 지금까지 강 장관과 이기준 전 교육부 장관, 이헌재 전 재경부 장관 그리고 최영도 국가인권위원회 위원장 등 4명의 고위공직자가 친척이 연루된 부동산 투기 의혹으로 사퇴했다.야당은 이런 사태는 정부의 “허술한” 임명체제로 인한 것이라고 주장하고 공직자에 대해 더욱 엄격한 조사를 요구했다.“국민은 공직자들이 국민이 생각하고 있는 도덕수준에 합당할 수 있기를 바란다. 청와대가 임명체제를 즉시 개선하지 않는 한 이번 사태는 마지막이 되지 않을 것”이라고 강재섭 한나라당 원내총무가 말했다.“2002년 대선에서 개혁과 부패철폐를 기치로 내걸었던 노무현 정부에서 부패가 증가하고 있다는 신호가 아니길 바란다. 그렇지 않다는 것을 증명하기 위해 청와대는 철저한 조사를 위한 대책을 수립해야 한다”고 심상정 민주노동당 의원이 말했다.사태의 심각성을 깨달은 청와대는 노 대통령이 전면적인 개혁의 필요성을 강조하는 가운데 임명체제의 개정을 서두르고 있다.청와대는 공직자에 대해 국회의 동의를 거친다든지 임명 대상자의 재산조사를 철저히 하며 임명에 앞서 부패방지위원회 등의 기구에 별도의 조사를 위임하는 등의 대책을 추진할 예정이다.또한 여당인 우리당은 공직자의 재산조사를 더욱 엄격하게 하기 위해 오는 4월 임시국회에서 공직자윤리법의 개정을 추진할 것이라고 발표했다. 그러나 청와대 관계자들은 그러한 목표를 추진함에 있어 자신들이 겪는 어려움을 토로했다.“요즘에는 인선 작업이 점점 더 힘들어지고 있다. 청와대 관리들은 아무도 고위공직을 받아들이지 않고 자신들의 과거 행적이 국민들에게 노출되는 리스크를 감수하려들지 않을까 우려하고 있다”고 한 청와대 관계자는 일요일 국내 신문과의 인터뷰에서 말했다.“이따금 청와대 관리들은 언론과 시민단체가 제기하는 부당한 의혹으로 인해 적절한 기준이 없어 상처 받고 난감한 입장에 처하게 된다”고 또 다른 관계자는 말했다. “공직자를 심판하는 것은 더 이상 법과 원칙이 아니라 ‘국민여론법’이다.”  전문가들은 현 상황을 낳은 것은 정부의 잘못된 인사체계가 아니라 고위 공직자에 관한 국민들의 정보수집 능력 향상과 높아진 기대감 때문이라고 말한다.“특히 인터넷을 비롯해 정보에 대한 접근이 보다 용이해 지면서 국민들은 공직자에 관한 모든 것을 손쉽게 조사할 수 있게 되어 비밀이 없어지게 되었다”고 박호래 탐라대 교수는 말했다. “심지어 과거라면 알려지지 않거나 무시되었을 사실조차 이제 국민들이 더 이상 용인하지 않게 되었다.”   그리고 국민들의 기준이 높아짐에 따라 과거 잘못이 공개되어진 고위공직자들은 더 이상 자리를 지킬 수 없게 되었다고 박 교수는 덧붙였다. “가장 중요한 문제는 정부의 인사검증시스템이 높아만 가는 사회적 인식을 더 이상 따라가지 못하고 있는 데 있다고 본다.”  익명을 요구한 한 정치학과 교수는 국민의 의혹 제기와 고위공직자의 사퇴라는 악순환의 고리를 완전히 단절시킬 수 있는 시스템을 만든다는 건 거의 불가능하다고 본다고 코리아 헤럴드에 말했다.“개인적으로 나는 청와대가 사람을 임명하기 전에 모든 것을 검증하는 일이 불가능할 거라고 본다”고 그는 말했다. “만일 정부가 개인의 능력과 경험은 무시한 채 도덕적으로 흠없는 사람만을 찾는 데 너무 많은 비중을 둘 경우 국정 운영은 크게 훼손될 것이다.”

title: [번역][NEWS ANALYSIS]China`s diplomacy put to test amid N.K. threat 북한...
content: With North Korea`s new bull-headed stance on the nuclear standoff, China`s diplomatic power over the reclusive North is being tested since it has so far played a lead role in bringing the North to three rounds of multilateral nuclear talks in Beijing.As the sole major ally of and key food supplier to the impoverished North, China has served as a diplomatic channel between concerned countries and the North during the whole process of the six-party talks on the North`s nuclear ambitions.Foreign affairs analysts say China will combine friendly diplomacy and pressure to turn around the North`s bombshell statement on Thursday that it already manufactured nuclear weapons and will boycott the nuclear talks indefinitely."Even though it is angry at the North`s recent threat, China will not express such sentiment publicly," said professor Yun Duk-min at the Institute of Foreign Affairs and National Security. "But China may put pressure on the North behind the doors, for example, indicating the issue can be referred to the U.N. Security Council."  He mentioned a similar case in 1994 when China agreed with the international community on punishing the North when it took out nuclear fuel rods from its 5-megawatt reactor despite continued warnings from the International Atomic Energy Agency. Then, the North allowed former U.S. President Jimmy Carter`s visit to Pyongyang in June, which laid the groundwork for a nuclear deal between Pyongyang and Washington.China`s efforts on the new development will be culminated when Wang Jiarui, head of the Chinese Communist Party International Department, visits Pyongyang this week, which will be the first official contact between the two countries following the North`s latest threat.Some have speculated that Wang will convey a personal letter of Chinese President Hu Jintao to North Korean leader Kim Jong-il to defuse the escalating tension."We may find out North Korea`s real position after Wang`s visit. I think China will present a strong position on the issue," a senior Foreign Ministry official said.Wang is expected to focus on whether the North`s claim of having built atomic bombs is a true game or its traditional brinkmanship. The dominant view sees it as Pyongyang`s strategy to raise the stakes ahead of a fresh round of six-party talks.If China finds the North is resorting to its old tactics to get compensations from the Bush administration, China may try to ally the North by promising some benefits including economic aid. Under the opposite scenario, China will have to join the United States in pressuring the North, observers say.Concerned countries are waiting to see how China`s clout over the North will work this time.Reflecting international expectations on China`s role, the United States and South Korea have called on China to induce the North back to attend the nuclear talks.U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice asked Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing that China enhances its roles on the nuclear issue and Li reaffirmed his country`s support for a nuclear-free Korean Peninsula, the Chinese government said Sunday."China will stay in touch with all relevant parties and strive to make the situation develop in a positive direction so that the six-party talks could be resumed as soon as possible," Li told Rice during their telephone conversation Saturday night.After his talks with senior U.S. officials, Foreign Minister Ban Ki-moon also said Sunday that both sides discussed views that China should strengthen its efforts to bring the North to the dialogue table.Besides outside requests, China itself is eager to abate the escalated tension because it is in China`s interest to keep the peninsula nuclear-free."China is also worried that North Korea`s possession of nuclear weapons will bring about the domino effect in Northeast Asia," Yun said. "Denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula is a crucial issue to China. If it is violated, its relations with the United States can also deteriorate."  China`s contribution to resolution of the nuclear issue has worked as its leverage in its negotiations with the United States on Taiwan issues.(shj@heraldm.com)  By Seo Hyun-jin   북한이 새롭게 강경 자세로 전환하면서 북한에 대한 중국의 외교력이 시험 받고 있다. 중국은 지금껏 3차례 열린 6자회담에 북한을 참가시키는 데 주도적 역할을 해왔기 때문이다.북한의 유일한 우방국이자 주요 식량지원국인 중국은 6자회담 개최 기간을 통틀어 관련국과 북한 사이의 외교 채널 역할을 해왔다.외교문제 전문가들은 지난주 목요일 핵보유국임과 동시에 6자회담 무기한 불참을 선언한 북한의 입장을 변화시키기 위해 중국은 우호적 외교와 압박을 병행할 거라고 말하고 있다.“북한의 최근 폭탄 선언에 대해 분개하고 있음에도 불구하고 중국은 그러한 감정을 공개적으로 표명하지 않을 것이다”라고 윤덕민 외교안보연구원 선임연구위원은 말했다. “그러나 중국은 북핵 문제가 유엔 안보리로 회부될 가능성 등을 시사하는 등 막후에서 북한에 대해 압박을 가할지 모른다.그는 1994년 국제원자력기구 (IAEA)의 계속된 경고에도 불구하고 북한이 5메가와트급 원자로에서 핵연료봉을 추출했을 때 북한을 징계해야 한다는 국제사회 여론에 중국이 동의했던 이와 유사한 사례를 언급했다. 당시 북한은 지미 카터 대통령의 방북을 허용했고 이는 북한과 미국간 핵문제 해결을 위한 토대를 마련했다.새로운 상황 해결을 위한 중국의 노력은 이번주 왕자루이 중국 당 대외연락부장이 방북하는 시점에 최고조에 이를 것이다. 이번 방문은 북한의 최근 폭탄 선언 이후 양국간 최초의 공식 접촉이 된다.일각에서는 왕자루이 중국 당 대외연락부장이 고조되고 있는 긴장을 완화시키기 위해 후진타오 주석의 친서를 김정일 국방위원장에게 전달할 거라고 추측했다.“왕자루이 부장의 방북 이후에야 북한의 진정한 입장을 알 수 있을 것이다. 나는 중국이 북핵 문제에 강력한 입장을 주장할 거라고 본다”고 한 외교부 고위 관리는 말했다.왕자루이 부장은 원자폭탄을 갖고 있다는 북한의 주장이 진실인지 아니면 기존의 벼랑끝 전술인지 여부를 파악하는 데 초점을 맞출 것으로 전망된다. 북한의 폭탄선언은 차기 6자회담을 앞두고 협상력을 높이기 위한 전략이라는 견해가 지배적이다.만일 북한이 부시 행정부에게서 보상을 얻어내기 위해 구태의연한 전술을 사용한 사실을 중국이 알게 될 경우 중국은 경제 지원을 포함한 상당한 보상을 약속하는 방식으로 북한을 달래려 할지 모른다. 그 반대의 시나리오인 경우 중국은 미국과 합세하여 대북 압박에 나설 거라고 전문가들은 말하고 있다.관련국들은 이번에 북한에 대한 중국의 영향력이 어떻게 작용할 것인지 관망하고 있다.중국의 역할에 대한 국제사회의 기대감을 반영하듯 미국과 한국은 중국이 북한을 6자회담에 복귀시켜 줄 것을 중국에 요청하고 있다.콘돌리사 라이스 미 국무장관은 북핵 문제와 관련해 중국이 역할을 강화해 줄  것을 리자오싱 중국 외교부장에게 요청했다. 리자오싱 외교부장은 한반도 비핵화에 대한 중국의 지지의사를 재확인했다고 중국 정부는 일요일 말했다.“중국은 차기 6자회담의 조기 개최를 위해 모든 관계 당사자와 접촉을 지속하고 상황이 호전되도록 노력할 것이다”라고 리자오싱 외교부장은 토요일 밤 전화 통화를 통해 라이스 국무장관에게 말했다.미국 고위 관리들과 회담을 가진 후 반기문 외교부 장관도 토요일 중국이 북한을 협상 테이블로 나오게 하려는 노력을 강화해야 한다는 견해를 양측이 확인했다고 말했다.외부의 요청 이외에 중국 자신도 한반도 비핵화가 자국의 이해와 관련이 있기 때문에 고조되는 긴장을 완화하기를 열망하고 있다.“중국도 북한의 핵무기 보유가 동북아에 도미노 현상을 불러올 것을 우려하고 있다”고 윤 연구위원은 말했다. “한반도 비핵화는 중국에게 있어 중대한 이슈이다. 그렇지 못할 경우 미국과 중국간 관계도 악화될 수 있다.”  북핵 문제 해결을 위한 중국의 기여는 양안 문제를 둘러싼 미국과의 협상에서 힘을 발휘해 왔다.

title: [Hwang’s China and the World] Seeking new Korea-China relations: Evalua...
content: Min Kwi-sik (left) and Dong Xiangrong.Now is the time for Korea and China to look back on the past, face the present and talk about the future. Over the past 30 years, Korea-China relations have developed to the point that we may call it explosive in respective fields. The establishment of Korea-China diplomatic relations was an important turning point in advancing the new era of prosperity in Northeast Asia. And now both Korea and China have grown into the core countries in the international community. China, along with the United States, has grown into a major powerhouse in the international community, and Korea has become a globally charming country. Nevertheless, it is also true that there are some friction and conflicts due to the rapid growth and compressed development of the relationship. However, the two countries should endeavor to overcome the current growing pains and build a more mature partnership. Korea and China are neighbors that cannot move away from one another. This geographic condition makes us take an approach in a longer-term perspective, with a longer breath. Meeting the 30th anniversary of Korea-China diplomatic relations this year, we should take it as an opportunity to further strengthen the infrastructure of the relationship and establish a new type of Korea-China relationship that enables strategic communication.In this regard, we prepared a series on seeking new Korea-China relations for three weeks including today, from the perspectives of social culture, economic trade and diplomatic and security. This week’s interview invites two representative experts on social culture, the first theme of our series. First, we have Dong Xiangrong, the senior research fellow at the National Institute of International Strategy, Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, and professor Min Kwi-sik from the Graduate School of International Studies in Hanyang University who also serves as the director of the Institute of Chinese Studies.Hwang: What is the scale of interpersonal communication between the two countries? Please analyze it from the perspective of quantity and quality.Dong: In terms of numbers, the number of people-to-people exchange is particularly valuable considering that South Korea has a population of only 52 million and the two countries are not connected by land, only by sea and air routes. However, as neighboring countries, although there have been over 100 million exchanges between China and South Korea in the past 30 years, the percentage of people who have visited each other’s country is not high. It is estimated that no more than 3 percent of China’s 1.4 billion population have visited South Korea, while a large proportion of South Korean visitors are business travelers who frequently travel between China and South Korea. What is the percentage of South Koreans who have direct experience of China? 30 percent? “Seeing is believing.” I hope more South Korean people come to China to experience the profound Chinese culture.Min: The people exchanges between Korea and China have grown rapidly. The peak was in 2016, with 8.26 million Chinese visitors to Korea and 4.76 million Koreans visiting China, exceeding 13 million in total. Since then, the number has decreased sharply due to the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) anti-missile system and COVID-19, however, it will recover to a considerable level after a while. The number of long-term residents from each country is the criteria to identify the qualitative exchanges. Today we have 1 Chinese for every 50 Koreans living in Korea, and 1 Korean for every 80 Chinese in China, which shows that the two countries are deeply linked and engaged to each other.Hwang: What is the situation for South Koreans in China?Dong: According to statistics from South Korea’s Foreign Ministry, there were 256,875 South Koreans in China in 2021. The total number of South Koreans in China has stabilized at 250,000 in the past decade, and the number of South Korean students in China has fallen by nearly half compared with the number five years ago. Currently, the number of Chinese in South Korea is about 800,000, and there are about 60,000 Chinese students in South Korea. Sizable Korean-populated areas have been formed in Wangjing in Beijing, Chengyang in Qingdao, Gubei in Shanghai, and these places have become attractive sites for Chinese people to experience Korean culture.Hwang: How would you describe the current circumstances of Chinese people in Korea and what challenges are there?Min: The long-stay Chinese in Korea are actually the major resource that supports the basic areas of the Korean economy, but the evaluation on these people is quite low. Technically they are the reliable speakers in terms of delivering Korean images to China. In this sense, it is problematic to portray Chinatown in a negative angle in films. In particular, the attitude toward Korean countrypeople living as second-class citizens in both China and Korea should be changed. Prior to improving the immigration policy, social and legal support for ethnic Koreans in China should be strengthened.Hwang: What are the achievements of the Korean Wave in China?Min: The Korean Wave first started with dramas and expanded into music, films and culture. But the thing is that Hallyu fans are limited to only certain generations. We must understand that the Korean Wave can only be maintained when it is supported by steady economic growth and democratic politics. Since the true Korean Wave can bear fruit by having people relish ‘Korea’ itself beyond just a few cultural genres, a comprehensive perspective and approach are essential to enhance Korea's soft power.Dong: The Korean Wave is an important channel for Chinese people to learn about South Korea. It has prevailed in China since the 1990s. In the beginning, some TV drama series with the theme of family life attracted a large number of middle-aged and elderly women viewers. The common identity in a Confucian cultural sphere made Chinese audiences regard South Korean culture as “an old friend.” South Korean romance dramas have captivated many young Chinese. It is jokingly said that the popularity of the Korean Wave has greatly increased women’s requirements for their partners, which indirectly had an impact on the decline of their desire for marriage. In recent years, Chinese teenagers have become enamored with K-pop and other popular culture. Regardless of China’s security concerns, the deployment of the US THAAD system greatly dampened the enthusiasm for the Korean Wave fans in China. The Korean Wave’s fever has been reduced. Even so, the Chinese public’s appreciation for Korean pop culture is still palpable. I personally run a social media blog with more than 80,000 followers in China. I once asked which South Korean movie was their favorite and received thousands of comments. It had far more clout than similar questions related to other countries.Hwang: What are the achievements of Korean-language promotion in China?Dong: From a worldwide perspective, the place where Korean education has developed most rapidly in terms of either speed or scale over the past 30 years in the world is China. Before the establishment of diplomatic ties between China and South Korea, only five universities in China had a Korean language major, such as Peking University and Yanbian University. Since the establishment of diplomatic ties, there has been a boost in the number of universities offering Korean language as a major. At present, more than 200 universities in China offer Korean language as a major, which is unimaginable in any other country. The demand for Korean language talents from Korean enterprises in China, Chinese enterprises in Korea, universities, academic institutions and foreign affairs agencies in governments at all levels has promoted the widespread development of Korean language education in China. In recent years, as the expansion of market demand has dropped, the number of students majoring in Korean language has also declined. Nevertheless, some Chinese learn Korean simply to better understand Korean culture and listen to Korean songs.Hwang: Is there any particular stories on achievements or challenges of the Chinese language fever in Korea?Min: As can be seen from the fact that many private Chinese academies closed down, the current Chinese fever has cooled considerably. It may be in a sense of growing pain, however, actually not many people necessarily need to learn Chinese. With the advent of interpretation apps, those who are willing to travel or appreciate Chinese culture can easily and technically find the solution. In addition, as China's cultural capacity grows, the number of people who naturally learn Chinese will increase. Therefore, what we should do now is make more efforts to raise the level of graduates from related departments which are specializing in Chinese.Hwang: What is the scale of Koreans among international students in China?Dong: Before the pandemic, China was the top destination for overseas study in Asia. The biggest group of international students in China is South Korean students. According to statistics from China’s Ministry of Education, there were 492,200 international students in China in 2018, 50,600 students of whom were from South Korea. After the outbreak of the pandemic, the number of international students in China dropped. Statistics from South Korea’s Foreign Ministry show that 34,000 South Korean students studied in China in 2021. The number is significantly lower than the number of Chinese students in South Korea. When it comes to Korean students studying in China, it reminds me of Choe Chi-won from the Silla Dynasty (57 BC-AD 935), who came to study in the Tang Dynasty (AD 618-907) and spread Chinese culture far and wide. The large group of overseas students has made an important contribution to enhancing exchanges between China and South Korea. Many of them have become leading figures in South Korea.Hwang: How many Chinese students are in Korea? What kind of achievements have they made or what are the challenges are they facing?Min: Last year, about 67,000 students out of 152,000 international students were Chinese students and that makes up 44.2 percent. Although the ratio has decreased compared to 10 years ago, since the number of international students has been increasing slightly, we can say the number of Chinese students was not largely affected by the THAAD issue. However, the fact that Chinese students mostly choose to study liberal arts in Korea might mean that our level of science and engineering should grow further. On the other hand, the percentage of students who came to Korea because they liked Korea, but return to their country as an anti-Korean after studying here is recording a pretty high rate. This is a problematic phenomenon. Only when the academic management of international students become more active and cautious, Korea’s competitiveness of studying in Korea will be maintained.Hwang: What is the situation of Korea-related majors at Chinese universities?Dong: There are roughly over 100 research institutions related to the Korean Peninsula in China. Korean institutions such as the Korea Foundation for Advanced Studies, the Academy of Korean Studies, and the Korea Foundation have provided various support to Chinese Korean Peninsula research institutes. In the past 30 years, Chinese scholars have applied for more than 300 projects related to the Korean Peninsula supported by the National Social Science Fund of China, which has greatly promoted Chinese scholars’ all-round research on the Korean Peninsula in terms of politics, economy, society, history and culture.Hwang: There are a few Korean universities that have China studies departments. What are the current situations there and what challenges are they facing?Min: First of all, many of the Chinese departments in local universities have closed down, and overall admissions are falling. This is due to the result that reflects people’s perception toward China, however, the abolishment of the department mustn’t be a hasty decision. Chinese studies that aims to teach its social science should be remained, even if the department changes into East Asian studies. Looking at these changes from a distance, we need human resources who major in Chinese-related studies and have capacities that exceed what a university can teach them. Considering China's growth, its size and importance, we cannot say that the current number of majors in Chinese studies is excessive.Hwang: What is the status of media and public opinion exchanges between the two countries?Min: The media is usually a window to understand other countries, but the two countries' media have failed their roles in the sense of making the other countries understand objectively. This is due to the sensational reporting based on the commercial nature of media. In addition, the emergence of online media outlets is mostly focused on making certain targets unappealing, rather than extending the positive aspect of exchanging information. In particular, as the government cannot control such information, conflicts between the two countries’ private sectors are amplified. In the end, when it comes to the solution, we have no other choice but to count on improvement in civic awareness although it must take some time.Dong: The mainstream media of China and South Korea have correspondents stationed in each other’s countries. They send back a large amount of information to the people of the two countries for reference. A relatively stable exchange mechanism has been established between major media of the two countries, such as the China-ROK Media High-level Dialogue. The main problem is that the image of each other’s country in mainstream media is not symmetrical. The coverage of China in South Korean media is generally negative. It has to do with South Korea’s news predilection for grabbing attention and focusing on negative events. The coverage of South Korea in mainstream Chinese media is generally positive. However, a new phenomenon has emerged in recent years with social media flourishing. In pursuit of clout, some bloggers not only tend to report negative news about other countries, but also would like to hype up negative news about their country debated in other countries. Some harsh, extreme views end up rapidly spreading on the internet, which exerts a negative impact on China and South Korea’s public opinion field and heavily affects people’s mutual understanding between the two countries.Hwang: What are the social and cultural conflicts between Korea and China?Dong: China and South Korea are culturally homologous, geographically similar and historically intertwined. It is regrettable that the historical experience, which should have increased mutual recognition, has triggered conflicts in today’s international political context. The social and cultural contradictions between China and South Korea mainly focus on two areas. The first is about the perception and collective memory of the past, including the nature of the relationship between the two countries in history, the Korean War and other issues. The second is the attribution of traditional culture. Basic principles need to be noted here, that is, the concept of the modern nation-state should not be used to analyze international relations in ancient times, nor can the concept of intellectual property in the contemporary world be used to define the ownership of ancient cultural products.Min: The core causes of the conflict between Korea and China are the issues that are highly abstract, such as the matters of historical and cultural sovereignty. As these matters are directly connected to the national identity, it is terribly difficult to make any kind of concessions or resolutions. This is why these problems usually stay under the ground but detonate once conflict arises. The basis of this sentiment comes from the reality that that historical superiority and inferiority are contradictory to the current national income level. Each has this psychological aspect to compensate their inferiority with a sense of superiority, therefore, even a small conflict tends to be greatly amplified.Hwang: What is the reason for the spread of anti-Korea sentiment?Min: As Korea and China built a functionalist approach that emphasizes reciprocal economic necessity, their emotional trust is relatively weak compared to the volume of trade. The root of the public's anti-Chinese sentiment is quite specific, for instance the fine dust problem. This anti-Chinese sentiment has been strengthened as it has caused inconveniences for people in life and such feelings tend to accumulate. Moreover, fear of China's rise has prompted resistance against the Chinese political system, and the continued ideological offensive by the conservatives has also played a major role. On top of that, the individualistic characteristics of the young generation might have overlapped, so the anti-Chinese sentiment spread to a degree that far exceeded economic benefits.Dong: Personally, I do not agree with the term “anti-Korean sentiment in China.” It is not so much opposing Korea as disliking Korea, which is a negative perception and sentiment toward Korea. Two time points were vital in the spread of the sentiment of disliking Korea. The first was the deployment of THAAD, which made many Chinese people very disappointed in South Korea. Therefore, the sentiment of disliking South Korea rose in China. During the Moon Jae-in administration, after China and South Korea reached a basic consensus on the THAAD issue and properly handled it, bilateral relations saw a turnaround at a critical phase. In fact, negative sentiment toward South Korea in the Chinese public has eased somewhat in recent years. However, it is a pity that the Beijing Winter Olympics this year has brought about some controversies on hanbok, referee’s decisions, etc. South Korea’s arguments were shocks to the Chinese people. From the Chinese public’s perspective, as one of the 56 ethnic groups in China, there is no reason why the Korean minority should not be allowed to sing and dance in their traditional costume at the Winter Olympics. Besides, any dispute over a referee’s decision in sports should be settled through established procedures, and an important basis for participating in sports competition is to accept the referee’s decision. And, it was rare to see responsible Korean politicians, scholars and sports figures make a rational and objective analysis on these issues. Some of them would rather add to the disputes than calm them.Hwang: What is the best way to carry out social and cultural exchanges between the two countries for the next five years? What advice do you have for the two governments?Dong: We need to let history be history, and let culture be culture and sport be sport. The stable development of the relationship between China and South Korea should not be interfered or even hijacked by other factors. History, culture and sports should become an important bond for enhancing bilateral relations. Politicians and the people of both countries need to realize that developing bilateral relations is in the fundamental interests of the two countries and their peoples. The social and cultural exchanges between the two countries are not too much, but too little and too inadequate. The people of the two countries do not know each other well enough. Anyone who hypes up the so-called dispute between China and South Korea to pursue their own selfish interests will eventually be abandoned by history. As the theme song of the 1988 Seoul Olympics goes, “Hand in hand, we can start to understand, breaking down the walls that come between us for all time.”Min: First of all, we must acknowledge the serious emotional conflict between the peoples from the respective countries and share the necessity for countermeasures. Since the two countries' national sentiments are sensitive to political and diplomatic issues, the most important thing is to reduce strategic conflicts and to increase political trust. China should be aware that its soft power has greatly weakened and readjust its public diplomacy toward neighboring countries. South Korean officials should reduce unnecessary misstatements that provoke China. Lastly, it is necessary to jointly start global citizenship education activities to get rid of excessive nationalist sentiment and to operate them as a 1.5 track that involves private organizations.By Hwang Jae-hoHwang Jae-ho is a professor of the Division of International Studies at the Hankuk University of Foreign Studies. He is also the director of the Institute for Global Strategy and Cooperation. This discussion was assisted by researcher Ko Sung-hwah and Shin Eui-chan.

title: [NEWS ANALYSIS]Civil servant union faces uphill battle
content: Confrontations between the government and illegally unionized government employees are set to intensify as the union yesterday called an unprecedented walkout for Monday.Despite repeated warnings by the authorities that to conduct a strike vote would be illegal, the Korean Government Employees Union launched a vote Tuesday, only to be blocked by thousands of police.Although it was unable to complete the balloting, the unauthorized labor group, which was formed two and a half years ago, proclaimed it will conduct the strike as planned, and will begin an all-out battle against a government-initiated special bill relating to civil servants` labor rights.If Monday`s strike materializes, it has the potential to seriously disrupt the nation`s administrative services. The KGEU claims to have about 140,000 members - almost half the 300,000 low-ranking public service workers in Korea. The members work in local-government positions as well as for the national government.Nonetheless, the union appears to face an uphill battle.Right to strike  At the center of the dispute lies a question on which neither the government nor the KGEU can easily give in, for different reasons. It is whether civil servants should be allowed to conduct collective actions such as strikes.The controversy arose when the government completed drafting a special bill on civil servant`s unionization and labor rights. The bill, which is now pending in the Environment and Labor Committee of the National Assembly, would grant government employees the right to form a union and to negotiate collectively on matters relating working conditions, but not the right to strike.The draft fell short of pleasing the currently-illegal union, which has been demanding full labor rights.However, the Prime Minister Lee Hae-chan reiterated in a Cabinet meeting Tuesday that allowing civil servant to strike will not happen in any case."While private companies have a countermeasure to deal with a strike by employees - the lockout - the government does not," he said, rejecting the KGEU`s demand that civil servants be treated as same as private-sector workers."The government will no longer tolerate the illegal activities of civil servants regarding this matter," Yonhap News quoted the prime minister as saying.Ironically, the government seems to have been caught in what began as an effort to give public service workers more labor rights."The bill is in itself the work of relatively liberal-minded administration," says Lee Joo-hee, a researcher at the National Labor Institute. "Although it doesn`t allow the full three labor rights, the move is a clear improvement compared to the current situation," Lee said."What union is asking seems to be too much at this point," she added.The three labor rights are the right to organize, to bargain collectively, and to strike.Nonetheless, the KGEU asserts that government workers` labor rights, which the union claims are guaranteed by the Constitution, have been denied for more than 50 years, and the workers have been forced to serve the nation without letting their voices be heard.By denying civil servants the right of collective action and also barring crucial parts of their right of negotiation, the government`s claimed intent to empower civil servants with the labor rights they are due is empty rhetoric, the union says."The special bill is aimed at putting a leash on the union activities, not granting the rights civil servants have long been deprived of," Jung Young-hae, the KGEU spokesperson told The Korea Herald.With full labor rights, civil servants can act as a monitoring entity within the government, thus helping to revamp corruption-ridden public sectors, he claimed.Replying to the prime minister`s argument, the union has responded that government can allow them the right to strike and then seek to outline a possible measure to put hold on strike like some other countries do.Countries like France and the U.K. allow full labor rights to civil servants, but also give the government measures to bring strikes to a halt, Labor Ministry data shows. Some other countries like Japan and Germany completely block civil servants` right to walk out, however.The International Labor Organization has advised the Korean government to allow full labor rights, including the right to strike, with limited restrictions related to national security, the union says.Civil servants` compensation  Civil servants in Korea have long been regarded as having "an iron rice bowl," a reference to lifetime employment that continues without regard to capability or job performance.In addition to job security, government employees receive various benefits that are not given many private sector workers, such as retirement pensions, financial support for housing and child-care, and tax benefits, to name a few.Those benefits are intended partly to compensate for the gap between the salaries received by government and private-sector workers.Traditionally, the government has been frugal on employees` monthly pay. However, the Civil Service Commission told The Korea Herald that typical government workers earn 95.9 percent of what typical private sector workers receive. The improvement is the result of a government five-year plan to boost civil servant`s pay. In 1999, a typical public official received only 88.4 percent of what a private sector worker received.For the last several years, while workers at private firms received pay raises averaging 5 to 7 percent, government employees` salary increased by 7 to 12 percent.For this reason, the government and many Koreans are denouncing the KGEU for demanding equal treatment with private sector workers at the same time they receive a handful of extra benefits that non-government workers don`t get.The KGEU says, however, that the "iron rice bowl" perception of public service workers is no longer accurate."The government has a clear vision to make the public sector labor pool more flexible by 2007. So civil service worker are increasingly exposed to possible layoffs," the KGEU`s Jung argues.The outlook  The assembly Environment and Labor Committee is scheduled to start deliberations on the civil servant bill next Tuesday.Backed by the nation`s two big umbrella unions, the KGEU is seeking to influence the deliberation and press the authorities to grant public workers full labor rights by staging a massive strike and rallies for an indefinite period.However, winning the campaign won`t be easy.The government, buoyed by support from the two major political parties, and rapidly mobilizing public and media opinion, is likely to remain firmly against granting public workers the right to strike.Further, the union appears to be suffering from internal hesitation, as a group of local union leaders reportedly has resigned in the face of the harsh police crackdown and a number of branches did not response to the headquarters` call to begin voting.A strike could generate a strong public reaction.Netizens already have issued a blizzard of angry remarks on Internet bulletin boards about the union`s efforts to conduct the illegal strike vote.A Labor Ministry poll conducted in September found that more than 70 percent of Koreans oppose giving civil servants the right to strike, while a majority of respondents agreed with the government`s plan to grant civil servants other basic labor rights.Asked about the KGEU`s planned strike, 27-year-old Yoo Jun-in, who said she has been preparing for a national exam to become a public official, reacted strongly. "I agree with the fact that civil servants should be recognized as laborers and should be given basic labor rights. But they shouldn`t forget all the benefits they receive for being a civil servant," she said."They work short hours and enjoy a five-day work week. I think it is selfish to ask for more, causing public distress through a strike," she added.Park Chul-jun, a 59-year-old retiree, said a civil servants` strike will worsen the nation`s already troubled economy and only hurt public sentiment."At this time of trouble, civil servants are those who are supposed to care for the nation`s future and make sacrifices. If they put their own interests first, who cares for the national interest?" he asked.(milaya@heraldm.com)  By Lee Sun-young

title: [NEWS ANALYSIS]Korea scrambles as U.S. confirms troop cuts
content: Long anticipated, it is now official: U.S. troop levels in South Korea will be cut by one third during the next 18 months although Seoul will seek a delay.On Monday night U.S. President George W. Bush unveiled his plan to bring home 60,000 to 70,000 servicemen and over 100,000 civilians stationed in Europe and Asia over the next 10 years.The planned reduction of troops in South Korea to about 25,000 is part of an American military realignment aimed at mitigating a new age of warfare after the end of the Cold War.Koreans have been preparing for the announcement for over a year, yet they are still in the dark on security issues with arch enemy North Korea and whether the South can afford to build up its defense to be self-reliant.The Korean government is scrambling to buy time and will request the United States to delay its plan to withdraw a large portion of the troops now stationed here.The two countries will hold a round of talks next week to discuss alliance issues, and Korean officials said the rescheduling of the U.S. troop reduction will be the main topic.Responding to Bush`s speech, Korea Foreign Minister Ban Ki-moon told reporters, "There will be no change in our country. We have been negotiating with the United States over the troop reduction. Details related to the troop cut will be discussed between the two countries." President Roh Moo-hyun is now unveiling his plans for the Korean military to be independent of foreign support. But this will mean spending a lot more money than is now earmarked for defense, experts say."The budget for defense stands at 2.8 percent currently, but the government will have to raise it up to 4.5 percent. This means taking the allotted portion from welfare or culture budgets," said Yu Suk-ryul, a researcher at the Institute of Foreign Affairs and National Security.This amount of spending worries economic watchers concerned about Korea`s slumping economy.Many also believe the reduction in U.S. troops will leave a "security vacuum." Despite years of progress in peace projects with North Korea, the communist state still cranks up the rhetoric against Seoul and Washington, and has not agreed to dismantle its nuclear weapons program."It`s premature to talk about withdrawing the troops," said professor Lee Jung-hoon of Yonsei University. North Korea has not changed its military policy and the United States should not change its policy either, he added.North Korea is expected to signal its disapproval of the U.S. troops cut plan because it may give Japan`s military a greater role in the region, Yu said.About 34,000 U.S. troops are now stationed in Korea following the redeployment of 3,600 to Iraq earlier this month. The United States will also be redeploying its 2nd Infantry Division south of the Han River by next year and relocating the Eighth Army`s main headquarters in downtown Seoul to an area one hour south of the capital by 2008.A survey conducted by The Korea Herald and published Monday said that despite growing anti-American sentiment here among young South Koreans, a majority of lawmakers want to maintain the status quo of U.S. troops on the peninsula.Of 237 lawmakers who responded to the survey, a total of 146, or 61.6 percent, want to keep the number of troops at current levels.Some U.S. commentators praised the Bush plan and said it was overdue. Thirty years ago troop cuts were not possible but now South Korea can afford to defend itself, said one supporter.Bush plans to spend $11 billion to update forces here and deploy cutting-edge technology that will require fewer personnel in combat situations."We`ll take advantage of 21st century military technologies to rapidly deploy increased combat power," Bush said in his address to veterans in Ohio on Monday. He added the long-term plan is designed to reduce stress on troops and their families.The troop realignment has become an issue of November`s U.S. presidential election.Democratic candidate John Kerry`s advisers were quickly on the attack. Retired Gen. Wesley Clark called it an "ill conceived move" and said its timing seemed politically motivated rather than designed to strengthen U.S. national security.Richard Holbrooke, a foreign policy aide to Kerry, told CNN reporters the nation should not withdraw troops from South Korea while the United States and other nations are still engaged in nuclear weapon reduction talks with the North.Bush supporters said the realignment will save American taxpayers money by closing down bases, but the Kerry camp issued figures that disagree.The United States is rebuilding a post-war Iraq with heavy resistance from insurgents and it is still committed to fighting a global war on terror with al-Qaida active in more than 60 countries.(apetty@heraldm.com)  (yeojean@heraldm.com)   By Andrew Petty and Chang Yeojean

title: [NEWS ANALYSIS]Korea scrambles as U.S. confirms troop cuts
content: Long anticipated, it is now official: U.S. troop levels in South Korea will be cut by one third during the next 18 months although Seoul will seek a delay.On Monday night U.S. President George W. Bush unveiled his plan to bring home 60,000 to 70,000 servicemen and over 100,000 civilians stationed in Europe and Asia over the next 10 years.The reduction of troops in South Korea is part of an American military realignment aimed at mitigating a new age of warfare after the end of the Cold War.Koreans have been preparing for the announcement for over one year, yet they are still in the dark on security issues with arch enemy North Korea and whether the South can afford to build up its defense to be self-reliant.The Korean government is scrambling to buy time and will request the United States to delay its plan to withdraw a large portion of the troops now stationed here. The two countries will hold a round of talks next week to discuss alliance issues, and Korean officials said the rescheduling of the U.S. troop reduction will be the main topic.Responding to Bush`s speech, Korea Foreign Minister Ban Ki-moon said, "There would be no change in our country."We have been negotiating with the United States over the troop reduction. Details related to the troop cut will be discussed between the two countries," he told reporters.President Roh Moo-hyun is now unveiling his plans for the Korean military to be independent of foreign support. But this will mean spending a lot more money than is now earmarked for defense, experts say."The budget for defense stands at 2.8 percent currently, but the government will have to raise it by up to 4.5 percent. This means taking the allotted portion from welfare or culture budgets," said Yu Suk-ryul, a researcher at the Institute of Foreign Affairs and National Security.This amount of spending worries economic watchers concerned about Korea`s slumping economy.Many also believe the reduction in U.S. troops will leave a "security vacuum." Despite years of progress in peace projects with North Korea, the communist state still cranks up the rhetoric against Seoul and Washington, and has not agreed to dismantle its nuclear weapons program."It`s premature to talk about withdrawing the troops," said professor Lee Jung-hoon of Yonsei University. North Korea has not changed its military policy and the United States should not change its policy either, he added.North Korea is expected to signal its disapproval of the U.S. troops cut plan because it may give a greater role to Japan`s military in the region, Yu said.About 34,000 U.S. troops are now stationed in Korea following the redeployment of 3,600 to Iraq earlier this month.
