It is essential to know what field and what type of popular culture each country is ready to receive. Upon this ground, a basic change of policy regarding Hallyu should be made to continue to raise the national image and to present a vision of cultural policy in conformity with the global age.Therefore, we should not conclude simply with a culture-industrial approach as other advanced powers have done. Rather we should humbly accept it as an opportunity to make a cultural approach and to realize mutual interchange and cooperation. We are to make it a project in which every effort will be taken to make every field of our society first-class.By Kang Chul-keun

title: (2nd LD) govt-economic assessment
content: (2nd LD) Economic slowdown to continue on slumping exports, higher inflation: finance ministry(ATTN: UPDATES with more info in last 2 paras; ADDS photo)By Kang Yoon-seung   SEJONG, Feb. 17 (Yonhap) -- South Korea's finance ministry said Friday the country's economy has slowed amid higher inflation and sluggish exports.   "South Korea's inflation remains at a high plateau, and domestic consumption recovery is slowing down. A persistent slump in exports and deteriorating business sentiment indicate an economic downturn," the Ministry of Economy and Finance said.   The finance ministry had been mentioning the possibility of an economic slowdown in its monthly economic assessment report, called the Green Book, since June last year.   "(Since June), South Korea's exports have been sharply losing ground, and recently, even consumption started to slow," Lee Seung-han, the director of the ministry's economic analysis division, said during a press conference.Lee Seung-han, the director of the economic analysis division under the Ministry of Economy and Finance, speaks during a press conference held in the central city of Sejong on Feb. 17, 2023. (Yonhap) It marked the first time for the ministry to assess that the economy has slowed since the country gradually recovered from the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic.   In January, the country's trade deficit reached a monthly record high of US$12.69 billion, marking the 11th straight month of losses, primarily due to soaring energy costs. South Korea is highly dependent on energy imports.   Consumer prices, a key gauge of inflation, rose 5.2 percent in January from a year earlier, compared with 5 percent growth estimated in December. Inflation rose by 5 percent or higher for the ninth month in a row.   "Externally, there are hopes over the reopening of China, and the soft landing of the global economy," the report said. "Uncertainties (however) linger due to the monetary-tightening moves and concerns over the prolonged war between Russia and Ukraine."   South Korea's economy is estimated to have grown 2.6 percent on-year in 2022, slowing from a 4.1 percent gain the previous year, the central bank's data showed last month.   The finance ministry expects the country's economy to grow 1.6 percent on-year in 2023 as it braces for the impact of global monetary tightening moves. People shop for groceries at a supermarket in Seoul on Feb. 15, 2023 (Yonhap)colin@yna.co.kr(END)

title: (LEAD) govt-economic assessment
content: (LEAD) Economic slowdown to continue on slumping exports, higher inflation: finance ministry(ATTN: CLARIFIES lead, paras 2-5 with details)By Kang Yoon-seung   SEJONG, Feb. 17 (Yonhap) -- South Korea's finance ministry said Friday the country's economy has slowed amid higher inflation and sluggish exports.   "South Korea's inflation remains at a high plateau, and domestic consumption recovery is slowing down. A persistent slump in exports and deteriorating business sentiment indicate an economic downturn," the Ministry of Economy and Finance said.   The finance ministry had been mentioning the possibility of an economic slowdown in its monthly economic assessment report, called the Green Book, since June last year.   "(Since June), South Korea's exports have been sharply losing ground, and recently, even consumption started to slow," Lee Seung-han, the director of the ministry's economic analysis division, said during a press conference.   It marked the first time for the ministry to assess that the economy has slowed since the country gradually recovered from the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic.   In January, the country's trade deficit reached a monthly record high of US$12.69 billion, marking the 11th straight month of losses, primarily due to soaring energy costs. South Korea is highly dependent on energy imports.   Consumer prices, a key gauge of inflation, rose 5.2 percent in January from a year earlier, compared with 5 percent growth estimated in December. Inflation rose by 5 percent or higher for the ninth month in a row.   "Externally, there are hopes over the reopening of China, and the soft landing of the global economy," the report said. "Uncertainties (however) linger due to the monetary-tightening moves and concerns over the prolonged war between Russia and Ukraine."People shop for groceries at a supermarket in Seoul on Feb. 15, 2023 (Yonhap)colin@yna.co.kr(END)

title: \<PRNewswire\>약 1만9천500명에 달하는 투자 전문가들, CFA 1급 시험 통과
content: [편집자 주] 본고는 자료 제공사에서 제공한 것으로, 연합뉴스는 내용에 대해 어떠한 편집도 하지 않았음을 밝혀 드립니다.-- APAC 응시자 수는 이 지역에서 CFA의 높은 관련성 반증 -- 업계 수준을 높이고, 신뢰를 회복하는데 열성적인 응시자들(홍콩 2014년 2월 11일 PRNewswire=연합뉴스) 전문적인 우수성과 자격에 관한 기준을 설정하는 투자전문가들의 글로벌 연합인 CFA Institute의 보고에 따르면, 2013년 12월 국제재무분석사(Chartered Financial Analyst, CFA) 1급 시험에 응시한 4만5천693명 중 43%가 시험에 통과하고, 고도로 훈련된 윤리적인 차세대 투자전문가 대열에 합류하기 위한 첫 단계에 진입했다고 한다. 2013년 6월과 12월에 총 9만3천195명이 CFA 프로그램 1급 시험에 응시했다. CFA 프로그램은 국제적으로 인정받는 대학원 수준의 교육과정으로, 이론 및 실천을 실제 세계 투자분석과 연계하고, 가장 높은 수준의 윤리 및 전문가 기준을 강조한다. (로고: http://www.prnasia.com/sa/2013/12/16/20131216173537320331.jpg )2013년 12월 APAC에서는 총 2만1천388명이 CFA 1급 시험에 응시했다. 7천823명이 응시한 중국은 전 세계적으로 응시자 수가 두 번째로 많은 나라가 됐고(첫 번째는 1만317명이 응시한 미국), 4천179명이 응시한 인도가 세 번째가 됐다. 그 외에 시험에 응시한 APAC 국가로는 홍콩(1천992명), 싱가포르(1천529명), 호주(1천459명) 및 한국(1천391명) 등이 있다. APAC는 총 응시자 중 거의 절반(47%)을 차지했는데, 이는 이 지역에서 CFA 자격의 관련성과 중요도를 반증하는 것이다. 이 결과가 나올 무렵, CFA Institute의 2014 국제시장분위기조사(Global Market Sentiment Survey, GMSS[http://www.cfainstitute.org/gmss ])에 따르면, 전 세계 투자 전문가들은 올 한 해 경제 전망에 대해 더욱 낙관적이었지만, 자본시장 건전성이 개선될 것이라고 확신하지는 못했다고 한다. CFA 프로그램 시험에 응시한 투자 전문가들이 보여준 집념은 더욱 믿을 수 있는 업계를 만들고, 윤리 실천이 투자 실적만큼 중요한 문화를 구축하고자 하는 강력한 열망을 반증하는 것이다. CFA Institute APAC 상무이사 Paul Smith, CFA는 “금융계는 투자자 신뢰 위기에 직면해 있으며, 모든 수준에서 업계 교육은 투자자 신뢰를 재구축하는데 있어 중요한 부분을 담당한다”면서 “APAC에서 차세대 투자 전문가들은 금융 미래를 만드는데 일조할 것이다. 시험에 통과한 투자 전문가 개개인은 투자자를 우선시하고, 사회에 더 나은 서비스를 제공하는 업계 문화를 구축할 수 있는 기회를 잡았다”고 말했다. CFA 자격증을 획득하려면 3단계에 걸친 시험을 통과해야 한다(모든 시험에 통과한 이들에 따르면, 각 단계당 300시간 이상을 공부해야 한다고 한다). 그뿐만 아니라 투자업계에서 4년 이상의 경력이 있어야 하고, CFA Institute의 윤리 강령과 전문가 행동 기준을 준수하기로 약속해야 한다. 또한 CFA Institute 학회 신청을 하고, CFA Institute 회원으로 가입해야 한다. CFA 프로그램 교육과정은 투자직에서 매일 요구되는 지식과 기술에 그 단단한 뿌리를 두고 있으며, 윤리적이고 전문적인 기준, 증권 분석과 평가, 국제적인 재무재표 분석, 양적 방법, 경제학, 기업 금융, 포트폴리오 관리 및 실적 측정 등을 다룬다. 1급 시험은 6월과 12월에 있으며, 2급과 3급 시험은 6월에만 있다. 대부분은 CFA 프로그램을 마치는데 3년 이상 소요되며, 그 과정에서 집념과 투지를 보여야 한다(현재까지의 합격률[http://www.cfainstitute.org/programs/cfaprogram/Documents/1963_current_candidate_exam_results.pdf ])2013년 12월, 전 세계 39개국 70개 도시 93개 테스트 센터에서 1급 시험이 시행됐다.CFA협회 소개CFA협회는 국제적인 투자전문가 단체로서, 전문적인 우수성과 자격에 관한 기준을 설정한다. CFA협회는 투자시장에서 윤리적 행동을 옹호하고, 국제 금융계에서 지식원으로 존중받는다. CFA협회의 최종 목표는 투자자들의 이익을 최우선으로 하고, 시장이 최상의 수준으로 기능하며, 경제가 성장하는 환경을 구축하는 것이다. CFA협회는 147개 국가와 지역에서 11만9천 명이 넘는 회원을 보유하고 있다. 그 중 CFA 자격증 소지자는 12만 명이고, 회원 학회는 140개에 달한다. 추가 정보는 웹사이트 http://www.cfainstitute.org/를 참조한다.출처: CFA InstituteNearly 19,500 Investment Professionals Worldwide Pass Level I CFA Exam APAC Candidate Numbers Reflect High Relevance to Region -- Candidates committed to raising standards and restoring trust in the industryHONG KONG, Feb. 11, 2014 /PRNewswire/ -- CFA Institute, the global association of investment professionals that sets the standard for professional excellence and credentials, reports that 43 percent of the 45,693 candidates that took the Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA) Level I exam in December 2013 have passed and taken the first step to joining the next generation of highly educated and ethical investment professionals. In June and December of 2013, a total number of 93,195 candidates sat for Level I of the CFA Program, a globally recognized, graduate level curriculum that links theory and practice with real-world investment analysis, and emphasizes the highest ethical and professional standards.(Logo: http://www.prnasia.com/sa/2013/12/16/20131216173537320331.jpg )In APAC, a total of 21,388 candidates took the CFA Level 1 exam in December 2013. mainland China fielded the second largest group to sit the exam globally, with 7,823 candidates tested (following the US with 10,317 candidates), while India was third with 4,179 candidates. Other APAC territories represented included Hong Kong (1,992), Singapore (1,529), Australia (1,459) and Korea (1,391). Overall, APAC comprised almost half (47 percent) of the total number examined, demonstrating the relevance and importance of the CFA designation in the region. The results come at a time when investment professionals worldwide report greater optimism over economic prospects for the coming year, but do not express confidence that the integrity of capital markets is improving, according to the CFA Institute 2014 Global Market Sentiment Survey (GMSS [http://www.cfainstitute.org/gmss ]). The dedication shown by investment professionals taking the CFA Program demonstrates a strong desire to build a more trustworthy industry and develop a culture where ethical practice is just as important as investment performance. "The financial community is dealing with a crisis of investor trust, and industry education at all levels is a critical part of rebuilding that trust," said Paul Smith, CFA, Managing Director, APAC, CFA Institute. "The next generation of investment professionals in APAC will help shape the future of finance, and each one of these successful candidates has the opportunity to build the kind of industry culture that puts investors first and better serves society." To earn the CFA designation, candidates must pass all three levels of exam (successful candidates often report dedicating in excess of 300 hours of study per level); meet the work experience requirements of four years in the investment industry; sign a commitment to abide by the CFA Institute Code of Ethics and Standards of Professional Conduct; apply to a CFA Institute society; and become a member of CFA Institute. The CFA Program curriculum is firmly grounded in the knowledge and skills required every day in the investment profession and covers ethical and professional standards, securities analysis and valuation, international financial statement analysis, quantitative methods, economics, corporate finance, portfolio management, and performance measurement. Level I exams are offered in both June and December and Levels II and III are offered only in June. It takes most candidates more than three years to complete the CFA Program, and requires dedication and determination. (View historic pass rates [http://www.cfainstitute.org/programs/cfaprogram/Documents/1963_current_candidate_exam_results.pdf ])The December 2013 Level I exam was administered in 93 test centers in 70 cities across 39 countries worldwide. About CFA InstituteCFA Institute is the global association of investment professionals that sets the standard for professional excellence and credentials. The organization is a champion for ethical behavior in investment markets and a respected source of knowledge in the global financial community. The end goal: to create an environment where investors' interests come first, markets function at their best, and economies grow. CFA Institute has more than 119,000 members in 147 countries and territories, including 112,000 CFA charterholders, and 140 member societies. For more information, visit http://www.cfainstitute.org/.SOURCE: CFA Institute▶연합뉴스앱  ▶궁금한배틀Y<저작권자(c)연합뉴스 무단전재-재배포금지>

title: Excise tax cuts fail to stir expectations
content: Reductions seen too limited to create mood for sustained consumer spending  New tax cuts designed to stimulate stagnant domestic consumption are not likely to trigger dramatic improvement because of household debt and sentiment and the scope of the reductions, analysts say.A spurt may be seen in the near term, but consumers are more likely to lapse back into tight spending, they add."The policy will not bring a sudden shopping boom," says Woori Securities` Yoo Jae-woo, explaining that the breadth of the tax cut was not much more attractive than discounts available offered through various retail channels, such as online shops.The tax cuts themselves are only a short-term stimulus, like a jolt of strong coffee. They expire in December.Also, the reductions apply to big-ticket items, such as cars, at a time when households are struggling to pay down debt and meet ordinary needs.About 4 million consumers are weighed down by debt from the end of the government-engineered credit card bubble that burst last year. And full-time employment remains weak, especially among young adults, who often are at the cusp of spending booms.The result is public sentiment is still flagging. Last week, the government reported that its consumer confidence index fell for the second straight month in March.It was sobering news to officials who have said since January that domestic spending would rebound in the second half of the year, teaming up with already strong exports to provide 5 to 6 percent growth, compared to 3.1 percent last year.Na Seung-lin, an economic professor at Hanyang University, said the government should focus more on easing corporate regulations and anti-corporate sentiment to stimulate the weak economy."Short-term and temporary stimulus measures such as tax cuts can only have limited impact on the market," he said.Oh Suk-tae, an economist at Citibank Inc., agrees, saying the tax reductions may spark a short-term boost but a "turnaround." While the stimulus represent the government`s firm determination to help the economy, they also seem to be politically motivated ahead of parliamentary elections, he said.Officials defend their action, saying government action was warranted."We could not wait any longer and did what we have to do regardless of the general elections," said Lee Jong-kyu, chief of the ministry`s Tax and Customs Office On March 23, the Finance Ministry announced reduced special excise taxes on cars, air conditioners and projection televisions, until the end of the year.The surprise move did not affect energy costs. The government plans to make adjustments to those rates in July.The special excise taxes, introduced in 1977, are designed to levy more taxes on luxury items and services.The government lowered the luxury taxes for the first time in 2001, which was a big success, boosting domestic demand by 11 percent.But tax cuts on cars in July 2003 stimulated automobile purchases only for two months.This time, the special taxes on cars and electronic goods are lowered 20 percent and 30 percent, respectively.The changes will lower the special sales tax on cars with an engine capacity of more than 2 liters from 10 percent to 8 percent. The tax on smaller engine displacement cars will drop from 5 percent to 4 percent.Under the changes, a Hyundai Avante sedan costing 13.9 million won ($10,199) will see 170,000 won shed from its price tag, while a midsize Sonata can be bought for 270,000 won less.Luxury cars like the Grandeur with a 3-litre engine will cost about 700,000 won less, while a BMW 530 priced at 88.5 million won will sell for 8.64 million won less.An analysis by Lehman Brothers said the tax cut should help the auto industry but not significantly."Overall, this is positive news for the auto sector, but realistically, we do not expect the impact to be material, as the net reduction on vehicle retail prices is expected to be only around 1.2 percent to 2.3 percent," says the analysis says The major beneficiary should be Hyundai Motor Corp., because it has the highest share of vehicles with engine capacities greathern than 2,000cc, says the analysis."We are certain that it (the tax cut) will lead to growth for our sales," said Lee Sang-jin, an official at Hyundai Motor Co., Korea`s top-selling automaker. "But given the very low consumer sentiment, we cannot tell how much sales will grow.The luxury tax on air conditioners will drop from 16 percent to 11.2 percent, while the tax on projection televisions tumbles from 8 percent to 5.6 percent. The tax on leisure goods will also be brought down from 20 percent to 14 percent.Air conditioners are also expected to cost 5.2 percent less, while prices for golf-related merchandise will drop 8.8 percent. High-end watches and perfumes will also see prices reduced by 4.6 percent and 2.7 percent, respectively.Korean retailers welcomed the tax cuts but were skeptical about any dramatic improvement in sales."We`ll wait and see how the situation develops, although we expect the tax cut to have some positive impact on our sales," said Kim Hyun-min, a company representative at Samsung Electronics Co., Korea`s largest electronics maker.Among consumer electronics, air conditioners are expected to see a noticeable gain. Under the government measure, an air conditioner with a price tag of 2 million won would see a reduction of between 120,000 won and 130,000 won."The lower excise tax is likely to spur our air conditioner sales as our summer marketing begins in April and goes through June," said Oh Sea-chun of LG Electronics, the nation`s top consumer appliances maker. "Air conditioners are expected to get the biggest boon from the tax cut." The tax cuts will mean 280 billion won less for the state coffers but the ministry claimed this could be made up if demand increases.(saintsim@heraldm.com)      By Sim Sung-tae

title: Funds not available for Pres. Park’s populist election pledges
content: [한겨레] Study shows that in her campaign, Park promised projects already determined to be financially infeasible By Kwon Eun-jung, staff reporterPre-feasibility studies have been carried for 10 of the 27 regional public construction projects that President Park Geun-hye pledged during her campaign. Of the 10, nine were determined to not financially feasible, reports say. Therefore major adjustments will inevitably have to be made to the pledges that Park’s government made to various regions in Korea. It looks as if the time has come for Park to pay the price for indiscriminately promising to carry out projects long requested by various regions in an effort to win their votes.The results of the pre-feasibility studies were available for view on the website of the Korea Development Institute (KDI) on July 15. In nine of the ten studies that have been done through the beginning of this year for regional public construction pledged by Park, the benefit-cost ratio (BCR) failed to exceed the baseline of 1.0. There are 167 projects that are connected with Park’s 106 local campaign pledges (106), and 27 of these are new public construction projects.The pre-feasibility studies for the regional pledges viewed on July 15 indicate that several of the projects that were rated as having a low benefit-cost ratio were pledged during Park’s campaign despite already having been determined to not be economically feasible on several occasions. One of the most vivid examples of such a project is the plan for the Central Inland Railroad Line that would link Icheon in Gyeonggi Province, Chungju in North Chungcheong Province, and Mungyeong County in North Gyeongsang Province. The project had initially been planned as a single-line railroad in 2005 after passing a pre-feasibility study in 2002, but public sentiment in the area began to shift toward favoring a dual-track railroad.After this, in 2011 with work already underway on the Icheon-Chungju section the government ran another pre-feasibility study, this time on the scenario of a dual-track railroad. In the second study, the financial analysis of the dual-track project was 0.29 and the overall assessment score (using the analytic hierarchy process) was 0.401. In order for a project to be determined feasible, the overall assessment score must be higher than 0.5. While the dual-track project essentially received failing marks both in terms of its economic feasibility and in the overall assessment, Park promised to move forward with it during the election campaign.The project to build Hanryeo Bridge to connect Yeosu in South Jeolla Province and Namhae County in South Gyeongsang Province, which received the lowest score in the pre-feasibility study, was another project for which a pre-feasibility study had already been conducted. While the project had been deemed infeasible in the pre-feasibility study conducted in 2002, yet another pre-feasibility study was run in 2006 before the opening of the Yeosu World Expo.This study included the possibility of building an underwater tunnel and considered two scenarios, which received the lowest pre-feasibility grades, at 0.045 and 0.108. Nevertheless, this project was also added to the list of Park‘s regional pledges.The analysis of economic feasibility, which is the chief index in a pre-feasibility study, compares the cost that must be invested in the present with the benefit that could be enjoyed in the future. The average score for the 10 pre-feasibility studies that have already been conducted for local projects is only 0.66. Massive public construction projects that didn’t even reach 1.0 on the cost-benefit ratio were indiscriminately selected as pledges during Park’s presidential campaign and, many were chosen as regional projects during the new administration.“The fact that Park selected projects that had not even made it past the pre-feasibility study as her pledges means that she made a lot of indiscriminate pork-barrel campaign pledges,” said Oh Geon-ho, a researcher at the Public Policy Institute for People and a finance expert. “I hope that she will not make the mistake of promoting these projects based on analysis of their political importance rather than their economic feasibility.”For projects with a low level of feasibility, the government is planning to make new plans through deliberation and coordination with local governments before beginning work on them. As a result, the government will have no choice but to alter or reduce the regional pledges it made during the campaign. However, that process is not expected to be simple. Most significantly, it is sure to create controversy among the residents of the regions that are affected. South Jeolla Province, North Chungcheong Province, and Gangwon Province, which all received low scores on the pre-feasibility studies, are regions whose residents strongly feel that they have been victimized by being left out of past investment in social infrastructure. The local governments in these regions are prepared to protest fiercely, insisting that policy-based decisions for promoting balanced regional development should be given the priority over concerns about economic feasibilityAlso notable is the fact that the local elections are going to be held in 2014. It is very likely that political parties, which have no choice but to pay attention to regional sentiment, will interfere with any government attempts to adjust its plans. In fact, when Choi Kyung-hwan, floor leader for the Saenuri Party (NFP), met with reporters from local papers on July 11, he said, “If it is difficult to work on the major pledges made to regions because of the pre-feasibility studies, I think it may even be necessary to change the way the pre-feasibility study system works.” The possibility is even being raised that politicians could tinker with the overall pre-feasibility study system.However, experts are calling for cool-headed thinking. “Pre-feasibility studies are the last defense against excessive, politically motivated government spending,” said You Jong-il, a professor at the KDI School of Public Policy and Management.“The Korean economy is currently facing structural difficulties, including a loss of tax revenue. These local pledges, which the government is trying to implement even if it means altering the pre-feasibility study system, could turn into a disaster as serious as the Four Major Rivers Project,” You said.“Considering that there is a high likelihood that decisions today will be connected with financial burden for governments in the future, rational decisions should be made,” said Song Yu-na, a researcher at the Public Policy Institute for People.Choe Hee-gap, a professor of economics at Ajou University, offered a different take on the local pledges. “The government must change the framework of regional projects to support the high value-added service industry, including welfare, education, and medical services specialized for the region. The Ministry of Strategy and Finance must offer guidelines to achieve this,” Choi said. “At the moment, we are seeing the same competition for a limited budget. This is the same old squabbling over which region is going to get a new road.”　Please direct questions or comments to [english@hani.co.kr]　   공식 SNS [통하니] [트위터] [미투데이] | 구독신청 [한겨레신문] [한겨레21]Copyrights ⓒ 한겨레신문사, 무단전재 및 재배포 금지<한겨레는 한국온라인신문협회(www.kona.or.kr)의 디지털뉴스이용규칙에 따른 저작권을 행사합니다.>

title: 래리 다이아몬드 "지속가능 민주주의 위해 소득과 부의 불공정과 불평등에 대...
content: [경향신문] 세계는 2021년 코로나19 팬데믹 속에 민주주의 후퇴와 포퓰리즘·권위주의 세력의 득세를 경험했다. 미국이 주도한 민주주의정상회의를 계기로 민주주의 논쟁은 초강대국 간 체제 경쟁의 전면으로 등장했다. 민주주의 이론의 세계적 석학 래리 다이아몬드 스탠퍼드대 교수는 3일 경향신문과의 인터뷰에서 2022년 새해에도 민주주의 쇠퇴 경향은 계속될 것이며 2024년 미국 대선에서 미국 민주주의가 거의 붕괴될지 모른다고 우려했다. 그는 민주주의 퇴보의 원인으로 지정학적 힘의 균형 변화, 세계화의 불균등한 충격, 이민 증가 등의 외부적 요인과 각국 내부의 경제적 불평등, 불공정의 증가에서 찾았다. 그러면서 지속가능한 민주주의를 위해서는 불공정과 불평등에 대처하는 것이 중요하다고 강조했다. 다이아몬드 교수는 한국 민주주의의 혁신을 위해서는 시민사회가 이데올로기적, 당파적 균열에 다리를 놓기 위해 결집해야 한다고 조언했다. 래리 다이아몬드 스탠퍼드대 교수 /스탠퍼드대 홈페이지“권위주의 국가들은 국제무대에서 더 공격적이고 확신에 차 있다”-현재 세계 민주주의는 어떤 추세인가.   “민주주의의 광범위한 쇠퇴 경향이 계속되고 있다. 민주주의에서 멀어지는 나라들이 민주주의에 가까워지는 나라보다 더 많다. 일부 자유민주주의 국가들은 덜 자유주의적인 상태가 됐다. 많은 선거민주주의 국가들이 고장이 나거나 인도와 브라질처럼 비자유주의적 포퓰리스트 지도자와 정당으로부터 심각한 압력을 받고 있다. 중국, 러시아로 대표되는 권위주의 체제들은 국제 무대에서 더 강력하고 공격적이며 확신에 차 있다. 전 세계 국가 중 절반 정도가 체제의 형식 면에서 민주적이라는 평가를 받지만 권위주의 체제와 가치들이 더 큰 탄력을 받고 있다.”-민주주의 쇠퇴가 시민의 삶에 미치는 영향은. “고품질 또는 자유민주주의는 시민들에게 본질적인 혜택을 제공한다. 민주주의는 다른 어떤 종류의 정치 체제보다 인권을 잘 보호하고 사법에 대한 공평한 접근을 보장한다. 그리고 민주주의는 시민들의 이익을 더 잘 대표하고 시민들의 요구에 반응하며, 정책적 실수를 바로잡는다. 또한 그간 축적된 사회과학적 연구를 통해 고품질의 민주주의가 부패 통제, 환경 보전, 불평등 억제, 시민에 대한 복지 제공 등에서 더 유능하다는 점도 증명됐다. 민주주의의 악화는 통상적으로 깊은 사회적 갈등, 정치적 양극화 그리고 다른 국가 기능 고장의 징후이다.”-지난해 국제사회는 민주주의 쇠퇴에 대해 무기력했다.  “유감스럽게도 전 세계에서 미국 그리고 자유민주주의 국가들의 집단적 힘은 약해진 반면 독재 국가들, 주요하게는 중국과 러시아의 힘과 협력이 증가하고 있다. 이로 인해 민주주의가 확립된 국가들이 민주주의 역행을 사전에 억제하거나 되돌리기 위해 쏟을 수 있는 레버리지가 감소했다. 민주주의가 후퇴한 사례마다 각자의 사연이 있다. 홍콩은 중국의 일부이기 때문에 베이징이 일국양제(한 국가 두 체제)에 대한 약속을 지키지 않아도 전 세계 자유민주주의 국가들이 이를 막기 위해 할 수 있는 게 거의 없다. 티벳과 신장에서 목격해 온 슬프지만 고통스런 진실이다. 중국은 크고 아주 강력한 나라가 됐으며 중국이 내부적으로 어떻게 통치하는지에 관해 서구가 영향을 미칠 수 있는 레버리지는 거의 없다. 하지만 대만은 사정이 다르다. 전 세계 민주주의 국가들이 대만 민주주의의 성공을 인정·지지하고 베이징의 권위주의 체제가 일방적인 해법을 부과하지 못하도록 돕는 것이 아주 중요하다. 미얀마의 경우 집단적으로 부패하고 억압적인 군부 정권에 대해 가혹한 제재를 부과해야 한다. 동시에 군부가 일종의 다원적이고 헌법적인 체제로 복귀하도록 유인을 제공하기 위해 외교적으로 관여해야 한다. 그렇지만 우리의 집단적인 레버리지는 역시 제한적이다. 유럽에서 가장 심각한 민주주의 후퇴 사례는 헝가리와 폴란드다. 헝가리는 더 이상 민주주의가 아니다. 두 정권이 사법부 독립, 법의 지배, 개인의 자유 및 민주적 절차에 대한 존중 등에 관한 유럽연합(EU)의 기준을 준수할 때까지 EU의 순금융자산 지원을 중단해야 한다.”“정부의 비상 권력은 팬데믹이 끝나면 종료돼야”-코로나19 팬데믹이 민주주의에 미친 영향은. “팬데믹 시기 정부 권력의 확대는 불가피하다. 건강한 자유민주주의 국가에서 시민들은 상당한 개인적 자유를 누리지만 동료 시민 그리고 전체 사회의 건강을 위험에 빠트릴 자유는 주어지지 않는다. 따라서 정부가 백신 접종과 마스크 착용을 의무화하고 이를 따르지 않는 시민들을 처벌하는 것은 민주주의와 부합한다고 생각한다. 유럽 특히 미국에서는 정부가 부과한 이런 의무가 분열의 원천이 됐다. 이는 정부에 대한 신뢰를 감소시키고 정치적 불만과 양극화를 고조시켰다. 정부가 팬데믹 기간에 권력을 강화하면서 생기는 다른 위험은 공중 보건 위기가 끝났는데도 정부가 이를 내놓지 않으려 한다는 것이다. 시민들의 휴대폰에 설치한 동선 추적 애플리케이션이나 다른 형태의 모니터링 및 규제들이 이에 해당한다. 건강 및 접촉자 추적 정보 등 정부가 팬데믹 기간에 획득한 어떤 종류의 비상 권력도 위기가 끝나면 종료되어야 한다. 디지털 시대를 맞아 자유를 지키기 위해 항상 깨어 있는 것이 중요하다.”“2024년 미국 민주주의는 거의 붕괴될 수도”-미국 민주주의는 어떤 상태인가.“미국 민주주의는 심각한 위기이자 시험의 시기를 지나고 있다. 정치 체제가 극도로 양극화됐다. 미국의 주요 양대 정당 가운데 하나가 대통령 임기 말 민주적 절차를 거의 파괴한 권위주의적 인물에게 점령됐다. 불행히도 도널드 트럼프는 대통령직에 다시 도전할 가능성이 매우 높고 현재 공화당 내에서 압도적인 지지를 받고 있다. 설상가상 공화당은 미국의 많은 주에서 투표권을 제약할 뿐더러 공화당이 지배하는 주 의회와 당파적 인물들이 선거 집행과 인증에 부당한 영향을 미칠 수 있도록 하는 법들을 열심히 제정하고 있다. 나는 미국이 2024년 대선에서 2020년보다 더 심각한 위기에 직면하고, 미국 민주주의가 거의 붕괴될지 모른다는 우려를 갖고 있다. 미국에서 관용과 용서라는 민주적 규범이 감소하고 있다는 점도 매우 우려스럽다. 체제 보전을 하려면 폭력이 필요하다는 신념이 사람들 사이에서 증가하고 있다. 민주적 규범의 쇠퇴는 광범위하게 퍼져 있는 총기 때문에 더욱 증폭되고 있다. 물론 나는 여전히 미국 사회가 민주주의에 도전하는 문제들에 대처하기 위해 결집하고 민주적 절차를 보전할 수 있을 것이라고 낙관한다. 그렇지만 더 이상 어떤 것도 당연하게 여길 수 없다는 것도 사실이다.”-미국 민주주의 쇠퇴를 보여주는 ‘트럼피즘’의 본질은.“트럼프에게 정책은 아무런 중요성도 없었으므로 트럼피즘의 본질은 정책이 아니다. 사실 트럼프는 정책에 아무런 관심도 없다. 그렇기 때문에 그가 속한 공화당은 2020년 대선을 앞두고 정강을 만들지도 채택하지도 않았다. 미국의 주요 양대 정당 중 하나가 대선을 앞두고 시민들에게 정강을 제시하지 않은 보도 듣도 못한 사태가 발생한 것이다. 따라서 트럼피즘의 본질은 체제, 딥스테이트(정부를 움직이는 제도 밖의 엘리트 권력집단) 그리고 법원과 언론, 직업 관료제를 포함하는 기성 제도에 대한 반감이라고 할 수 있다. 극도의 반민주적 포퓰리즘이 채택해온 고전적 공식이다. 이것은 분노와 반감의 운동으로서 양극화 상황에서 자라나는데 트럼피즘의 경우 인종적 분열과 정체성 분열 위에서 번창했다. 트럼피즘의 본질은 정책이 아니라 정체성과 반감에 기반한 동원에 더 깊이 관련돼 있다.”“세계 자유민주주의 국가들은 단합해야”-미국 민주주의 쇠퇴의 세계적 함의는.“우리는 세계 1차 대전과 2차 대전 사이의 기간에 미국이 고립주의로 후퇴하고 세계적 관여와 책임을 멀리했을 때 초래된 위험한 결과를 목격했다. 미국 자유민주주의 사례는 모든 결함에도 불구하고, 어쩌면 그 결함들에 대처하려는 시민 사회의 비범한 운동 때문에, 전 세계의 많은 사람들에게 영감을 제공했다. 미국 민주주의가 계속 쇠퇴한다면 분명히 전 세계 민주주의에 아주 부정적인 영향을 미칠 것이다. 그렇지만 우리는 전보다 다극화된 세계에 살고 있다. EU는 매우 중요한 행위자로 남아 있고 세계적으로 한국, 일본 등 자원과 영향력을 보유한 중요한 민주주의 국가들이 존재한다. 세계 자유민주주의 국가들은 민주적 가치들을 지키고 증진하기 위해 더 많은 일들을 적극적으로 해야 한다. 단합해야만 이 목표를 효율적으로 추진할 수 있다.”-조 바이든은 미국 민주주의를 회복시킬까.  “바이든 대통령은 미국 민주주의를 강화하고 활기를 다시 불어 넣기 위해 노력 중이라고 본다. 그러나 일부 노력은 입법 조치가 뒷받침돼야 한다. 또한 지난 1월 6일 의회를 습격함으로써 미국의 선거 민주주의를 공격한 이들을 처벌하는 강력한 사법적 조치가 필요하다고 생각한다.”-미국이 주도한 민주주의 정상회의의 의미는. “많은 곳에서 민주적 규범과 제도들이 공격받는다면 오늘날 우리가 이미 그렇게 하고 있는 것처럼 조직화되고 세계적인 대응이 필요하다. 민주주의 정상회의는 이런 대응의 일부였다. 앞으로 각 정부는 민주적 원칙들을 방어하기 위한 연대뿐 아니라 그들의 영토 안에서 민주주의를 심화시키고 개혁하기 위한 구체적인 조치를 취하겠다는 약속을 이행해야 한다.”“신냉전으로 가고 있다면 누구 책임인지 맑은 눈으로 보라”-민주주의를 중국 압박 도구로 만들었다는 비판도 있다. “전 세계 민주주의 국가들이 민주적 원칙들을 지키려고 행동하고 이 중요한 목적을 위해 모일 때 중국과 러시아 그리고 다른 권위주의적 정권들은 이를 적대적이고 공격적이며 신냉전을 추구한다고 맹렬히 비난한다. 민주주의 정상회의에 참석한 어떤 나라도 신냉전 또는 중국·러시아와의 갈등 원하지 않는다. 하지만 러시아는 우크라이나와 다른 이웃 국가들을 군사적으로 위협했고, 유럽의 가장자리에서 전쟁 같은 상황을 초래했다. 중국은 남중국해 전체의 영유권을 주장하고, 그 지역의 자원을 군사화하고 독점하기 위해 가차없이 움직임으로써 인도·태평양 지역의 불안정을 초래하고 있다. 또한 중국은 대만을 위협하는 공격적인 언사를 쏟아내고 군사력을 호전적으로 과시하고 있다. 만약 신냉전으로 흘러가고 있다면 누가 책임을 져야 하는지 맑은 눈으로 봐야 한다.”“민주주의와 부의 집중, 둘다 가질 수는 없다.”-민주주의 쇠퇴는 내재적 문제인가, 환경과 운영의 문제인가.“현재 민주주의가 겪고 있는 침식과 퇴보의 시기에 대한 책임 자체는 민주주의 이념이나 이데올로기에 있다고 보지 않는다. 지정학적 힘의 균형의 변화, 세계화가 각국 내부에 미친 경제적 불안정 효과, 이민 증가 압력이 유럽과 미국에 미친 영향 그리고 각 민주주의 국가 내부의 문제들 특히 경제적 불평등과 불공정의 가파른 증가 등에 원인을 돌려야 한다. 민주주의가 지속가능하려면 우리는 소득과 부의 분배에서 극명하게 나타나고 있는 불공정과 불평등 수준의 증가에 대처해야 한다. 미국의 유명한 대법관 루이스 브랜다이스 ‘우리는 이 나라에서 민주주의를 갖거나 막대한 부가 몇 사람의 손에 집중되도록 할 수 있지만 둘 다 가질 수는 없다’고 말했다. 한 세기가 지났지만 그의 경고는 여전히 유효하다.”-민주주의 퇴조와 포퓰리즘의 관계는. “포퓰리즘은 양극화의 산물인 동시에 양극화를 생성하고 증폭시킨다. 포퓰리스트 지도자들은 설 자리를 잃었다고 느끼는 분노한 시민들과 엘리트 및 소수자들 사이에 패인 깊은 분열을 이용해 권력을 잡고 유지한다. 설 자리를 잃었다고 느끼는 시민들은 그들에게 주어진 정당한 몫이라고 생각하는 권력과 자원들을 엘리트와 소수자들이 도둑질했다고 느낀다. 포퓰리즘은 냉소적이고, 교묘하며, 패권적이다. 포퓰리즘은 ‘인민’이 확립된 규칙과 제도로부터 등을 돌리게 하고, 포퓰리스트 지도자와 정당에게 맹목적 신념을 갖도록 호소하며, 주요 인종 집단이 취약한 소수자와 이민자들에게 등을 돌리게 함으로써 민주주의에 중대한 위협을 가한다.”-민주주의 쇠퇴를 되돌리기 위한 근본적인 해법은.“단일한 해법이 있다고 말할 순 없지만 지표가 되는 몇가지 중요한 원칙들이 있다. 먼저, 우리는 단기적인 당파적 이익이나 이데올로기적 목표가 아닌 민주적 원칙과 규범들에 충실해야 한다. 민주주의를 실천하지 않고 민주적 규범 및 규칙을 준수하지 않으면서 민주주의의 쇠퇴를 되돌릴 순 없다. 둘째, 각국은 경제적 불평등과 불안정 증대 문제에 대처할 방법을 찾아야 한다. 민주주의는 모두가 존엄성을 지키면서 살 수 있고, 스스로를 계발하고 발전시킬 기회를 가지는 공동의 기획이다. 셋째, 민주주의 국가들은 기후변화처럼 그들이 직면한 정책적 도전 과제 그리고 고령화, 물리적 인프라 노후화, 이민, 정체성 분열 같은 여러 다양한 도전들에 대해 효율적인 대응책을 마련하는 정치적 의지와 능력을 보여줘야 한다. 전 세계 민주주의 국가들이 직면한 다양한 도전들은 공통적이므로 조율된 대응을 할 필요도 있다.”“한국 시민사회가 이데올로기·당파적 분열에 다리 놓아야”-한국 민주주의의 과거와 현재를 어떻게 평가하는가.“한국은 정치적 양극화와 기성 정치에 대한 환멸의 시기를 지나고 있는 여러 국가들 중 하나이다. 그럼에도 한국은 ‘제3의 민주화 물결’의 가장 성공적인 사례로서 30년 이상 건강한 민주주의를 유지해 왔다. 주요 대선 후보를 포함한 정치 지도자들은 행동을 절제하고 상호 관용이라는 민주적 규범을 보여주기 위해 노력해야 한다.”-한국에서도 정치적 양극화에 대한 우려가 크다. “한국 민주주의 관찰자와 연구자들 사이에선 사법 시스템의 정치화, 부패의 지속, 어떤 대가를 치르더라도 승리와 우위를 추구하는 정치적 태도에 대한 우려가 증가해 왔다. 미국과 마찬가지로 한국은 시민사회가 정당의 노선과 정당 체제를 뛰어넘어 결집해야 하는 순간이라고 본다. 시민사회가 기본적인 민주적 가치들에 대한 신념을 쇄신하고 민주주의와 ‘좋은 거버넌스’를 약화시키는 정치적 행위들을 개혁해야 한다. 미국과 한국 모두 선거자금이 심각한 문제를 안고 있는 것으로 보이며 우선적으로 개혁해야 한다. 최근 몇 년 동안 미국 민주주의에서 심화된 문제들은 시민사회 조직과 연합 등이 더 긴밀한 네트워크를 형성하도록 하는 동기를 부여했다. 이 네트워크는 전통적인 이데올로기적, 당파적 분열에 다리를 놓고 민주주의를 방어하고 개혁하는 것을 주요 목표로 한다. 만약 한국에 그런 네트워크가 존재하지 않는다면 그것을 형성하기 위해 많은 대가를 치러야 할 것이다. 정치적 정체 상태에 대한 불만은 두 가지 방향으로 흐를 수 있다. 첫번째는 소외와 냉소, 퇴장이 증가하는 것이며 두번째는 개혁을 위한 결집이다. 첫번째 경향은 민주주의의 쇠퇴, 궁극적으로는 붕괴로 흐른다. 두번째는 쇄신으로 이어진다. 한국과 미국이 모두 두번째 경로를 선택하기를 희망한다.”■래리 다이아몬드는 미국 스탠퍼드대 교수이자 후버연구소 선임연구원으로 재직 중인 정치학자이자 사회학자이다. 미국 비영리 기구인 ‘미국민주주의재단’이 펴내는 ‘민주주의저널’의 공동 편집자다. 그는 민주주의 이론 연구에 헌신하는 동시에 미국 국무부, 유엔, 세계은행, 미국 국제개발처 등 다양한 정부 기구 및 국제 기구에 자문을 제공함으로써 전 세계 민주주의 확산을 위한 노력도 기울여 왔다. 그는 각종 실증적 자료 분석을 통해 2006년부터 전 세계에서 민주주의가 퇴조하는 경향을 보이기 시작했다고 지적해 왔다. 다이아몬드 교수는 한국을 수차례 방문했고, 김병국 전 고려대 교수와 함께 <한국 민주주의 공고화>라는 책을 편집하는 등 한국 민주주의에 대한 식견도 넓다. 다이아몬드 교수와의 인터뷰는 지난해 말 e메일로 진행됐다. 이하 영어 인터뷰 전문◆ Trends of global democracy- In your 2014 paper “Facing up to the democratic recession”, you demonstrated the decline of global democracy through empirical analysis. What is your assessment of the current state of global democracy?“There continues to be a broad trend of democratic decline around the world. Many more countries are moving away from democracy then toward it. Some liberal democracies are becoming less liberal. Many electoral democracies have broken down or, like India and Brazil, are under serious pressure from illiberal populist leaders and ruling parties. Authoritarian regimes, led by China and Russia, are becoming more powerful, aggressive, and assertive on the international stage. While about half of the countries of the world remain democratic in their regime form, authoritarian regimes and values now have greater momentum.”- How does the decline of democracy affect the lives of citizens and the fate of the nation?“A high-quality, or “liberal” democracy offers intrinsic benefits to citizens. It does a better job of protecting human rights and ensuring fair access to justice than any other kind of political system. It does a much better job of representing and responding to the interests of citizens, and of correcting policy mistakes. We also know from a growing accumulation of social science research that high-quality democracy does a better job of controlling corruption, protecting the environment, reducing inequality, and providing for the welfare of citizens. To the extent that democracy is stable and healthy, the society is likely to be as well. When democracy deteriorates, it is usually a sign of deep social conflict, political polarization, and other dysfunctions in the nation. Generally speaking, the societies that do the best job of providing for the general welfare of citizens and ensuring a healthy social order also have stable and deep democracies.”- In 2021, Western democracies including the United States strongly criticized when authoritarianism was emboldened and democracy was suppressed in Hong Kong, Myanmar etc, but it seems that did not bring much change. What was the problem?“Unfortunately, the global power of the United States, and also of the liberal democracies collectively, has been diminishing while the power and coordination of the world’s autocracies, principally China and Russia, has been growing. This has reduced the leverage that the established democracies can bring to bear to try to prevent, contain, or reverse the rollback of democracy.Every case of democratic regression has its own story. Hong Kong was already part of China, and if Beijing was not going to respect any longer its commitment to “one country two systems,” there was very little that the world’s liberal democracies could do to prevent it. This is a sad but painful truth, which we have seen played out in Tibet, Xinjiang, and of course China as a whole. China is a big and now very powerful country, and the West has rather little leverage to affect how it governs its own people internally. However, although the dispute over its status remains unresolved, Taiwan, is a vibrant and highly successful liberal democracy, which is not functionally under Beijing’s control. It is vitally important that the democracies of the world acknowledge and support the success of Taiwan’s democracy and help to ensure that a deeply authoritarian regime in Beijing cannot unilaterally impose a solution on it.In the case of Myanmar, what the military suppressed was not a democracy but rather what we would call a competitive authoritarian regime, or if you will, a semi-democracy. Having some significant political representation competition and freedom is better than having none at all, and what the military did to suppress it was tragic and completely unwarranted. We should collectively impose very stiff sanctions on the corrupt and repressive military regime in Myanmar, while trying to engage it diplomatically to offer incentives for it to return to some kind of pluralistic and constitutional system. But again, our collective leverage is limited.The most serious instances of democratic rollback in Europe have been in Hungary and Poland, and Hungary is no longer even a democracy. I think the regression in these two countries represents a failure on the part of the European Union to bring to bear on these regimes the very considerable leverage that the EU has. The European Union has been providing some extensive net financial transfers to both of these countries, and it should have stopped doing so long ago until the two regimes came into compliance with EU standards regarding judicial independence, the rule of law, and respect for individual liberties and democratic processes. Moreover, when Viktor Orban first started desecrating democracy after he returned power in 2010, the EU could have suspended Hungary’s voting rights within the EU, but this requires unanimity among the other members, and once there was a second populist regime that was rolling back democracy and the rule of law, each regime would have blocked the suspension of the other.The lesson of all of these cases and many more is that the liberal democracies of the world must stand united in helping to defend democratic norms and processes around the world when they come under pressure. When we stand together, we still have considerable leverage that we can apply.”- The past two years have been the ‘COVID-19 era’. Each country has different countermeasures against COVID-19, and some countries have shown a pattern of strengthening control over the people in response to COVID-19. What are the implications of the pandemic on democracy?“Inevitably in a pandemic the power of government must and will expand. In a healthy liberal democracy, citizens have considerable individual freedom, but they should not have the freedom to risk the health of their fellow citizens, or indeed of the entire society. Therefore, I think it is consistent with democracy for the government to mandate vaccinations and mask wearing and to penalize citizens who don’t comply. This has not been too much of a problem in Asia, but in Europe and especially the United States, which don’t have the prior experience with pandemics like SARS, these kinds of government mandates have been a source of deep division. Unfortunately, this has reduced trust in government and heightened political grievance and polarization.The other danger is that governments acquire powers in a pandemic that they don’t want to surrender once the public health crisis is over. An example of this is the tracking and tracing apps on peoples cell phones and other intrusive forms of government monitoring and regulation. It is very important that any kind of emergency power, such as health and contact monitoring, that governments acquired during the pandemic be terminated once the crisis is over. We already face rising challenges to privacy and other rights in the digital era, and it is vital that we always remain vigilant and protective of our liberties.”◆ American Democracy- Concerns about the decline of democracy are widespread in the West, including the United States. What is the current state of American democracy?“Democracy in the United States is going through a period of serious crisis and severe testing. The political system is very deeply polarized. One of the two political parties in the United States has been taken over by an authoritarian personality who nearly destroyed the democratic process during his last term in the presidency. Unfortunately, Donald Trump is highly likely to contest for the presidency again, and he has overwhelming support right now within the republican party. Worse still, Republicans have been eagerly passing laws in many US states that restrict voting rights and give Republican-controlled state legislatures and other partisan figures unwarranted influence over the administration and certification of elections, which should be a completely neutral and independent function as it is in most other liberal democracies. I fear we could be headed for a crisis in the 2024 US presidential election far worse than in 2020 - and that almost led to the demise of American democracy.I am also very concerned about the decline of democratic norms of tolerance and forbearance in the United States. Our political system and indeed our society are very severely polarized right now, and there is a growing belief that violence may be necessary to achieve whatever transcendent aims people have in the political process or to “save the system” from whatever existential threats people think it faces. Violence is the enemy of liberal democracy and a powerful symptom of its ill health. Unfortunately, the decay of democratic dorms in the United States is amplified by the widespread availability of guns, including high-powered, high-capacity automatic weapons that no private citizen should be allowed to have.I remain optimistic that American society will rally to meet the challenges that its democracy faces, and that we will defend the democratic process. We still have a very vigilant and well-organized civil society and a strong independent judiciary that stood up to and rejected Trump’s efforts to overthrow the legitimate results of the last presidential election. But we can no longer take anything for granted.Although there are still significant illiberal, populist pressures and dynamics at play in many European democracies, I think democracy in Europe and in Canada and Australia are in better health. There is a very dangerous right-wing populist bigot contesting for the French presidency in the next election, and other European countries will face other challenges in the years to come. But support for extreme right and illiberal or anti-democratic forces has generally subsided in European democracies recently, as we saw in the very recent German elections. One condition for containing political support for the populist right and maintaining liberal democracy in Europe is to control illegal and unrestrained immigration into Europe. In the last couple of years or so, the EU seems to have had more success with this, but of course it will face continuing pressures in the years to come.”- The history of American democracy seems to be distinguished pre-Trump from post-Trump. Mr. Trump has been criticized for undermining American democracy, but American citizens had chosen him. What is the essence of so-called Trumpism?“First, I need to make a correction to your question. The majority of American citizens did not choose Donald Trump to be president - not in 2016 and not in 2020. Trump lost the popular vote for president in both elections. But he did win a lot of votes, and of course in 2016 he did narrowly win the Electoral College. Unfortunately, the United States is saddled with very outmoded political institutions that can override the will of the majority. The principal one here is the Electoral College but I also have in mind hear the Senate filibuster and in fact the way that the Senate is composed, which vastly under-represents states with large populations and over-represents small rural states. Yet, this is our constitutional system and I think there is no prospect of reforming our constitutional structure in the near term. However, we can fairly easily eliminate the Senate filibuster, and there is growing sentiment to do so.You ask about the essence of Trumpism. It’s not really a policy essence, since policies are not really very important to Trump. Indeed, he is so little concerned with policy that he did not even bother to have his political party, the Republican party, write and adopt a political platform for the 2020 presidential election. This was the first time in anyone’s memory that one of the two major political parties in the United States did not present a political platform to the American people during a presidential campaign.So the essence of Trumpism is an attitude of grievance against “the system” the “deep state” and established institutions, including the courts, the media, and the neutral professional bureaucracy of the state . This is the classic formula of a liberal and ultimately anti-democratic populism. It is a movement of resentment, of negative sentiment, and so it thrives on polarization and in this case, on racial division and other identity divisions.Of course, Trump did push a conservative, low tax, anti-regulatory agenda as president. He sought to weaken protections for the social safety net, for the environment, for labor, and to appoint justices with conservative social and economic philosophies. All of these are familiar left-right policy differences in a democracy, and they are the legitimate subject of policy debate. But I do not think that policies of any kind are the essence of Trump’s appeal. It’s much more about the mobilization of identity and grievance.”- Last July, you wrote “A World Without American Democracy” in Foreign Affairs and were concerned about ‘the global consequences of the United States‘s democratic backsliding’. What are the global implications of the decline of American democracy?“Since the end of World War II and in some ways dating back to the end of World War I, the United States has been the world’s most dynamic and powerful democracy. We saw in between the two world wars the dangerous consequences of American retreat into isolationism and away from global engagement and responsibility. The example of liberal democracy in the United States, even with all its flaws and to some extent because of the extraordinary movements in civil society to address its flaws, has been an inspiration to many people around the world. If democracy in the United States were to continue to decline, this would obviously have very negative implications for democracy globally. But we live in a more multipolar world, the European Union remains a very important actor, and there are other important democracies in the world with resources and influence, including Japan and Korea. Other liberal democracies in the world must step up and do more to defend and promote democratic values. We can only be effective in this project if we stand together.”- Americans voted for Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election. Is Mr. Biden restoring American Democracy?“I think President Biden is trying to strengthen and reinvigorate American democracy. But some of what needs to be done in that regard can only be done with legislation such as the Freedom to Vote act and the John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act. These bills have been passed by the House of Representatives but are now stuck in the Senate and can only be adopted if Democrats in the United States resolve to lift the Senate filibuster for these bills. The decision about that now Rests with one United States senator whose vote is needed in a closely divided senate.I also think that we need strong judicial action to punish those responsible for the January 6 assault on American electoral democracy. There is a bipartisan congressional committee that is investigating the insurrection, and many people have been prosecuted and convicted in the federal courts. Much more remains to be done but I am hopeful that we will get to the bottom of this, and we will achieve legal accountability.“- President Biden recently held a ‘Summit for democracy’ and emphasized solidarity for democracy. What do you think about this?“When democratic norms and institutions are under assault in so many places, as they are today, there is a need to organize a global response. The Summit for Democracy was one part of that response. More than 100 countries in the world came together to declare that they value democracy, that it is the best form of government, and that there steps we all need to take to defend human rights, strengthen independent media, fight kleptocracy, secure free and fair elections, and ensure the technology is used to strengthen freedom and not undermine it. These themes were addressed in depth in the Summit, and by representatives of civil society as well as governments. Now the governments must not only exhibit solidarity in defense of democratic principles, they must make good on their pledges to take specific steps to deepen and reform democracy within their own borders in the coming year.”- The Biden administration was criticized for inviting leaders criticized for authoritarianism. Some critics say that the Biden administration made democracy a tool for the “new cold war” against China and Russia. Can those criticisms be justified?“Anything the democracies of the world do to defend democratic principles and to gather together for this vital purpose is bound to be denounced by China and Russia (and other authoritarian regimes) as hostile, aggressive, and promoting a ‘new cold war.’ Very few of the participants in the Summit for Democracy want to see a new Cold War, or any other kind of conflict with China and Russia. But it is Russia that is creating a war-like condition at the edge of Europe by militarily threatening Ukraine and other neighbors, and by having already invaded Georgia and Ukraine and seized pieces of their territory. And it is China that is generating insecurity in the Indo-Pacific by claiming control over all of the South China sea while moving relentlessly to militarize and monopolize its resources. It is China that is using aggressive language and belligerent displays of military force to threaten Taiwan. If we are drifting toward a ‘new cold war’, then we need to be clear-eyed about who bears responsibility for this.”◆ Causes and solutions- Is the decline of democracy originated from an inherent problem of the democratic ideology and system, or is it a problem of environment and operation?“I don’t think it is the ideas or ideology of democracy per se that is responsible for the current period of erosion and regression. Rather, this owes to the changed geopolitical balance of power in the world, to the destabilizing effects of globalization on economic security within countries, to the effects of rising immigration pressures on Europe and the United States, and to other problems within democracies, especially the steep rise in economic inequality and injustice. If democracy is to be sustainable, we must address starkly rising levels of unfairness and inequality in the distribution of income and wealth. One of America’s most famous Supreme Court Justices, Louis Brandeis, once said, “We can have democracy in this country or we can have great wealth concentrated in the hands of a few, but we can’t have both.” A century later, that warning remains no less valid.”- In terms of the decline of democracy, political polarization and populism are heavily discussed. How did them affect democracy?“I believe I have already addressed this above. Populism is both the product but also the generator and amplifier of polarization. Populist leaders come to power and retain power by driving a deep wedge between aggrieved citizens who feel they are losing ground and elites and minorities who they feel are robbing them of the power and resources that should rightfully be theirs. Populism is cynical, manipulative, and hegemonic in its pretensions. By seeking to turn “the people” against established rules and institutions and appealing to them to place blind faith in the populist leader and party, and by turning majority ethnic groups against vulnerable minorities and immigrants, populism constitutes a major threat to democracy.”- Where can we find the fundamental solution to reverse the decline of democracy?“I wouldn’t say there is a single solution, but there are some key guiding principles. First, we must place loyalty to democratic principles and norms over short-term partisan advantage and ideological goals. We cannot reverse the decline of democracy if we don’t practice democracy and adhere to democratic norms and rules. Second, each country must find its own ways to address the problem of rising economic inequality and insecurity. Democracy must be a shared enterprise in which everyone can live in dignity and have an opportunity to improve themselves and move forward. Third, democracies must show they have the political will and capacity to formulate effective responses to the other policy challenges they face, especially climate change but also numerous other challenges, such as the aging of many of our societies, decaying physical infrastructure, immigration, and other identity divisions. At the same time, many of the challenges confronting democracies around the world are challenges that they face in common and should formulate coordinated responses to. These include not only climate change but the way that corrupt, dirty money moves across borders to be laundered, hidden, and then circulated to influence and undermine our democracies. Related to this is the way that powerful authoritarian regimes, especially Russia and China, use covert, coercive, and corrupting influence - what we call “sharp power” - to penetrate and sway our democratic institutions.”◆ Korean Democracy- In Korea, the presidential election is currently underway. As a prominent researcher who has analyzed Korean democracy, how do you evaluate the past and present of Korean democracy?“Korea is one of many countries that is going through a period of partisan polarization and disillusionment with establishment politics. Still, it has been a very great success story in the third wave of global democratization, and it has now sustained a vigorous democracy for more than three decades. I only hope that political leaders, including the two leading presidential candidates, will act with restraint and try to manifest democratic norms of mutual tolerance and mutual restraint.”-There are also concerns about political polarization and the decline of democracy in Korea. May I ask for your advice for democracy in Korea.“There have been growing concerns among analysts and observers of Korean democracy about the politicization of the justice system, the persistence of corruption, and a posture of trying to win and prevail in politics at any cost. It seems that this is a moment in Korea, as in the United States, when civil society must mobilize across party lines and from outside the party system to try to renew commitment to basic democratic values and reform some of the political practices that are diminishing democracy and good governance. Campaign finance seems to be a serious problem in both the United States and Korea, and a priority for reform.In recent years, the deepening problems of American democracy have motivated the formation of a very dense network of civil society organizations, networks, and alliances that bridge traditional ideological and partisan divides and that have as their main purpose the defense and reform of democracy. If such networks don’t exist in Korea today, there would be great value in building them. Dissatisfaction with the political status quo can lead in two directions: The first is toward growing alienation, cynicism, and withdrawal; the second is mobilization for reform. The first trend leads to the decay and ultimately breakdown of democracy, and the second to its renewal. I hope both our countries will take the second path.”  Larry DiamondSenior Fellow, Hoover InstitutionMosbacher Senior Fellow in Global DemocracyFreeman Spogli Institute for International StudiesBass University Fellow in Undergraduate Educationhttps://diamond-democracy.stanford.edu/

title: [Us and Them] Korea’s division runs deeper than South and North
content: Regional discrimination found in rift between Jeolla and Gyeongsang provinces, rupture between Seoul and rest of the country(123rf)"When I met a new friend in Busan, he asked me where I was from. I said Gwangju and he called me a ‘Jeolladian.’ I did not know what it meant at first." A 20-something cellphone seller in Busan, S has lied about his hometown to his customers, not wanting to cause any unnecessary trouble."My customers would ask me where I was from," he said. "I did not say that I was from Gwangju because I thought it would not benefit me in any way if I told them the truth. So it was a white lie for me." Jeolladian is a derogatory term against people from the Jeolla provinces, often used on the far-right website Ilbe.Korea is mostly known for the division between the South and North on the global stage. But the cracks extend all the way to the bottom of the peninsula, where deep-rooted regionalism prevails. The regional rivalry goes both ways – between the southwestern Honam region that includes the Jeolla provinces and Gwangju, and Yeongnam, which comprises the Gyeongsang provinces and the cities of Busan, Daegu and Ulsan. A woman in her early 30s told The Korea Herald of her struggles at the Seoul branch of a company based in Gwangju. "As my company was established in (South Jeolla Province), most of the employees are from Honam. There is one supervisor in his 40s who obviously treats me badly just because I’m from Daegu," she said. "Another senior employee says 'Hey, Daegu' whenever he calls me." A recent survey shows how hatred based on regionalism is a common problem. Conducted by Realmeter on behalf of the National Human Rights Commission of Korea in May, the survey asked people who were the most targeted group for hate speech both online and offline. With the option to select multiple answers, people who were born in certain regions were the second-most picked group for both online and offline.About 3 in 4 respondents said they have seen hate speech based on regionalism on the internet while a little less than 70 percent said they have witnessed the same type of hatred in their daily life.Although a newer rupture has emerged between Seoul and the rest of the country, the most well-known regional enmity in Korea is between Honam and Yeongnam.The beginning of the decadeslong rivalry between the two regions, dates back to the days of former President Park Chung-hee, who came to power after leading a military coup in 1961. "Regional sentiment deteriorated dramatically with the regionally unequal economic development carried out under the Park Chung-hee administration on top of the tragic disaster in Gwangju in May 1980," Han Hong-koo, a professor at SungKongHoe University, wrote in the Journal of History in 2019. "Regional enmity exploded in the direct presidential election, which was revived after 16 years in 1987. The country’s regional enmity worsened extremely because Korea’s political forces actively manipulated it."Most countries have some level of regional enmity, but South Korea may be the only country that has had its politics dominated by regional conflicts and disputes for 30 years without other major divisions, such as racial, religious or linguistic ones, Han added. In the history of politics, Honam has been a progressive stronghold while Yeongnam voters have traditionally backed conservatives. Studies have shown, however, that the regionalism and the hatred that stems from it has waned in recent years. A study published by the 21st Century Political Science Association in 2018 showed that voters did not show negative feelings toward candidates from other regions. According to the researchers’ analysis, voters in Yeongnam and Honam expressed favoritism toward candidates from their own regions, but did not rule out others from different regions. The study concluded that regional emotions are more about favoritism for one’s own group rather than excluding other regions. "Regionalism will not go away easily. Because it is old and has become a complex conflict in terms of economy, culture and social structure. But is it something that has to be removed?" said Lee Jun-han, a professor of political science and international studies at Incheon National University. "In the past, there was a saying that if a stick ran for an election on behalf of a certain party, some regions would cast votes for that stick. But such extreme choices are becoming weaker. It will be hard to expect Korea’s regionalism to change much from that because taking out the concept of region altogether is difficult." The Science and Technology Policy Institute wrote in a social conflict analysis that people often manipulate media, especially in the run-up to an election to drum up support. "In particular, the conflict between Yeongnam and Honam seems the most severe. This indicates that candidates are using provocative news reports to further instigate regional enmity so they can receive more votes," it said. "We must break away from the chronic disease of regional enmity. It’s time to come up with ways to create a society where politicians, media and citizens can grow together to make politics, media and Korea more developed."Seoul vs. the rest There is a saying here that goes, "South Korea is the Republic of Seoul." It takes a shot at the reality that everything in the country is focused on the capital. Data shows how lopsided the situation is. According to Statistics Korea, half of the country’s population live in the Greater Seoul area of Gyeonggi Province, Incheon and Seoul, while the region accounts for half of the country’s gross domestic product. "We were talking about meeting up in front of the Daegu train station for our project. A graduate student asked me how I was going to get there. I said I will take the subway. She asked me if Daegu has its own subway," Kim Jeong-hyun, a 27-year-old graduate student, told The Korea Herald. The graduate student who had questioned Kim is in her 30s and was born in Seoul. Another interviewee who wished to remain unnamed said his boss was surprised that he came from Chungju, North Chungcheong Province. Chungju has a population of over 200,000. "He said he didn't expect me to have come from a region other than Seoul because I looked 'stylish,' which was very offensive and thoughtless," he said. According to a survey conducted by the Hope Institute, a private policy studies think tank in Seoul, 92 percent of 450 respondents said they have experienced discriminatory language or expressions based on region. "Despite the growing social perception that people should not discriminate, regional discrimination and discriminatory language have existed deeply throughout Korean society and have existed in different forms according to the trend of the times," said Yoo Da-in, a campaign planner at the Hope Institute. "Language is said to reflect society. Of course, there may be complex reasons, but social conflicts have happened due to the regional gap called 'the Republic of Seoul' and some of them have been reflected in regional discriminatory language."The Hope Institute categorized the respondents’ experiences based on the characteristics of the discriminatory language used. Expressions of regional prejudice and stereotypes took up the largest portion, followed by comments that were based on the premise that everything is centered around Seoul. Yoo said such terms constitute "microaggressions," trivial and subtle interactions or behaviors -- sometimes unintentional -- that express a bias toward a group.Some examples of microaggression she mentioned include “Do you have Starbucks (in your hometown)?" "Don’t fix your dialect. It’s cute," and "You are from Chungcheong province, but your action or speaking is not slow?" In order to uproot microaggression, awareness and sensitivity needs to be raised in order to create an atmosphere of respect and understanding of others, she added. On why regionally discriminatory language does not seem to be emphasized as much as other types of discrimination, Yoo pointed to the perception that people think it is fading away. Discriminatory expressions used before the 1990s are not being used anymore, but the problem is that new discriminatory expressions are continuously created, she said."Discriminatory expressions come from conflicts and disputes between people. But once they are created, they are used as tools to further incite conflicts and disputes," Lee Jeong-bok, professor of Korean Language and Literature at Daegu University, wrote in a journal published by the National Institute of Korean Language in 2017."Speakers often do not realize such expressions are discriminatory and some people think it is not a problem to use them figuratively. In fact, this is where the education for acknowledging discriminatory expressions is important."----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The concept of “us” is a strong force in Korean culture, and to be counted as “one of us” in any group comes with privileges big and small within its boundaries. However, for those who fall outside the boundaries of “normal,” life in Korea is riddled with hurdles and sometimes open hatred. In a series of articles, we take a closer look at the biases that exist in Korea, and the lives of those branded as “them” by mainstream society. -- Ed.

title: [CES 2023] SK hynix chief says merger of Western Digital, Kioxia will 'n...
content: SK Group vice chairman and affiliate heads look for newest technologies at CES 2023SK hynix Vice Chairman Park Jung-ho tries on a virtual reality program of urban air mobility set up at the SK showroom in this year's Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, US on Thursday. (Yonhap)LAS VEGAS -- SK hynix Vice Chairman Park Jung-ho said Thursday the merger of two memory competitors -- US’ Western Digital Corp. and Japan’s Kioxia Holdings Corp. -- "will not be easy," shrugging off the possibility of the two chipmakers' tie-up that could transform the business landscape.Earlier in the day, Bloomberg reported that Western Digital and Kioxia are considering merging into one publicly traded company, citing unnamed sources. The structure of the potential deal is fluid, the report added."The Japanese government is friendly with the United States, but I believe it will not easily approve of the merger of the two countries," Park told reporters as he toured around the SK Group showroom set up at the Consumer Electronics Show 2023 in Las Vegas, which kicked off on Thursday.According to TrendForce, a market analysis firm, Samsung Electronics topped the sales of NAND flash chips in the third quarter last year, taking the market share of 31.4 percent, as Kioxia followed with 20.6 percent. SK hynix stood third in the list, taking 18.5 percent of market sales, while Western Digital posted 12.6 percent.In the event of a Kioxia-Western Digital merger, their combine market share of 33.2 percent would beat those of both Samsung Electronics and SK hynix. However, it is not the first time the two chipmakers have discussed a merger. Their previous talks fell through in 2021.While the memory chips industry faces a downturn from sluggish demand, Park said the grim situation will not last long.“I believe the slump in the memory chip industry will not last for long,” he told reporters.As a breakthrough, Park said he is considering expanding the product portfolio into other fields, including mobility and server sectors.“The major clients buying SK hynix’s semiconductors have been PC manufacturers, but I believe it is important to expand our client group to those in mobile, mobility and server sectors as well. I am holding many meetings (at the CES) for that goal.”Over the decline of NAND flash prices that have continued for over a year, Park forecast the average selling price will edge down from that of the end of last year.“(The price rise) would depend on how fast the client sentiment for investment recovers. We are talking with our customers, but macroeconomic trends affect the issue,” Park added.After his tour of the SK Group showroom, Park also met with Qualcomm CEO Christiano Amon to discuss the overall situation of the semiconductor industry and of their possible collaboration, SK said.Chey Jae-won (center), vice chairman of SK Group and brother of the conglomerate's Chairman Chey Tae-won, began his tour around the SK Group's showroom at the CES venue in Las Vegas, US on Thursday. (Jo He-rim/The Korea Herald)As the world's largest convention of home appliances and technologies kicked off on Thursday, Park and other members of SK leadership made visits to the SK showroom and those of others.Chey Jae-won, vice chairman of SK Group and brother of the conglomerate's Chairman Chey Tae-won began his tour around the CES venue early on Thursday, together with Cho Dae-sik, the chairman of the SK Supex Council and the second-in-command, Kim Jun, the vice chairman and president of SK Innovation and Choo Hyeong-wook, SK E&S president.After visiting the SK Group's showroom, Chey also visited the showroom of Samsung Electronics and LG Electronics, where he was greeted by the chiefs of both companies, Samsung's Vice Chairman Han Jong-hee and LG's CEO Cho Joo-wan.Chey Tae-won had planned to participate in this year's CES, and face-to-face meetings were planned with business partners, but they were all turned to virtual ones after his secretary was confirmed with COVID-19.By Jo He-rimKorea Herald correspondent (herim@heraldcorp.com)

title: [KH Explains] Why is Boryung assailed by investors over space vision?
content: Boryung's risky bet puts over 10% of total equity into still-nascent space businessJay Kim, CEO of BoryungAmid global pharmaceutical companies' efforts to foray into the space health care industry, major South Korean health care company Boryung has likewise released an adventurous vision to establish its footing in the nascent sector. However, the company's business acumen is being questioned by stockholders, as experts say the hefty investment in the space business may still be risky.Since being anointed with the title of CEO for Boryung in January, Jay Kim, grandson of Boryung founder Kim Seung-ho, has spared no expense in expanding space-related projects for the drug-making company.NASA's space shuttle Endeavour exhibited during Boryung's CIS Challenge Demo Day held in Samuel Oschin Pavilion, Los Angeles on Dec. 9 (Boryung)In April, Boryung launched a global challenge in collaboration with US commercial space station developer Axiom Space and advisory firm Starburst to provide commercialization support for technologies to help optimize human health for space travel.The efforts were followed by the company's decision to invest a whopping $50 million in Axiom Space, accounting for 13.7 percent of the company's total equity and 7.8 percent of its total assets, according to Hanwha Investment & Securities.The company's rather unforeseen sally into the new business field, on top of its mammoth investment, has been brewing sentiments of concern for its stockholders.Boryung's shares closed at 9,060 won ($7.15) on Thursday, and its share price has been gradually dipping all year. Thursday's shares marked the lowest point in the year and a 37.95 percent drop from Dec. 30, 2021, when Boryung shares were 14,600 won each.The company's latest investment in the US startup was cited as one of the reasons for the dull market sentiment."Investment of 13.7 percent of a company's total equity is considered large," an analyst at Hanwha Investment & Securities told The Korea Herald on the condition of anonymity."It can indeed cause financial volatility if subsequent investments are made," he added.Hanwha Investment & Securities recently declared a halt to the corporate analysis of Boryung.Experts did not specifically provide an answer as to why the firm has given up analyzing Boryung, but it is generally understood that security firms stop analyzing a company when the growth potential for stocks of the company becomes too murky to predict, and uncertainties surrounding the companies grow.Another analyst pointed to the high costs and risks involved in developing new drugs in space as reasons for lukewarm responses to the company's latest vision."A big reason for a pharma company to venture into space would be to develop new drugs in a zero-gravity environment," another anonymous researcher at a local securities firm said. The zero-gravity environment facilitates the production of homogeneous drugs by preventing ingredients from sinking to the bottom.“At the same time, it is a pricey and time-consuming process that is extremely difficult to succeed,” he said."Without proper research facilities in space, the business can be unrealistic."Lee Jae-min, a professor at Seoul National University School of Law, admitted that government support is crucial in assisting the private sector’s foray into the still-nascent space business, saying there should be a legal basis to do so.Despite investor jitters, experts agree on the high potential of the space business. According to the Korea Aerospace Research Institute, it is a $447 billion market, with an annual growth rate of 8 percent. In Korea, the market size was estimated to be around 3.9 trillion won as of 2019.

title: KDI warns “downside risks” for first time in six months
content: South Korea’s state think-tank Korea Development Institute (KDI) warned against “downside risks” that the Korean economy is facing amid rising global uncertainty for the first time in six months.“Korea’s economic recovery is slowing on the contraction in the face-to-face service industry, and downside risks are running high amid growing global uncertainties,” according to KDI’s monthly report on economic trends released on Thursday.The institute warned of “uncertainty” in the Korean economic recovery since July last year, but it is the first time since April this year that the think-tank observed “downside risks”.The steady rise in energy and commodity prices including crude oil has been driving up producer and consumer prices, the report said. The strong commodity prices and global supply shortages have deteriorated the manufacturing business confidence. The business sentiment index (BSI) for the manufacturing industry has shrunk from 101 in July to 96 in August, 94 in September and 92 in October. “Some businesses including automobile sector are suffering the ongoing supply crunch for intermediate goods and distribution disruptions,” said Jung Kyu-chul, head of the macroeconomic analysis and forecasting department at KDI, warning that the U.S. monetary tightening and China’s Evergrande debt crisis could weigh further on the recovery momentum of the manufacturing industry.  “Global industrial production and goods trade continued to stall, and major countries saw a contraction in corporate sentiment due to the growing concerns over economic situation in the US and China,” according to the report.The rapid growth at above 2 percent in consumer prices over the past six months is another cause of concern for the Korean economy. According to Statistics Korea data, prices of petroleum and livestock products increased sharply at 22 percent and 13.9 percent, respectively, in September compared to the previous year. “The recent price hikes are driven by supply issues instead of demand,” said Jung. He said the continued inflationary pressure may have a negative impact on the economy.The country’s economic and financial leaders are trying to stabilize the financial markets that have been volatile in recent weeks. The country’s vice minister of economy and finance Lee Eok-won held an emergency meeting on Thursday after the Korean stock, currency and bond prices dipped amid concerns over external risk factors. Due to the possibility of increased volatility in the financial market at home abroad, he pledged to strengthen oversight on the market situation and take immediate actions when deemed necessary.Finance minister Hong Nam-ki also convened a ministerial meeting on Thursday to discuss ways to deal with the U.S. request to submit data of Korean chip makers. The U.S. government has asked Korean chip makers including Samsung Electronics and SK hynix to hand out data on chip production, inventory, orders, sales and clients by Nov.8.[ⓒ Maeil Business Newspaper & mk.co.kr, All rights reserved]

title: An insane state-run institute
content: The Korea Research Institute for Human Settlements (Krihs) accused the media for hyping up and worsening apartment prices in Seoul and across the country. In a recently published report, the state-run institute claimed that it found media influence in the investment concentration in apartments and the jump in average prices as well as the sky-high housing values in Seoul, including the three hot Gangnam real estate districts. The report studied the relationship between press coverage on average housing prices, top prices and trade volumes and consumer sentiment.  The report concluded that an increase in media coverage on apartment price surges in Seoul actually fanned the anticipation for a further rise. The phenomenon has deepened since 2017 to send the prices to record highs, said the report.  The report was based on the assumption that media reports influence housing prices. Data was collected to back the theory and fixed to stretch the correlation, bringing the finding it had aimed. The institute’s analysis, however, has committed fallacy from the definition of basic statistical analysis. It is like attributing the rain to the prayer ritual after the rain finally comes.  The jump in housing prices resulted from the government’s repeated policy failures. It had to trot out 26 sets of real estate measures because it never got it right. In April, President Moon Jae-in admitted that he had little excuse on real estate issues. It is preposterous to lay the blame on the media.  Krihs President Kang Hyun-soo had been a key confidante of Kim Soo-hyun, former presidential policy chief who had designed the real estate policy for the Moon Jae-in administration. The two went to the same graduate school on environment at Seoul National University and rotated to head the progressive space and environment society called the Korea Association of Space and Environment Research. Kang was the third head of the association and Kim the 10th. Short-lasted Byun Chang-heum who resigned over the Korea Land and Housing Corp. scandal was also a member of the research group. While the ruling Democratic Party railroads with a highly controversial amendment to the Media Arbitration Act, a state think tank claims the media was the behind the housing unrest. All this is outrageous.

title: Korea’s M\&A scene in a standstill as financing rate nears double digits
