Many interviewees pointed out that the values and sentiments they see in Korean soap operas are more acceptable than Western or Japanese popular culture because they derive from Confucianism and are the real sentiments of real Asian lives.Many Taiwanese and Asians living in Vienna empathize with Korean popular culture because it presents Asian sentiments under modern conditions, as in fashions and lifestyles.Many people that I interviewed pointed out the importance of "family values" and social relationships. According to Alice Chen, who considers herself a great fan of the Korean Wave, Korean television dramas convey the traditional roles of men and women in relationships better than other Asian products."I believe that the Korean Wave results partly from this search for "Asianness" in contemporary Taiwan. Many Taiwanese believe that Korean popular culture contains what Taiwanese consider to be an Asian character or value. Something they miss in Western culture, or even in Japanese popular culture -which some Taiwanese respondents have criticized - is that it is too unrealistic to Taiwanese situations. I love to see Korean soap operas. They are always so sentimental and sad. You know, like the old-time stories. This makes me wanting to see more Korean soap operas." (Alice Chen, interview with author, April 1, 2002) As expressed by Alice Chen, the evocation of Asian sentiment and values is an important factor that attracted Taiwanese to Korean popular culture.Many Asians that I interviewed in Vienna, Austria also point out the Asianness contained in Korean soap operas is the most attractive drive of Korean popular culture. According to Dorcy, who is from the Phillipines, told me how popular Korean soap operas are among them. She argued since Korean soap opera is so popular in the Phillipines, she always purchase whenever she return home and share with her friends here. According to her, "I think every Asians like Korean soap operas. Not only us but I know other Asians like to watch them, too" (Interview with author, Dec. 15, 2007). Through interviewing many Asians living in Austria, it is discovered that the Asian sentiment and values that are expressed in Korean popular culture is the most significant reason behind the circulation of Korean popular culture among Asians.The second reason is that the economic decline of Asia forced television producers to seek out products cheaper than Japanese and Western products. One of these was soap operas, the starting-point of the Korean Wave in Taiwan. According to Shim Doo-bo, the Korean Wave arose mainly because of the media liberalization that swept across Asia in 1990s, when the economic crisis made Asian buyers prefer the cheaper Korean products compared with Japanese and Hong Kong products. Lili, the primary producer of K-Pop Entertainment at Gala-TV in Taiwan, told me that the main reason that GTV began programming Korean soap operas was because of their cheap prices compared to Japanese products, and Korean soap operas were even cheaper than domestic ones. According to her, Korean soap operas were of much better quality then Taiwanese products, but were much cheaper, so GTV dubbed in Mandarin and aired the programs as if they were locally made soap operas. At that time, the cost of domestic dramas was as high as $20,000 per hour.In 1999, GTV began buying old dramas from the Korean Broadcasting System under the considerations that it costs less than the domestic dramas and the quality of the Korean dramas could be guaranteed. GTV was informed that KBS had invested a huge amount of money in production. Indeed, Korea has long invested in dramas, and after 1993 it has encouraged the investment of private capital in the media industry. Therefore, to supplement domestic dramas, GTV introduced Korean dramas of low cost and good quality.In the initial state, GTV domesticated the imported Korean dramas by adding domestic flavor and not labeling the dramas as Korean imports. GTV not only provided Chinese dubbings and subtitles, but also televised the programs right after domestic programs, so that people would naturally feel them to be their domestic programs. At first, Korean dramas had little success: they garnered no more than 1 percent of viewers.But "Firework," first shown in 2000, took ratings to a historical high of 4.9 percent, and was then rerun several times. Its success led Taiwanese cable companies to import other Korean dramas. Seen in Taiwan throughout years, these dramas became one of the most important factors of the Korean Wave in Taiwan today.The third reason for the success of the Korean wave is the self-confidence and nationalism Koreans show through their popular culture as well as in international events. The term self-confidence was often mentioned by respondents when they characterized South Korean popular culture. Most used the term when they described the performance of South Korean pop singers.Taiwanese see in South Korean pop music a confident character, even if it is only the self-confidence of energy expended in singing and dancing. Many Taiwanese interviewees said South Korean self-confidence has made them curious about Korean society, and this curiosity has led them to learn more about Korean culture. According to Feng Lai, a journalist for the gossip magazine Apple, "Korean music is very strong and projects self-confidence. Just like their nationalism. They are strong and confident" (interview with author, May 3, 2002). As Lai points out, this is a reason why performers who project exaggerated masculine or sexy attitudes are favored in Taiwan.Through South Korean pop culture, viewers can experience how Koreans manage to keep Korean values while incorporating Western elements into their culture. Korean pop culture has borrowed the best of Western popular culture and recreated it according to Korean tastes. That is why Korean popular culture differs from others: it expresses inner passion and powerful energy. Many Taiwanese claim they get a sense of the nationalism of the Korean people from South Korean popular culture.Mally said, "I think Koreans are very proud of their culture and tradition. When I look at Korean soap operas or movies, I am always so amazed. They try to express `Korea.` Look at all these ancient dramas, ?ΨDaejanggeum (Jewel in the Palace),?Ψ for example. I could just feel how Koreans are proud of their tradition and culture. The clothes, food, history, and all those things explored - it still doesn`t feel like old past. Korean people still feel so confident about themselves" (interview with author, June 15, 2004).Movies like "JSA" and "Shiri," which deal with the political issues of the Korean peninsula, strongly affected Taiwanese. John at Avex Office in Taipei said, "After I saw these two movies, I felt very sad. Taiwanese cannot make this kind of movies. It is all about love and also probably too sensitive part to touch on, because we all don`t think the same about politics anyway. Anyway, "JSA" and "Shiri" really impressed me, and I have seen another side of Korea. They are just a very strong nationality" (interview with author, July 15, 2004).The circulation of popular culture in Asia is becoming much more active. Having started with Japanese popular culture and Hong Kong popular culture, many Asian teenagers now favor Korean popular culture. Some people argue that the Korean Wave is slowly fading away, and it no longer interests Asians much; however, many interviews that I have conducted with Taiwanese and overseas Asians show that Korean popular culture has its own distinctive character, which Asians can assimilate. Therefore, even overseas Asians are fond of watching Korean dramas. The Korean Wave has been an ongoing issue in Asia for ten years. To some Asians, it is not fascinating, or a new topic of interest, but it remains a very important element in intraregional circulation and thus has become part of the cultural makeup of the Asian pop cultural landscape.By Sung Sang-yeon

title: Time for pragmatism
content: Yeom Jae-ho The author is an emeritus professor and former president of Korea University. There is only a year left until the next presidential election in March 2022. The two mayoral by-elections, in Seoul and Busan in April, this year will surely serve as litmus tests for the presidential race. The country, exhausted from intense political infighting between the ruling and opposition parties throughout the last four years, must clearly assess the successes and failures of the Moon Jae-in administration before heading into the presidential election.    The last three presidents ended their terms with impeachment, imprisonment and suicide, which brought immense damage on the people. The country is divided and reason lost, while only political banners are flapping in the wind. Divisions continue to run ever more deeply, but our political leaders hide behind banners. Political leadership resolving society’s problems together through compromise and debate is lost as each side, wrapped in their respective ideologies, only seeks to maximize their own interests.    Young Tony Blair emerged to rebuild a wayward British Labour Party by proposing a third way independent of ideology. Chairman Deng Xiaoping paved the way for China to become one of the G2 with his pragmatic brand of thinking, embodied in his proverb: “It doesn’t matter whether a cat is black or white. If it can catch mice, it is a good cat.” Chancellor Angela Merkel, a native of East Germany, embraced pragmatic progressivism in leading Germany and the European Union. All these are the images of leaders who have brightened their countries’ futures.    The Moon Jae-in administration began by presenting a blueprint to transform the country with its purge against “accumulated evils” through reforms of the chaebol and prosecution. It promised to move the presidential office to Gwanghwamun Square, to move closer to the people, and Moon himself promised to be a president of unity and dialogue who even embraces his political opponents.    The Blue House even set up an electronic monitor to check on national employment levels in order to resolve the issue of youth unemployment. Moon advocated becoming the driver of peace on the Korean Peninsula, and said he would promote environment, safety, women and human rights issues. He promised equality and justice. But when we look back, all this was just political rhetoric, and we only remember irresponsible and amateur policies.    Even those who are critical of the ruling Democratic Party (DP)’s past governance respect former President Kim Dae-jung’s efforts to overcome the financial crisis through major reforms in finance, corporations, labor and public spending, and President Roh Moo-hyun’s pursuit of the Korea- U.S. Free Trade Agreement, troop deployment to Iraq and the construction of a naval base on Jeju Island. It was because people saw in them the images of leaders who embrace other ideas by being pragmatic progressives.    Our country can no longer be hostage to uncompromising factions on the right and left as clearly seen in the ultraconservative Taegukki troops and the avid followers of Moon. It is disappointing to see the Seoul and Busan by-elections devolve into vote calculations based on the popularity of candidates or anti-administration sentiment rather than a genuine competition between policy visions for the people. We cannot leave our future up to politicians with only rhetoric but no vision and philosophy, sophistry without clear policies, focused on costs and benefits without principle, and not willing to take responsibility for their own words.    We must be wary of the populism being forged by politicians who trick the people with sweet words. Instead of ad hoc populist policies, politicians must devise pragmatic and detailed policy. Instead of making a law that hands out billions of dollars to the self-employed hit by Covid-19 restrictions, we should think of quarantine methods that can allow them to operate their businesses in limited but regular ways. A government’s competence is defined by its ability to maximize the effectiveness of health measures while trying to limit cash handouts for fiscal integrity’s sake and lessen the burden placed on future generations. Progressive policy is coming up with detailed plans to minimize infection through the use of big data analysis. Handing out money is the easiest way, but it is also the most incompetent policy.    We must end political fights and return to the realm of “life politics.” A real progressive government must emerge that is willing to administer the country through compromise.

title: [Earnings roundup] LG Chem breaks earnings records on battery boom
content: LG Display pares losses, Kia's Q4 net nearly triples　LG Chem, LG Display, Kia and a score of other companies on Wednesday released business results from the final quarter of 2020, summing up a year hit hard by the infectious disease and restrained consumer sentiment.　Despite the unfavorable market conditions, some managed to report surprisingly strong earnings in the face of adversity.　LG Chem breaks record 　 LG headquarters in Yeouido, Seoul (Yonhap)　Strong battery sales pushed revenues of LG Chem to a record high in 2020.　The country’s leading chemical company reported annual sales of 30.05 trillion won ($27.1 billion), surpassing the 30 trillion-won mark for the first time. Compared to a year ago, sales grew 9.9 percent. 　Operating profits also spiked 185.1 percent on-year to 2.35 trillion won. 　LG Chem also broke records in quarterly figures.   　In the final three months of the year, LG Chem earned 8.85 trillion won, up 19.9 percent from the previous year, while its operating profit registered 673.6 billion won. 　“Amid the pandemic, the annual revenue saw a 10 percent growth and exceeded a 30 trillion-won mark for the first time. In the fourth quarter, LG Chem further strengthened its competitiveness through the successful split-off of its battery business division,” said LG Chem Chief Financial Officer Cha Dong-seok.　LG Display bounces back 　 8.5 generation OLED plant in Guangzhou, China (LG Display)　LG Display, which in the third quarter of last year swung to profit after six consecutive quarters of operating deficits, reported strong fourth quarter results on the back of increased demand for panels for IT gadgets and TVs. 　Its operating profit for the November-December period came in at 685 billion won, which beat market expectations. Compared with a quarter earlier, the figure was up 318 percent.   　Revenue stood at 7.4 trillion won and net profit was 620.9 billion won. 　The strong fourth quarter figures pulled up its full-year results. 　The company’s operating loss in 2020 was reduced by 1.3 trillion won ($1.1 billion) to 29 billion won, from the previous year’s 1.36 trillion won. Its full-year net loss was 70.6 billion won, another 98 percent on-year increase from 2019’s 2.8 trillion won. 　FnGuide, a financial data analysis service, had projected a 2020 operating loss of 408 billion won for LG Display. 　Seo Dong-hee, LG Display’s chief financial officer, credited the performance to increased sales of organic light-emitting diode panels, as well as the company’s agile response to maximize opportunities in the contactless, non-face-to-face market environment. 　In the fourth quarter, the continued work-from-home culture due to COVID-19 led to more sales of diverse display panels, and to increased demand for large OLEDs and plastic OLEDs, LG Display said in a press release. 　IT panel sales accounted for the biggest portion at 37 percent, whereas TV panels made up 29 percent and mobile panels and other items amounted to 34 percent. 　　Kia’ Q4 net profit almost triples  　 Kia's new brand logo and slogan (Kia Corp.)　Kia Corp., South Korea’s second-largest carmaker and sister brand to Hyundai Motor, saw its latest quarterly net profit nearly triple from a year earlier, on the back of improved product mix.　The company’s net profit from October to December last year came to 976.75 billion won ($883.78 million), up from 346.36 billion won observed a year earlier, the company said Wednesday in a statement.　Operating profits also more than doubled to 1.28 trillion won from 590.52 billion won, while sales expanded 5 percent to 16.91 trillion won from 16.11 trillion won during the same period.　The company’s debt ratio during the given period climbed 11.3 percent to 102.3 percent, with 4.2 trillion-won debt against 928 billion-won capital.　Full-year-wise, Kia Motors’ revenue rose 1.8 percent on-year to 59.1 trillion won, and operating profit increased 2.8 percent on-year to 2.06 trillion won. Net profit fell 17.7 percent on-year to 1.5 trillion won. 　The company credited its fourth quarter performance to a cut in incentives and improvement in average sales price.　“Partial strike and COVID-19 has adversely affected business environments,” Kia said in a press release, “We have still managed to improve our performance through increased sales of high profit-yielding vehicles.” 　Kia’s vehicle line includes Sonet, Seltos, Sorento, Carnival, Telluride and Sportage.  　In terms of wholesale transaction, Kia said it sold more than 742,000 cars -- more than 137,000 units in Korea and 605,000 overseas.　The most drastic improvement was observed in India, where the company’s sales rose 85.6 percent on-year during the final three months of the year. The regional growth, along with the 4 percent on-year growth in the US market, offset the decline in most other markets, officials said.　The automaker saw its sales drop 5.2 percent here, 7.3 percent in Western Europe and 11.3 percent in China during the final quarter.　Based on its latest performances, Kia has decided to pay a 1,000 won-per-share dividend, with total payout amounting to 400.9 billion won.　　LG Household & Health Care to pay W184.4b in dividends　 The history of fu (LG Household & Health Care)　Beauty product sales faltered, but household items towed LG Household & Health Care’s 2020 performance.　Despite the difficult business environment, the company managed to continue its 16-year growth streak. LG Household & Health Care decided on dividends of 11,000 won per ordinary share and 11,050 won per preference share. The total payout amounts to 184.4 billion won.　The company reported full-year revenue of 7.8 trillion won and operating profit of 1.2 trillion won, up 2.1 percent and 3.8 percent, respectively, on-year. 　The fourth quarter revenue alone was 2 trillion won and operating profit was 256 billion won, up 4 percent and 6.3 percent on-year, respectively. These were the company’s best-ever fourth quarter results.　But LG Household & Health Care’s beauty business fell 6.1 percent and 8.3 percent, respectively, in revenue and operating profit compared with the previous year. The company made 4.4 trillion won in revenue and 822 billion won in operating profit in the beauty sector.　The home care and beauty business, on the other hand, grew 25.9 percent in on-year revenue at 1.8 trillion won, and posted 63 percent growth in operating profit at 205 billion won. By Lim Jeong-yeo (kaylalim@heraldcorp.com) & Kim Byung-wook (kbw@heraldcorp.com)　[네이버에서 코리아헤럴드 구독]▶ KH Podcast     ▶ KH Video<ⓒKoreaHerald(www.koreaherald.com)무단전재 및 재배포 금지>

title: [Special feature] What is Park Geun-hye’s appeal?
content: [한겨레] NFP leader led her party to victory in April, but the presidency is a much bigger challengeBy Sung Han-yong, political correspondent and Song Chae Kyung-hwa, staff writer Wearing a black suit and a solemn facial expression, Park Geun-hye stood before a podium, getting ready to give a speech one day after the general elections that gave the ruling New Frontier party a majority win. Only once done reading the script did she finally smile. Without taking reporters’ questions, she got off the stage and shook hands with journalists, saying she knew how busy they must have been following every move she had made during the election campaign.   Then she visited a guard post located outside of the party headquarters building to shake hands with about 20 conscripted policemen, who are mostly in their early 20’s. “It was thanks to your service that I was able to lead the party with no safety worries during the race.”What she added next drew big applause from the young uniformed men: “You will all get married one day soon. And I understand rising worries about high interest rates for housing loans. I will make sure you will be out in society leading quality lives with no such worry. I wish you the best.”   There are a few explanations for the somewhat unexpected results in the April 11 parliamentary elections, in which the ruling New Frontier Party retained its majority-status, shattering earlier predictions that the opposition Democratic United Party (DUP) would beat its conservative rival. Among many factors that led the conservative camp to electoral victory, experts point to Park Geun-hye’s leadership as the main reason.  How and why so many are drawn to the daughter of former strong-arm leader Park Chung-hee? On the campaign trail, she was greeted by as if she were a  celebrity. No matter where she went, big crowds soon formed to get a glimpse of her. Requests to take a photograph with her were overwhelming. Her popularity was higher among women and older people. Voters’ interest in her seemingly centred more around her appearance than her words. The soft-spoken saviour for the apparently failing NFP always thanked those who praised her looks. Many expressed surprised at Park’s smaller-than-expected stature. Similar reactions from voters were seen all across the country, especially in the southeastern region of Yeongnam.In Gangwon province, where the ruling camp clinched all nine parliamentary seats, the chairwoman’s appeal never seemed to wane.  Wonjoo-A and B district in the mountainous province had previously been considered DUP strongholds. But following the two visits paid by Ms. Park, mood in those areas began to change.  The winds of the soft-spoken Park soon swept the region. Park visited every contested district seeking support from voters, and on an election day they gave her what she had wanted. Ms. Park’s public appeal, which no other politicians are able to grasp these days, has been a source of wonder for many. The Hankyoreh asked NFP’s newly-elected who have long worked with Park for their thoughts on favourable public sentiment toward her.First, she has always been perceived as the daughter of the charismatic and authoritarian leader Park Jung-hee, who was assassinated by his long-time subordinate, and this perception will never change irrespective of what she does. For those over in their 50’s, she is a subject of sympathy, a  princess-turned-iron lady  politician who experienced the tragic loss of both her parents to assassins. She is single with no children. She has successfully cultivated her image as a victim persecuted for long by macho political figures like Chun Doo-hwan, Lee Hei-chang, Roh Moo-hyun and Lee Myung-bak. Voters associate her personal life stories with political ones, bolstering her victimized image.  The 60-year-old woman’s pure and innocent appearance is another boost to that association. Secondly, economic challenges due to neo-liberal policies have helped her gain a political edge. As income inequality increases, those who slip from the middleclass are apt to become nostalgic for the military-authoritarian rule that brought Korea rapid economic growth. Those with nostalgia can be persuaded to believe that a former dictator’s daughter could be able to change their lives once in power.  Whether she will be able to make these fantasies come true is another story. Korean politics has a record of having been driven by charismatic and powerful figuressuch as former presidents, Kim Young-sam, Kim Dae-jung and Roh Moo-hyun. With the absence of strong leaders, only Ms. Park stands alone as the influential and has drawn popularity even from young people. Though computer entrepreneur-turned-professor Ahn Cheol-soo has been considered placed within the category of political stars, he has yet to enter politics and watched the general elections from the sidelines. Political experts do not differ significantly on this. “Park has not shown a clear vision for the country nor has she major achievements,” writes political consultant Park Sung-min in his book ‘The Collapse of Politics’.” “The image made of integrity, bravery and courage that she has painstakingly cultivated over many years is a key element in understanding her popularity. Patriotic comments like ‘I am married to the country” also helped push up her positive image,” Park Sung-min notes. The author says “the extent of trust Park has won from the public is so wide that people even feel secure entrusting their property to her, the only kind of such in current political arena”, and goes on to claim “the fact that she rarely makes mistakes in her speech also strengthens her credit”. Trying to interpret the Park’s leadership through her characteristics places a focus on only Park.  The need to analyze her leadership by looking at the power structure of country’s conservative forces and the NFP therefore arises. Based on this analysis, some allege Park’s role was only to maximize the NFP’s power, which has remained intact and been backed by strong conservative groups for a long time.Looking at histories of the governing camp helps understand deep-rooted conservatism in the country. The foundation of the NFP dates back to the Democratic Justice Party formed in 1980 by the Chun Doo-hwan military government. It then was merged with two other opposition parties in 1990 to emerge as the Democratic Liberty Party (DLP). The DLP was then only renamed as New Korea party by former president Kim Yong-sam a few years later. Three-time presidential candidate Lee Hoi-chang changed the name again, calling it the Grand National Party in 1997. Amid all these changes in the past three decades, the conservative party never let its grip slip on a majority in the National Assembly, except for just once in 2004 when it was hit hard by aftermath of its impeachment against then-president Roh Moo-hyun.   The NFP’s dominance has always remained unchanged on the back of a strong connection among power elite, a combination of conservative ideas, regionalism in Yeongnam, financing from chaebol and the so-called Cho-Joong-Dong media, a reference to the three major conservative newspapers. The first time this 'cartel' lost its grip on to a power was in 1997 when the opposition’s presidential candidate Kim Dae-jung defeated his conservative rival Lee Hoi-chang amid the financial crisis. The conservatives’ second presidential election defeat five years later was a humiliating repeat. From the three consecutive losses to the liberal bloc, it had learned it was crucial to avoid moves that might split its supporters and refrained from flexing its muscle too much.  Putting Park in the middle of the electoral battle was a calculated move from its experience in 2004. The opposition DUP’s earlier dream of winning over 150 assembly seats simply displays its lack of understanding of still-intact predominance of such cartel and its unyielding faith in Park. Some political commentators, however, say the 60-yeard-old woman has been overestimated. “The election results less reflects outperformance of the chairwoman than poorly-executed DUP campaigning, in which the opposition made a number of blunders,” said a political analyst who spoke on condition of anonymity.  The analyst said the governing party may lose in December should the voting turn out reaches around 65 percent.  “The NFP apparently failed in extending its support base to the districts in Seoul in the general elections. Unless Park brings changes to her top-down decision making style and behind-the-door deal making, she could blow her chance to achieve her long-held dream later this year,” added the commentator.  “Park could not stop Moon Jae-in from beating his NFP rival, and other DUP candidates in Busan all carried neck-and-neck races despite the five-time visits by Park,” said a campaigning aide to Moon, who requested to be unnamed.  “The campaigning in Busan was mainly orchestrated by local NFP organizations. Park had little influence in swinging voters' sentiment here. She has clearly been overstated," said the aide. Despite differing assessments of her influence and power, many agree that Park has cemented her presidential ambition by bringing the April 11 electoral triumph to the conservative bloc.  Many will certainly be drawn to watch how the woman with two images, the one beloved by the public and the other symbolizing a conservative 'cartel', will lead herself and the conservative forces in the run-up to the country's biggest event in December.Translated by Kang Jin-kyu, Hankyoreh English internPlease direct questions or comments to [englishhani@hani.co.kr]공식 SNS [통하니] [트위터] [미투데이] | 구독신청 [한겨레신문] [한겨레21]Copyrights ⓒ 한겨레신문사, 무단전재 및 재배포 금지<한겨레는 한국온라인신문협회(www.kona.or.kr)의 디지털뉴스이용규칙에 따른 저작권을 행사합니다.>

title: Korea, China debate rages over Goguryeo
content: Public calls on Seoul government to take firm stance on Beijing`s history move   The public uproar over the South Korean and Chinese academic debate on the historical ancestry of the Goguryeo Dynasty (37 B.C.-A.D. 668) met unexpected opposition earlier this month, when Culture Minister Lee Chang-dong criticized the heated media coverage and cautioned against the issue developing into a political issue.Lee confirmed the ministry`s stance of avoiding direct intervention in the ongoing arguments and expressed skepticism about the logic employed by media outlets in calling for the government to make an official statement against Beijing."China`s recent movements claiming Goguryeo as part of their national legacy are, to a large extent, politically motivated and defensive. The government would be wise not to politicize the issue, considering China`s sensitivity about its ethnic diversity and the two million ethnic Koreans living in their northeastern provinces," Lee said in a news conference. Promising further support on related academic research, he stressed that the current controversy should be resolved though extensive academic discussions between the neighboring countries and not through political debates.Lee`s comments - the boldest statement yet made by any government official on the matter - immediately met fierce resistance, with politicians and the media accusing the minister of betraying the "national interest." Rep. Gu Sang-chan of the majority Grand National Party called Lee`s comments a "disgrace," while Millennium Democratic Party chairman Chough Soon-hyung chose to describe them as "regrettable" and announced the formation of a discussion panel within the party dealing with the controversies surrounding Goguryeo`s history and the sovereignty over Dokdo, a tiny island off the eastern coast which Japan claims is part of its territory.The Dong-a Ibo, a vernacular daily, suggested the government lacked commitment in defending "national sovereignty," while several other media outlets followed a similar line, albeit using more reserved rhetoric.It is not hard to understand why Lee`s comments were considered by many as contrary to the general public sentiment. Since a group of 17 historical societies across the nation - including the Korean Ancient Historical Association and the Korean Archaeological Society - declared joint action against their Chinese counterparts in December last year, the issue has been a rallying point for politicians and civic activists alike calling for the government to respond boldly to China`s attempts at "distorting history." Many have urged the government to support the North Korean efforts to put Goguryeo`s mural paintings on the U.N. World Heritage List at UNESCO`s general meeting, scheduled for June in Suzhou, southern China.The bid was put on hold indefinitely last year, when a report questioning the preservation condition of the sites was filed with the International Council of Monuments and Sites, a UNESCO subcommittee. According to numerous reports by the Korean media, Chinese scholars and authorities contributed significantly to the ICOMOS report. China has been pushing its own bid for World Heritage designation on its Goguryeo murals in Jian, northeastern China.However, government officials have been reluctant to connect the North Korean bid with the Goguryeo controversy, fearing an awkward standoff with China.Debate over Northeast Asian Project  The recent conflict between academics of the two countries over the ancestry of Goguryeo - which extended from the northern part of the Korean Peninsula to the greater part of Manchuria in its prime - was triggered in February 2002 when China launched the "Northeast Asian Project," a five-year, $2 million government project on the regional studies of Northeast Asia.South Korean academics have criticized the Northeast Asian Project, headed by the state-run Chinese Academy of Social Science, for distorting historical facts following the release of several papers last year asserting Goguryeo was part of the Chinese legacy and denying any continuity between the Manchuria-based kingdom and the current Korean Peninsula.The Northeast Asian Project has so far released five papers on the issue, mostly dedicated to proving that Goguryeo started as a subject state of the Qian Han Dynasty (206 B.C.-6 A.D.) and remained as such under the Chinese kingdoms that followed. The base of their logic is simple: Goguryeo was founded by the tribes of Okjeo, Han, Yemaek and other tribes of Qian Han who lived in southeastern Manchuria and never intended to break away from their geopolitical origin, paying tributes to the Chinese kingdoms of their time. The scholars also point out the fact that nearly half of Goguryeo`s population was absorbed by the Han tribe of the Tang Dynasty (618-907) after the kingdom`s collapse.Korean scholars deny the validity of such theories."To connect the issue of paying tributes with political submission is clearly irrational as it was an accepted procedure of foreign relations at that time. Such assertions would put, absurdly, the histories of Vietnam, Japan and Korean history through the Joseon Dynasty as part of Chinese legacy," says Gong Seok-gu, a history professor at Hanbat University."Chinese scholars have ignored the essence of Goguryeo`s relationship with the Chinese dynasties and the dynamic shifts between concordance and conflict." China`s claim over the legacy of Goguryeo, as well as other Manchuria-based states such as Gojoseon (dismantled in 108 B.C.) and Balhae (698-926), are not new. The Chinese government defined their concept of national history in the early 1980s under their ideological motto of "a unified multi-ethnic country" which regards the histories of all the ethnic groups that live or lived within their current borders as part of the Chinese legacy.The doctrine provides the ideological framework for China`s policies in governing ethnic minorities, where ethnic diversity is considered the most critical obstacle in forging national unity. Currently there are 56 ethnic groups identified by the Chinese government. The majority Han Chinese make up 92 percent of the population while the remaining 55 groups inhabit approximately 60 percent of the territory.Considering the large community of ethnic Koreans in the northeastern provinces and around the North Korean border, securing sovereignty over the heritage of ancient Manchuria has always been of keen interest for Chinese authorities.Before the 1990s, Chinese academics focused on Balhae - which acquired much of Goguryeo`s territory - and on separating its history from the Korean heritage. Ironically, the arguments were centered at proving Balhae`s discontinuity with Goguryeo, which most Chinese scholars of the time regarded as part of Korean history, at least for the period after Goguryeo`s capital was moved from Guknaeseong (current day Jian) to Pyongyang in 427.Such theories were abandoned when the Chinese focus shifted to Goguryeo in the following decade. Critics point out that the series of robbery attempts on the Goguryeo murals in the mid 1990s, later revealed to have been carried out by ethnic Koreans in China backed by South Korean nationalists, were one of the factors that triggered Beijing`s sensitive response.South Korean scholars regard the Northeast Asian Project as China`s most ambitious attempt yet to secure the historical sovereignty of ancient Manchuria. The Northeast Asian project consists of nine themes with most studies directly concerning the Korean Peninsula, such as the "The Study of Gojoseon, Goguryeo and Balhae," "The Political Condition of the Korean Peninsula and the Possible Influence on the Northeastern Border" and "The Study of Northeast Asian Ethnic Groups." Political motivation is clearly revealed in the words of the official founding declaration of the Northeast Asian Project which reads: "We are determined to correct the historical facts manipulated in the hands of our neighboring countries in their attempt to take advantage of Northeast Asia`s newly established global status." "The Northeast Asian Project, being systematically pushed by a government agency, should be regarded as more alarming than Japan`s distortion of history textbooks," says Korea University`s Choi Gwang-shik."China`s attempts to claim Goguryeo, Gojoseon and Balhae as part of their national legacy will shed 1,000 years from Korean history and limit its spatial heritage to the southern part of the Korean Peninsula."  The majority of scholars, including Choi, agree with the public sentiment in demanding the government take a firmer stance against Beijing`s supposed attempts at "distorting history."   Voices of caution  However, a number of critics point out that the current conflict over national history is an indicator that the academic culture of both countries is still held captive by the reasoning of the colonial era, where the asserted image of the nation and nation-state held ascendancy over the consciousness of logic and experience.The concept of the nation is a modern invention - widely defined as a politically connected and motivated unit sharing the primal elements of language, territory and ethnicity - that emerged following the replacement of feudal hierarchy with political solidarity and ideological motivation as elements of social structure. Applying the concept of history to the pre-modern ages as part of the building of a nation-state is an absurd argument, they argue.Considering China`s political motivation, academic investments, access to the historical sites and the fact that their argument is buttressed by their current border, it is questionable whether the Korean academia can gain anything from verbal exchanges and by relying mainly on the subjective notion of ethnic nationality."We basically have a case of nationalistic self-assertion on the part of China`s government-directed scholars, but we should not forget that the claims that Goguryeo was a `Korean kingdom` also hardly contain any pretense of academic exactitude," says Oslo University`s Vladimir Tikhonov, a scholar specializing in ancient Korean history, widely known by his penname Pak No-ja in Korea."Instead of putting forward nationalistic emotions, Korean academia could simply make a calm analysis of the underlying logic of Chinese nationalism and give the public a clear understanding that nationalistic claims are not history but just a deeply flawed modern interpretation of collective memory," he said.According to Tikhonov, there was a discussion between overseas Korean studies specialists on the subject, with the dominant understanding for the basis of China`s intentions found in worries about the future of the North Korean regime and possible future claims to the Dongbei territory, northeastern China, from the Korean side."My guess is that some toning down of the `Manchu neun uri ttang` (Manchuria belongs to us) voices in Seoul will help to calm down some of China`s fears," he said.Seoul`s response  The criticism that both countries share a flawed paradigm of national history seems largely lost amid the fierce public reaction to the subject.Civic activists and academic groups are holding rallies almost daily at the Chinese Embassy in downtown Seoul, while, in less than three weeks, over 1 million civilians signed a nationwide petition denouncing Bejing`s supposed distortion of historical facts. The civic group "History World" succeeded in convincing more than 20,000 Internet users to bombard UNESCO and ICOMOS Web-sites with e-mails demanding the international organizations recognize China`s "historical conspiracies." Despite the heated public sentiment, the government continues to maintain its reserved stance, preferring to limit the Goguryeo controversy to an academic matter while remaining on guard against the issue spiraling into a diplomatic dispute.In a meeting presided over by Prime Minister Goh Kun last week, the government announced plans to establish a state-run research center for Goguryeo studies with an annual budget of 10 billion won ($8.3 million)."There is a widespread sense of agreement among government officials that the issue should be resolved through academic discussions between the two countries and not develop into a clash of national sentiments," said Park Heung-shin, the director general of the cultural affairs bureau at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade.By Kim Tong-hyung    (thkim@heraldm.com)

title: [번역]Consumer confidence rose in Nov. 11월 소비심리 상승
content: Korea`s consumer expectation index soared to a nine-month high in November, suggesting consumers are slowly preparing to open their wallets, the National Statistical Office said yesterday.The consumer expectation index, a measure of consumer sentiment toward prospects for the economy and their future spending plans, rose to 94.6 points last month, up from 91.5 in October.Based on a survey of 2,000 urban households, the index rose for the second consecutive month to its highest figure since February when the index stood at 96.1, the statistics office said."Consumer sentiment is seen to be improving despite the falling value of real estate and other assets, but it`s too early to predict a solid upturn as the index is still below 100," said Jeon Shin-ae from of the office`s statistics analysis division.A reading below 100 indicates that consumers who expect the economy and living standards to worsen in the coming six months outnumber those who expect an improvement.Also last month, the sub-index measuring future spending plans surged to 100.9 from 98.2 in October, rising above the 100-mark for the first time since May, to suggest that consumers are becoming more willing to increase their spending.As evidence of the improved consumer sentiment, the government pointed out that the combined sales for November at the nation`s top three department stores, Lotte Department Store Co., Hyundai Department Store and Shinsegae Co., fell only 6 percent, the lowest drop in three months.The Finance Ministry expects the upcoming holiday spending spree to help boost sales to bring the declining figure to only 1.7 percent.Meanwhile, due to recent government measures to stabilize the inflated real estate market, consumers are less optimistic about housing and real estate conditions than they were six months ago, but maintain a largely favorable stance toward stocks and bonds.(jemmie@heraldm.com)   11월 한국의 소비자기대지수가 9개월만에 최고를 기록해 소비자들이 서서히 지갑을 열 준비를 하고 있는 것으로 보인다고 어제 통계청이 발표했다.향후 경기전망에 대한 소비심리와 소비지출 계획을 측정하는 소비자기대지수가 10월의 91.5에서 지난 달에는 94.6으로 상승했다.2,000여 도시가구를 대상으로 실시한 조사에서 이 지수는 2개월째 상승을 계속하면서 96.1을 기록했던 지난 2월 이후 최고를 기록했다.“부동산과 기타 자산의 가치가 하락하는 가운데서도 소비심리는 개선되고 있는 것 같다. 하지만 지수가 아직도 100 이하이기 때문에 본격적인 상승을 점치기는 아직 이르다”고 통계청 전신애 통계분석과장이 말했다.지수가 100 이하면 향후 6개월간의 경기와 생활수준이 더 나빠질 것으로 생각하는 사람의 수가 좋아질 것으로 생각하는 사람의 수보다 많다는 것을 의미한다.그뿐 아니라 지난달에는 미래의 소비지출계획을 측정하는 하위지수가 10월의 98.2에서 100.9로 올라 5월 이후 처음으로 100선을 넘어섬으로써 소비자들이 소비지출을 더 늘리려 한다는 것을 시사했다.정부는 소비심리가 개선되었다는 증거로서 11월에 국내 3대 백화점 즉, 롯데백화점과 현대현대점 그리고 신세계의 전체 매출의 감소가 6퍼센트에 그쳐 지난 3개월 이래 감소폭이 가장 줄어 들었다는 점을 지적했다.재경부는 명절을 맞아 소비지출이 진작되어 판매가 늘어나면 감소치는 1.7퍼센트 정도에 그칠 것으로 기대하고 있다.한편 최근 과열된 부동산시장을 안정시키려는 정부의 대책으로 인해 소비자들은 6개월 전에 비해 주택과 부동산에 대해서는 덜 낙관적이었으나 주식과 채권에 대해서는 대체적으로 선호하는 입장을 견지하고 있다.

title: Ahn Cheol-soo gains momentum as contender against Park Geun-hye
content: [한겨레] A series of missteps by the ruling party has led Busan residents to search for a perceived political outsiderBy Kim Kwang-soo, Busan Correspondent and Seong Yeon-cheol　　“Most of the people I met over Chuseok were talking about Ahn Cheol-soo and Park Geun-hye,” reported a first-term ruling Grand National Party (GNP) lawmaker from Busan.Popular sentiment is roiling in Busan and South Gyeongsang Province. Angry with the ruling party over the cancellation of plans to build a new airport in the region, a recent savings bank scandal, and an escalating labor-management controversy at Hanjin Heavy Industries and Construction (HHIC), residents have been seeking out alternatives, as witnessed with the rapid rise of local figures like Ahn, dean of the Seoul National University Graduate School of Convergence Science and Technology, and Roh Moo-hyun Foundation Chairman Moon Jae-in.The “Ahn phenomenon” is one element of the Chuseok sentiment reported by ruling and opposition party politicians from the region. Main opposition Democratic Party (DP) Supreme Council member Kim Young-choon, who is currently gearing up for a run in the Busanjin-A district for next year’s general election, said Wednesday, “Nearly everyone I have met has talked about how great Ahn Cheol-soo is.”“I traveled around traditional markets and downtown streets listening to what people have to say, and I met a lot of people who only recently learned that Ahn Cheol-soo is from Busan, as well as many who did not know about it,” Kim added. “But it is clear enough that there is an ‘Ahn phenomenon’ going on.”“More and more people are saying that not only the current opposition but the newly emerging figures as well should join forces to develop an alternative,” Kim reported.Ahn’s origins in Busan appear to have made him seem like a more realistic prospect to locals.“It does seem like people are more positive about Ahn than others because he is from Busan,” said a first-term Busan-area GNP lawmaker about the popular sentiments expressed over the extended holiday. “But I do not think they are able to agree for certain yet about whether he is presidential material.”A number of Busan residents expressed hopes for a new figure that is not part of the political establishment. Many also seemed interested in the fact that Ahn posed a threat to the GNP and its former chairwoman and leading presidential contender Park Geun-hye. An opinion poll conducted on Sept. 6 and 7 by the Dong-A Ilbo and Korea Research had Ahn leading Park by 42.5 percent to 37.7 percent in the Busan/South Gyeongsang region.GNP Lawmaker Lee Jin-bok said, “A lot of people said it was really unpleasant to see the ruling party in upheaval over the Ahn Cheol-soo phenomenon.”Moon Sung-hyun, former minor opposition Democratic Labor Party (DLP) chairman and current DLP local Changwon committee chairman, said, “In Changwon and elsewhere in South Gyeongsang, there have been clear signs of change, with people saying they are not merely going to vote for their party’s candidate.”“Quite a few of the people I met over Chuseok said, ‘Please rally behind someone upstanding and intelligent as a consolidated opposition candidate. If you do, we will not hesitate [to vote for this person],’” Moon added.Busan residents differed in their expectations as to how far the Ahn phenomenon would reach. GNP lawmakers who traveled the region for the last Chuseok before next April’s general election were generally skeptical in their analysis. Some predicted that the Ahn phenomenon would run its course and that the stable regional composition and the GNP’s organizational strength would prevail in the election.“I think it is like pro baseball, where Busan citizens are always saying Lotte is a bad team, but they are always cheering on the ‘Busan Seagulls’ at the stadium,” a GNP lawmaker said.Some analysts said the Ahn phenomenon has actually rallied ruling party supporters in the Busan/South Gyeongsang region.But Kim Young-choon cautioned, “The Ahn Cheol-soo phenomenon is an expression of distrust and rejection of the political establishment, and at the moment there is a strong sense of rejection of the GNP in the Busan/South Gyeongsang area, though not really enough for people to come out in support of other opposition parties.”　　　　Please direct questions or comments to [englishhani@hani.co.kr]　　  공식 SNS [통하니] [트위터] [미투데이] | 구독신청 [한겨레신문] [한겨레21]Copyrights ⓒ 한겨레신문사, 무단전재 및 재배포 금지<한겨레는 한국온라인신문협회(www.kona.or.kr)의 디지털뉴스이용규칙에 따른 저작권을 행사합니다.>

title: ‘Maverick’ Hong Joon-pyo elected chairman of GNP
content: [한겨레] Hong faces significant challenges in uniting GNP factions and preparing for next year’s general electionsBy Shin Seung-keun, Staff Writer　　Lawmaker Hong Joon-pyo, 57, was elected as the new chairman of the Grand National Party on June 4. The ruling Grand National Party (GNP) held its national convention at Seoul’s Olympic Gymnastics Arena, electing Hong as chairman and Yoo Seung-min, Na Kyung-won, Won Hee-ryong and Nam Kyung-pil as members of its Supreme Council. Hong presented himself as a “bold chairman,” but it remains to be seen if the GNP will experience smooth sailing now that he is at the helm. The tasks faced by the man who has been brought from the periphery and placed in the center are tough, and include brining harmony between party factions and re-establishing the party’s policy line, while leading the party through next year’s general and presidential elections. Hong received comparatively even numbers of votes from the Lee Myung-bak faction and Park Geun-hye faction within the party. His path of individuality, whereby he belongs to no particular faction, drew attention to him as an alternative at a time when the party was gripped by a sense of crisis at the prospect that continued factional conflict within it in advance of elections could spell the end. Analysis also suggests that Hong received many second votes from the Lee faction old guard, its unity weakened, and from the Park faction and younger factions, which wanted to prevent a recovery of the Lee faction forces.The pro-working class policies Hong produced as chairman of a GNP Special Committee on working class policies, even amid criticism from conservatives of “haphazard populism,” reinforced his image as a reformist, a phenomenon that fell into place with the party’s general internal trend of reform. It seems that Hong’s experience as GNP floor leader and Supreme Council member, and his attempts to differentiate himself from other candidates by presenting himself as a “commander in chief with the power to fight,” proved persuasive to a GNP support base that feels uneasy about next year’s elections.Hong, who entered the world of politics in 1996 as a lawmaker with the New Korea Party, was known, together with minister Lee Jae-oh and Gyeonggi Province governor Kim Moon-soo, as a “sniper” and was at the vanguard of attacks against the ruling party. He was then re-elected four times, while failing to be selected by his party during attempts to run for election as Seoul mayor in 2006 and a presidential candidate in 2007. Following the change of government in 2008, Hong became the ruling party’s first parliamentary floor leader, before losing a party leadership bid to Ahn Sang-soo at last year’s GNP convention, by a margin of 462 votes. Since then, he has been chairman of the Special Committee on Working Class Policy and built an independent political realm, calling himself a “progressive conservative.” There is a high possibility that Hong will increase the pace of working class policy. In a press conference after his election, he stated, “As party leader, I will continue the work I did as chairman of the special committee on working class policy.”While chairman of the committee, Hong took a leading role in creating a revision to a subcontractor law to prevent big businesses from snatching technology and patents from small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and a revision to a lending law to place an upper limit on loan interest.“Now that I am party leader, I will seek the advice of many people and push ahead once again with new housing policies and a lowering of interest rates in the lending industry, which were passed in an irregular manner [from 39 percent to 30 percent],” he said. Hong has likened the relationship between the GNP and Cheong Wa Dae to an hourglass, saying, “At first, all power is concentrated with Cheong Wa Dae, but, as time passes, the power to connect with public sentiment falls down to the party.” Some take the view, however, that a clear lead from Hong could lead to friction with the GNP floor delegation or Cheong Wa Dae (the presidential office in South Korea or Blue House). At the recent party convention, Hong expressed opposition to free school lunches, calling them “tax meals,” and revealed policy differences with floor leader Hwang Woo-yea’s new faction by stating that further corporate tax cuts should be restricted to SMEs.“If he makes policies only according to what he thinks, it will lead to conflict not only with the GNP floor delegation but with Cheong Wa Dae too,” said one first-term Seoul lawmaker.During a press conference the same day, Hong said, “Suddenly coming up with policies without consulting the government is the kind of thing the opposition party would do. It is when the government does not respond to the demands of the party that the party makes the decisions and moves forward.” Hong’s fate depends on next April’s general election. If he is unable to solve the problem of nominations, over which party factional interests are divided, his powers of leadership will inevitably fall sharply. Hong declared loudly that his first task upon assuming leadership was to “destroy factions,” but he needs to find a compromise amid animosity from the Lee faction and misgivings from the Park faction, which suspects he is playing a political game of his own. If the GNP loses the election, an early end for Hong will be almost inevitable.“Reversing anti-GNP sentiment by the time of the general election is too great a task for a single party leader,” said one lawmaker.Hong said, “I will protect not only former party leader Park Geun-hye but also other strong GNP presidential candidates to ensure they do not get hurt.” 　　Please direct questions or comments to [englishhani@hani.co.kr]　　 공식 SNS [통하니] [트위터] [미투데이] | 구독신청 [한겨레신문] [한겨레21]Copyrights ⓒ 한겨레신문사, 무단전재 및 재배포 금지<한겨레는 한국온라인신문협회(www.kona.or.kr)의 디지털뉴스이용규칙에 따른 저작권을 행사합니다.>

title: FMD dents demand for Korean beef, pork
content: Korean beef promotion event is held in Suwon, Gyeonggi Province. (Yonhap News) About half of Korean consumers cut spending on beef and pork due to concerns over foot-and-mouth disease, which has spread nationwide since November and caused significant damage, a survey conducted by Nielsen Company showed Tuesday.The survey was conducted on 1,000 internet users in major cities in Korea including Seoul, Daejeon, Daegu, Gwangju and Busan from Feb. 25 to March 4.About 49 percent of respondents said they decreased local beef and pork consumption while 49.5 percent said they bought local beef and pork as usual.The FMD has also dampened consumer sentiment even among those who know that FMD has no effect on human beings. Among them, 46 percent said they had no intention of buying beef and pork. Among those who incorrectly believed that FMD could affect human beings, 65.3 percent didn’t intend to buy these meats.Just over 44 percent of customers said they would substitute beef and pork with other meat such as chicken and duck. About 33 percent said they will not buy local beef and pork for a while and 22.5 percent said they will purchase imported meats.“The survey indicates consumer sentiment is down due to the FMD spread. As local beef and pork prices rose due to decrease in supply, the price gap between local beef and pork and imported meats led customers to choose the imported. We need to recover price competitiveness of local meats as well as to promote campaign to reduce public concerns on FMD,” said an analysis at the research company.The South Korean government lowered the alert level for FMD on March 24 as not a single outbreak was reported since Feb. 26. The FMD epidemic resulted in the culling of more than 34 million cows and pigs, causing about 3 trillion won ($2.6 billion) in losses, local news reports said.By Lee Woo-young (wylee@heraldm.com)

title: Park Won-soon pledges change following by-election victory
content: [한겨레] Strong support from voters in their 20s, 30s and 40s propelled Park as the election was widely discussed on TwitterBy Lee Tae-hee, Staff Writer　　Unified opposition candidate Park Won-soon defeated ruling Grand National Party candidate Na Kyung-won by a considerable margin in the Oct. 26 Seoul mayoral by-election. Park took 53.4% of the votes cast, beating Na’s 46.2% by 7.2 percentage points. “The people have secured a victory over the establishment, and the election has beaten an outdated generation,” said Park after his victory had been confirmed. “Universal welfare will be the engine that creates a Seoul centered on people.” In comparison to the past three presidential elections, the 7.2% difference between Park and Na is sufficient to go down as a trouncing defeat in the GNP’s history. During the 1997 presidential election, the difference between Kim Dae-jung and Lee Hoi-chang was 3.9 percentage points, while that between Roh Moo-hyun and Lee Hoi-chang in 2002 was 6.3. The difference between Lee Myung-bak and Chung Dong-young at the 2007 presidential election was 28.7 percentage points. This election has confirmed that public sentiment in Seoul has turned its back on the GNP. When all votes were counted on Wednesday night, Na only stood ahead of Park in the three southern districts of Gangnam, Seocho and Songpa, and in the Yongsan District. Immediately after the election, analysis of exit polls by three major broadcasters according to age group suggested that Park received a flood of votes from those in their 20s, 30s and 40s. His support from these age groups was overwhelming, coming to 69.3% among those in their 20s, 75.8% among those in their 30s and 66.8% among those in their 40s. Na enjoyed the support of 56.5% of voters in their 50s and 69.2% of those in their 60s. The GNP’s sound defeat in the Seoul mayoral by-election has increased the likelihood of internal disputes for the party, including demands for reform from GNP lawmakers representing the metropolitan region. Former GNP Chairwoman Park Geun-hye, who supported Na, also appears to have taken a considerable blow. It is highly probable, on the other hand, that the by-election result has boosted the standing of Seoul National University Graduate School of Convergence Science and Technology Dean Ahn Chul-soo, who visited Park’s election headquarters two days before the by-election and reconfirmed his support for Park, as a leading prospective presidential election candidate. Park’s victory is also expected to function as a catalyst for unification among opposition parties and groups, given that it is the result of a grand collection of progressive opposition parties such as the Democratic Party, the Democratic Labor Party and the People’s Participation Party, and elements of civil society centered on “innovation and unity.” Voter turnout for Wednesday’s Seoul mayoral by-election was 48.6%. The average turnout at the re- and by-elections for 11 local authority heads across the country was 45.9%. The GNP won eight of the local authority head elections. The DP won against independent candidates at two elections in North Jeolla Province. The Oct. 26 by-election also proved the power of social network services, symbolized by Twitter. The Twitter-related term “voting evidence shot” of voters taking a photo of themselves at polling stations has now become established as a leading political term. As of 8 p.m. on the day of the by-elections, the number of tweets containing the word “vote” or “evidence shot” was counted at 173,011. This amounted to 11.3% of the total of 1,531,337 tweets during the time period. It represented a huge leap in the use of these words on Oct. 24 (33,472, or 1.24% of the total) and Oct. 25 (60,533, or 2.65%).“The appeal of the term ‘evidence shot’ can be understood when its use is compared to that of Steve Jobs’ name on Oct. 5, the day of Jobs‘ death, when only 3.5% of tweets mentioned ’Steve Jobs,‘” said expert social media analysis company Gruter. The number of tweets mentioning “vote” or “evidence shot” on Wednesday stood at 10,335 at 7 a.m., then increased to 13,738 during the next hour, then again to 14,189 between 8 a.m. and 9 a.m. After 10 a.m., it fell to 9,800. At 4 p.m. it was 10,881; after which it rose again sharply to 14,212 at 5 p.m., 16,321 at 6 p.m. and 14,038 at 7 p.m. This corresponded exactly to the voting trend among workers in their 20s, 30s and 40s, who voted more before work in the morning and after work in the evening.　　　　Please direct questions or comments to [englishhani@hani.co.kr]　   공식 SNS [통하니] [트위터] [미투데이] | 구독신청 [한겨레신문] [한겨레21]Copyrights ⓒ 한겨레신문사, 무단전재 및 재배포 금지<한겨레는 한국온라인신문협회(www.kona.or.kr)의 디지털뉴스이용규칙에 따른 저작권을 행사합니다.>

title: Sales forecast for KOSPI-listed firms drops
content: Revised estimate comes after reduction in government’s growth projection The average level of revenue KOSPI-listed firms are expected to generate in the second half of the year dropped, stock analysis said Tuesday, raising concerns over a slower economic growth on weaker consumption and waning exports.The estimation of operating profits for 115 listed companies on KOSPI for the July-December period fell to a total of 47.68 trillion won ($44.7 billion) this week, from 48.17 trillion won of January, according to analysis by FN Guide, a leading online financial information provider. The projections fell for 58 companies of the total analyzed.The drop in the revenue forecast reflects declining growth projections of major exporters of Asia’s fourth-largest economy. This darkening of projections comes as the government last week cut the growth forecast and raised the inflation outlook on weakening consumption and commodity price volatility. The won’s rise to a 34-month high against the dollar Tuesday added concern for exporters, which raised speculation that Seoul will tolerate a stronger won in the coming months to tame inflation at the expense of losses by exporters.“Slowing global demand and price volatilities of commodity imports could dampen performance of major exporters here. They could drive general investor sentiment down and slow the economy for the next six months,” Yoo Byung-kyu, a director at Hyundai Research Institute said.The operating profit estimated for Samsung Electronics in the July-December period fell from 9.47 trillion won in January to 8.84 trillion won this week, down 11.1 percent. The projection for LG Electronics also fell from 795.4 billion won to 639.8 trillion won in the same period.Forecast for Korean Air and Asiana Airlines dropped by 232.5 billion won and 94.8 billion won each in the same period.The government expects the economy to grow 4.5 percent this year, down from the 5 percent projected earlier. It said inflation will likely hit 4 percent, upping its forecast from 3 percent after the Consumer Price Index exceeded Seoul’s target range of 2 to 3 percent for the past half a year.By Cynthia J. Kim (cynthiak@heraldm.com)

title: Seoul stocks rebound amid hopes of a U.S. stimulus deal
content: The closing figures for the Kospi and the dollar price against the won are displayed in a trading room at Hana Bank in Jung District, central Seoul, on Wednesday. The benchmark Kospi rose 14.97 points, or 0.54 percent, to close at 2,771.79. [YONHAP]       Stocks ended their two-day losing streak Wednesday, backed by optimism over the U.S. stimulus talks and positive reports related to U.S. biotech company Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine candidate. The won fell against the dollar.    The benchmark Kospi rose 14.97 points, or 0.54 percent, to close at 2,771.79.    Trading volume was high at about 1.1 billion shares worth some 13.3 trillion won ($12.2 billion), with gainers outnumbering losers 542 to 284.    Foreigners sold a net 44 billion won, while institutions bought a net 198 billion won. Retail investors offloaded a net 138 billion won.    The Kospi rebounded largely on rosy expectations that the world's largest economy would hasten a fresh stimulus deal before its previous benefits expire by the end of the year, analysts said.    Large caps advanced, following U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's comment that lawmakers would have to stay in Washington until the $748 billion relief deal is clinched.    Investor sentiment was also boosted by reports that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration confirmed Moderna's vaccine candidate to be safe and effective in its preliminary analysis.    But the Kospi's gains eased as Korea added a daily record high of 1,078 more Covid-19 cases. Health authorities said the current second-highest social distancing measures have failed to curb the virus spread, hinting it would not hesitate to implement the toughest Level 3 if necessary.    "In today's session, local stocks seemed affected by bits of separate events and the investors' responses to them," said Bookook Securities researcher Lee Won.    Samsung Electronics closed unchanged at 73,800 won while chipmaker SK hynix also finished flat at 117,500 won.    Pharmaceutical firm Samsung Biologics gained 0.88 percent to 807,000 won, but Celltrion shed 1.81 percent to 353,500 won.    Internet portal giant Naver rose 0.88 percent to 285,500 won, with its rival Kakao moving up 0.27 percent to 372,000 won.    Chemical maker LG Chem jumped 2.25 percent to 819,000 won, and rechargeable battery maker Samsung SDI increased 2.17 percent to 564,000 won.    Hyundai Motor, the country's largest automaker, advanced 0.8 percent to 190,000 won, and steelmaker Posco added 0.93 percent to 271,500 won.    The Kosdaq rose 8.38 points, or 0.9 percent, to close at 939.65.    The local currency closed at 1,094.0 won per dollar, up 0.7 won from the previous session's close.    Bond prices, which move inversely to yields, closed mixed. The return on the three-year bond lost 0.3 basis points to close at 0.988 percent, and the return on the 10-year bond added 1.7 basis points to close at 0.91 percent.      BY CHEA SARAH, YONHAP   [chea.sarah@joongang.co.kr]

title: CU finds craft beer success through unexpected partnerships
content: Convenience store chain CU’s 7Brau Gompyo Wheat Beer, left, and Muke’s Soft IPA. According to BGF Retail, operator of convenience store chain CU, sales of craft beer between January and October shot up 546 percent compared to the same period a year earlier. [BGF RETAIL]     Korea’s beer industry is booming with the rising popularity of domestic craft beers largely thanks to the growing popularity of homsul, or drinking at home, amid the prolonged coronavirus pandemic.     According to BGF Retail, operator of convenience store chain CU, sales of craft beers between January and October shot up 546 percent compared to the same period a year earlier.     The popularity is led by a series of conceptual craft beers that the convenience store launched in collaboration with breweries and distinctive brands such as a well-known flour company and a shoe polish company.     CU in May teamed up with brewery 7Brau and flour company Daehan Flour Mills to launch a craft beer called 7Brau Gompyo Wheat Beer, commonly known as Gompyo beer. Gom means bear in Korean, and the flour brand is known for its distinctive bear logo.     The first 100,000 cans of Gompyo beer sold out just three days after its introduction, with 300,000 cans sold in a week, according to BGF Retail. Five months after its release, more than one million units have been sold.     Gompyo beer ranked No. 1 in the craft beer category and made the top 10 domestic beer brands by the number of units sold in less than a week after its release.     Unlike other craft beers that are usually popular among people in their 20s and 30s, Gompyo beer was also popular with people in their 40s and 50s — largely due to the Daehan Flour Mills' bear on the label, printed in a retro style that appealed to older drinkers.     According to BGF Retail, roughly 81.7 percent of its craft beer sales came from people in their 20s or 30s last year, while people in their 40s accounted for only 5.6 percent. In the case of Gompyo beer, people in their 40s made up some 14.3 percent.     The Malpyo Dark Beer launched on Oct. 8 in collaboration with Squeeze Brewery and Malpyo Industries. [BGF RETAIL]     CU on Aug. 6 launched another craft beer line Muke’s Soft IPA. The beer was made by North Chungcheong-based Platinum Craft Brewing Company and the popular webtoon “Tiger” from Naver Webtoon.         Muke's Soft IPA is a session IPA beer with less than 5 percent alcohol content. The can features the main character of the webtoon, a baby tiger named Muke.     BGF Retail said it aims to target "funsumers" — a portmanteau of “fun” and “consumer” — describing consumers who consider fun as one of the key factors when purchasing products.      According to analysis by CU, the number of people mentioning webtoons and beer at the same time on social media in July soared by 22.4 percent compared to the same period a year earlier.     “We came up with a craft beer lineup collaborating with a webtoon for the first time in the industry targeting customers who enjoy [small and distinct happiness] by drinking a can of beer while reading webtoons after work,” said Lee.     As well as the success of the bear and the tiger, CU also tried a horse. This time, it teamed up with Gangwon-based Squeeze Brewery and a shoe polish company Malpyo Industries. Mal means horse in Korean.     Shoe polish from Malpyo Industries has been a steady seller for nearly 50 years since its introduction in 1967.     The can of beer was designed with the Malpyo Industries logo, an image of a horse, as well as the font that is very familiar to Korean consumers. Malpyo Dark Beer in October ranked fourth in terms of sales, surpassing other popular imported beers such as Qingdao.     “As more consumers are showing interests in craft beer, it has been establishing a strong presence in the beer market with unique designs and tastes,” said Lee Seung-taek, a merchandiser at BGF Retail. “We anticipate that the popularity of Malpyo Dark Beer is likely to grow further during the winter.”     CU's recently launched craft beer called Our Ale. The convenience store teamed up with Jeju Beer and Hyundai Card. [BGF RETAIL]     But animals were not the only focus of CU's craft beer campaign.       The convenience store recently cooperated with Jeju Beer and Hyundai Card to release a craft beer called Our Ale. The three companies jointly worked for one and a half years to come up with the new beer.     Our Ale is themed around a Jeju Island myth about a goddess of immense size and strength named Seoulmundaehalmang, who created the island by shoveling mud from the seabed. Some ancient records refer to this goddess as Samandugo or Seonmago. Halmang means grandmother in Jeju's dialect.     The design of the beer describes the goddess by using the color of blue, green and red, which respectively describe the sea, volcanoes and sun.     The craft beer lineup at CU has doubled this year compared to last year.     According to CU, the domestic craft beer market, which was worth some 88 billion won ($80.7 million) last year, is expected to exceed 200 billion won by the end of the year.     The anti-Japanese sentiment has been another driving force. Korean customers who continue to boycott Japanese products, including popular Japanese beer such as Asahi and Sapporo, are turning their eyes to domestic beers.     In 2017, when the popularity of imported beers shot up, roughly 60 percent of the beer market was dominated by imported beers. Of the remaining 40 percent taken up by domestic beers, craft beer only took some 1.9 percent. With the fast-growing popularity of craft beer, now it takes 9.5 percent — a fivefold increase compared to 2017.     Sales of craft beer at CU significantly jumped since July 2019 when the boycott against Japanese consumer goods reached its peak. Sales of craft beer during the July to December period last year rose 241.5 percent compared to the same period the previous year.     Other convenience store chains are scrambling to catch up.     A model promotes 7-Eleven’s Whelk Beer, which it recently launched in collaboration with Satellite Brewing and Yoo Dong, best known for its popular canned sea whelk product. [7-ELEVEN]     7-Eleven recently collaborated with Yoo Dong, best known for its canned whelks, to introduce a Vienna Lager-style Whelk Beer. Satellite Brewing, which is known for owning the most craft beer recipes in the country, is in charge of making the beer.     It doesn’t taste like whelks, but targets people who enjoy drinking beer while eating whelks, one of the popular side dishes that Koreans love to eat while drinking.     7-Eleven’s craft beer sales also saw a sharp increase this year. Sales in the January-to-October period spiked 492.4 percent compared to the same period a year ago. The number of brands on offer also grew to 11 from last year’s five.     “The craft beer market has been growing as it is easier to achieve collaboration than other beers,” said Lee Woo-chang, a merchandiser who is in charge of alcohol at 7-Eleven. “We anticipate that craft beer can play a critical role in the sales rise as it is highly valuable in the convenience store market.”     GS25, another convenience store, has been selling a series of landmark-themed craft beers from brewery Kabrew.     GS Retail, operator of GS25, earlier this year started selling a craft beer called Namsan. Namsan Seoul Tower is one of the famous landmarks representing Seoul, the capital city of Korea. It is the fifth beer in the convenience store’s craft beer series.     Earlier beers in the series were Gwanghwamun, Gyeongbokgung — both representing landmarks in Seoul — and Jeju Baekrokdam and Seongsan Ilchulbong, which are both landmarks in Jeju.     According to GS25, of its total canned beer sales, craft beers accounted for 2.1 percent in 2018 and 7 percent in 2019 — but rose to 8.8 percent this year.     BY CHEA SARAH   [chea.sarah@joongang.co.kr]

title: President’s approval ratings rise above 50 percent
content: [한겨레] The rise has created tension with the GNP, which believes it should be central with upcoming presidential electionsAhn Chang-hyun, Staff Writer　　　New Year’s opinion polls carried out by different press outlets generally showed President Lee Myung-bak enjoying governance support ratings of over 50 percent. The only rating under 50 percent was found in an SBS survey, which showed a support rate of 48.2 percent. In other polls conducted by Munhwa Broadcasting Company (MBC), the Hankyoreh, Korean Broadcasting System (KBS), and the Hankook Ilbo, his rating was above 50 percent, at 53.3 percent, 51.8 percent, 50.9 percent, and 50.1 percent, respectively. This marks a substantial rise from his previous ratings, which hovered in the mid 40 percent range. While the majority expressed support for the president, the atmosphere was less welcoming for members of the ruling Grand National Party (GNP). Indeed, some GNP members were suspecting a support rating bubble due to the large gulf between the high support ratings for President Lee and the negative popular sentiment they experienced themselves.A first-term lawmaker from the Seoul area said Monday that there was “a difference of more than 20 percentage points between the polling figures and the outcome in last year’s local elections.”“It does not seem like the opinions of the voters you meet in localities are captured in the opinion polls,” the lawmaker said.Analysts said this differential stems not only from the fundamental limitations of polling using home telephones but also from the different meanings carried by surveys on support for the president. Observers noted that the support rating figures conflate opinions such as “he is working hard” and “he has not made any major mistake.” Indeed, polling experts said that the high support figures for the president include “imaginary numbers.” In their view, the fact that President Lee is enjoying high support ratings entering the fourth year of his term, in contrast with previous presidents, stems from fundamental differences in the way they started out. In other words, whereas previous presidents enjoyed high support early on in their terms only to see them fall along a “staircase” or “L” pattern, President Lee was able to rise along the “staircase” model because he started with support ratings down around 10 percent due to the candlelight vigil demonstrations over the unilateral decision to resume U.S. beef imports.The analysis suggests that factors working in the president’s favor include the fact that he presented himself the “economy president” and was therefore not subject to high expectations in other areas, that he has maintained a distance from potentially controversial political issues, and that no convincing alternative has presented itself among the opposition.“Right now, opinion polls are assessments of governance, so they also include the sense of ‘things are better than before,’” said Yoon Hee-woong, head of the research analysis office for the Korea Society Opinion Institute. “It is the same principle as there being a clear difference between saying that a particular baseball player does a ‘good job’ and being a fan of that player.”The emphasis on “party-centered governance” from the GNP leadership since the start of the year also appears to be a continuation of this perception. During a meeting of the GNP’s Supreme Council Monday, Chairman Ahn Sang-soo said, “The administration must bear in mind that the party should be at the center of major policy, as this is the year ahead of the general and presidential elections.” “Even if we do cooperate with the administration where cooperation is needed, we will provide a thorough check where checks are warranted,” Ahn added.Also at the meeting, Supreme Council member Chung Doo-un said that 2011 was “effectively the last year for the reelection of the GNP.”“The party needs to engage in direct governance,” Chung said.A high-ranking party official said, “Ours is a different story from Brazil, where former president Lula was enjoying support ratings of over 80 percent.”“The next election is something the party is doing, and to win it we will need to step over whoever is in the way, even if it is the Cheong Wa Dae,” the official added. 　　Please direct questions or comments to [englishhani@hani.co.kr]세상을 보는 정직한 눈 <한겨레>  [한겨레신문 구독 | 한겨레21 구독]공식 SNS 계정: 트위터 www.twitter.com/hanitweet / 미투데이 http://me2day.net/hankyorehⓒ 한겨레신문사, 무단전재 및 재배포 금지<한겨레는 한국온라인신문협회(www.kona.or.kr)의 디지털뉴스이용규칙에 따른 저작권을 행사합니다.>

title: KDI cuts 2021 growth outlook, citing sluggish domestic recovery
