These developments have contributed materially to the drop in demand for housing this year.  Without a doubt, they also have caused significant hardship for many individuals and families.Recently, we have watched the deterioration in financial conditions extend beyond the subprime market.  Investors appear to have reassessed their outlook and their tolerance for risk, especially for structured financial products and for securities of highly leveraged firms.  Bond spreads--especially those for speculative-grade debt--widened substantially in June and July, and the volatility of equity prices increased as well.  In mid-August, following several events that led investors to believe that credit risks might be larger and more pervasive than previously thought, the functioning of financial markets, including short-term and interbank funding markets, became increasingly impaired.  Notably, many asset-backed commercial paper programs found rolling over their paper increasingly difficult.  To help restore orderly conditions, the Federal Reserve in recent weeks has increased the provision of reserves, cut the discount rate, and changed its usual discount-window lending practices in order to facilitate term borrowing, together with other measures.  Stepping back from the rush of unfolding events, we are seeing a pattern that occurs from time to time.  Financial markets and institutions perform the essential function of channeling funds to those individuals or firms having the most productive investment opportunities.  However, an increase in uncertainty and concerns about the quality of information can lead investors to pull back from financial markets and restrict productive lending--with potentially adverse implications for real activity.  That is essentially the story I laid out ina paper delivered at the Kansas City Fed’s Jackson Hole conference about ten years ago.7  In my view, such an increase in uncertainty is an important part of what we have observed recently and stems from heightened concerns about the value of financial securities related to certain types of loans, about who is holding these securities, and about how a revaluation of these securities might affect thebalance sheets of various financial intermediaries.  Consequently, investors have become less willing to put funds into various financial markets, particularly into the more opaque segments of those markets.As best we can tell thus far, the imprint of these developments on economic activity appears likely to be most pronounced in the housing sector.  However, economic activity could be affected more severely in other sectors should heightened uncertainty lead to a broader pullback in household and business spending.  That scenario cannot, in my view, be ruled out, and I believe it poses an important downside risk to economic activity.I also believe that the process of adjustment that is under way in financial markets--of investors reassessing the outlook for risk and their tolerance for that risk--will ultimately create a more solid financial footing for the real economy.  But in the meantime, the FOMC is monitoring the situation and is prepared to act as needed to mitigate the adverse effects on the economy arising from the disruptions in financial markets.Thank you for your interest and attention.  I look forward to your questions and observations on recent developments.(서울=연합인포맥스)(끝)

title: Steelmaking, chemical, IT seen to be free from inflation fears
content: Investors and companies are scrambling to find a remedy to soaring inflation. Inflation fears that have continued since May have sent the benchmark Kospi index below the 1,670 point mark. The local stock market opened weak on the first day of the year’s second half, with the index recording 1,666.46 on Tuesday. A protracted market correction, which seems to have no end in sight, has put the brakes on individual investors' bargain hunting. Will there be a breakthrough? Securities companies are seeking to ease investor sentiment by presenting strategies to help investors survive through an era of soaring inflation.Securities experts singled out industries that are expected to stay clear of inflationary pressure, and that can even pass the pressure onto product prices to their benefit. Daewoo Securities recently conducted an analysis of U.S. and Korean industries that sustained higher returns than market returns during times of high oil price-driven inflation. The analysis revealed that steelmaking, chemical, and IT sectors performed robustly in both markets. Lee Won-sun, a researcher at Daewoo, said, “The steelmaking sector is attractive because the industry is one of those sectors that can easily pass rising production costs onto product prices. The IT sector is also expected to benefit more than other industries due to companies’ strong commitment to improve efficiency stemming from rising production costs.” Export shares also are considered as an alternative pick, through which investors can expect solid profits through the second quarter earning season. In addition, large cap shares offer more stable investments than shares of smaller firms. Stock experts also singled out countries that are relatively free from the inflation trend in the global market. Such countries include those that can minimize damage on their economic fundamentals due to a limited impact of inflation on their economies. Among advanced economies, experts singled out Japan, which has been struggling amid deflation, as an alternative investment option. Resource-rich countries also drew keen attention from market experts. By Lee Se-kyung /seilee@fnnews.com ※ Copyrights ⓒ The Financial News. All rights reserved. title: [COMMENTARY] Irrational pessimism pummels U.S. bond market
content: What a difference a year makes.Each year, Jim Reid and his colleagues at Deutsche Bank AG publish an influential analysis of credit markets that puts current yields and fundamentals in historical perspective.If you buy a bond from a company that might go bankrupt, then you expect to receive a higher interest rate. In an efficient and well-functioning market, the higher yield in a diversified portfolio of such bonds should offset the losses you would incur over time because of defaults. If a 10-year Treasury is yielding 4 percent, then you should only buy a 10-year bond from a company with a good chance of defaulting if the yield is significantly higher than 4 percent.How much higher? That is exactly the question addressed with impressive analytical precision by the Deutsche Bank report. It provides a great thermometer reading of the bond market. The report calculates how large the default probabilities must be to command the current yields on different classes of bonds.A comparison of this year`s report with last year`s provides a striking and even startling view of how rough the credit crisis has become."Last year, spreads on high-yield bonds were so low, that you could have expected to lose money if you purchased them, even if they defaulted at the lowest rate in history," Reid, head of fundamental credit research at Deutsche Bank in London, said in an interview last week. "This year, spreads are so high that you can expect to make money even if they default at the highest rate in history." That`s one way to say that corporate bonds look like a good buy right now. If you think about it in terms of implied default probabilities, the analysis gets downright shocking.Looking at the iBoxx Dollar Liquid Investment Grade Index, Reid and his colleagues estimate that current spreads imply that 19 percent of five-year bonds in the index will default during the next five years. This is an unbelievably high rate.The highest default rate for these bonds was just 2.4 percent, and the average rate since 1970 was 0.8 percent.From Citigroup Inc. to JPMorgan Chase & Co., financial firms have been particularly hard hit in this crisis. This is apparent in Reid`s numbers as well.Current prices suggest that 21 percent of five-year bonds in the financial industry are expected to default during the next five years. This places financial bonds - the debt of some of the bluest of blue-chip firms - smack dab between single A- rated bonds (which have an implied expected default rate of 20 percent) and BBB-rated bonds (which have an implied expected default rate of 22 percent.) Those implied default rates are also way outside of historical experience. The highest five-year default rate for A- rated bonds was 2.5 percent. The most for BBB-rated bonds was 5.8 percent.The mayhem, of course, hasn`t just affected five-year bonds. Longer maturities have even more extreme default scenarios priced in. Current prices suggest that 29 percent of corporate bonds will default over the next 10 years. That rate is six times higher than any 10-year period since 1970.It is worth noting that these default probabilities are probably somewhat inflated, as default risk isn`t the sole consideration when looking at bond prices. Even so, the market is pricing in a bond-market catastrophe that`s far worse than anything that has ever happened.What should one make of these numbers? Even an optimist should be startled by what bond markets are saying. The market isn`t just expecting a downturn; it`s expecting a calamity. A University of Chicago-style believer in the absolute wisdom of markets should be loading up on canned goods and checking the fortification of his underground bunker.A more rational response to this report might be to recognize that markets, while they are right on average, tend to overreact in both directions. A person with this sentiment would have looked at last year`s prices and concluded that they were irrationally low. Now, panic has set in, and spreads are way too high, pricing in something close to the end of civilization.The world economy has survived wars, oil embargoes and even a depression. That suggests it can survive this, too, even if things get worse before they get better. If you believe that, then a buy-and-hold strategy on bonds looks about as good as it ever will. If enough investors see that, then this credit crunch might finally begin to ease.By Kevin Hassett  Kevin Hassett, director of economic-policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute, is a Bloomberg News columnist. He is an adviser to Republican Senator John McCain of Arizona in his bid for the 2008 presidential nomination. The opinions expressed are his own. - Ed.

title: Opponents to Korea-U.S. FTA trapped in anti-U.S. struggle
content: This is the third in a series of articles on the ongoing Korea-U.S. negotiations for a free trade agreement. - Ed.By Choi Sung-no The Korea-U.S. FTA negotiation meetings held on four occasions appear to have failed to bring the parties closer to an agreement on major controversial matters, despite progress made on some fronts. The prospects for the fifth meeting to be held in the U.S. in December are not so bright, either.Korean people`s support for the FTA has dwindled amid continued anti-FTA demonstrations. Under such circumstances, there arose a need for the government to obtain the consensus that its open-door policies will bring the nation higher economic prosperity.In this regard, it should be pointed out that public broadcast stations substantially controlled by the government broadcast programs that incite sentiment against the Korea-U.S. FTA, thus causing general public`s support for it to dwindle. To make the matter worse, some National Assembly members of the ruling party have expressed their objection to the FTA. There are even people who express doubts about whether the current Government is willing to push ahead with the FTA with the U.S.Instigation by anti-U.S. group  At present, the so-called Pan-Korea Anti-FTA Movement Headquarters plays a leading role in exaggerating possible side effects of the door-opening and instigating the mob. It is comprised of leftist labor organizations, farmers and civic groups. They are instigating people, saying, "The nation will go bankrupt soon after the FTA is signed"; "Look at Mexico. Its economy came to be under the control of the U.S. after the signing of the FTA"; "Utility charges and educational/medical expenses will increase more than ten times"; or "With the opening of the agricultural sector, all farmers will go bankrupt."  It appears that they depend on the use of rhetoric or symbolism and appeal to the sentiment of the innocent rather than the analysis of facts. Such leftist tactics of instigation have been used in many countries for distortion of facts. In essence, these leftists are anti-capitalists in some countries, and anti-U.S. groups in Korea. They even ran riot in Pyeongtaek a few months ago, asking for the pullout of the U.S. forces from Korea.They are opposed to the open-door policy, but their opposition this time is made fiercer because it is an agreement with the U.S. They insist that the nation`s economy will be subordinated to the U.S. to a greater extent with the signing of the FTA. It was the same theory used decades ago in anti-U.S. campaigns. They are ridiculously attempting to revive the theory that was scrapped by leftist themselves to stir up the sentiments of innocent people.Leftists in Korea use violence and deceptive tactics. These anti-U.S. groups, a minority in the Korean society, sometimes show a strong ripple effect. They show their solidarity under the leftist ideology. They form part of the nation`s new leadership. Thus, they will continue to pose a threat to the nation in years to come.Hollowness of a blind opposition  The problem with the leftists in Korea is that they are objecting for objection`s sake and asking to stop the negotiations with no proper reasons instead of analyzing possible changes and effects of the FTA to make what they insist sound plausible. There is no reason to object to an attempt to enhance our own interest through negotiations with a foreign country and open our market reciprocally.Opening the nation`s market and being engaged in international competition is unavoidable if we are willing to enhance our competitiveness in weak industrial areas and create new added value where possible. It is directly linked to national survival and prosperity. Such being the case, the leftist groups` attempts to block new opportunities are a matter of regret. The attitude against door-opening appears to be an attempt not to lose their existing rights and refuse to adopt new changes. Such an attitude will fundamentally block the opportunity for new development through this door-opening.Expansion of mutual exchanges with a huge market like the U.S. means brisker activities in the ocean of infinite possibility, although it also means being exposed to uncertainties. We cannot expect a new success without making challenges.Door-opening is the right choice  There is no denying that the opening of the market and free trade have been the growth engine for the Korean economy. Some scholars advise cautious promotion of the FTA with the U.S. or making proper preparations before pushing ahead to sign it. They appear not to know the reality of regulations imposed in Korea. It is difficult to push ahead with market liberalization without applying external shocks due to the pressure from interest groups. After all, the opening of the market is the only way to put an end to problems related to regulations and enhance competitiveness. An FTA with a foreign country is just the beginning of a process. The opening of the market is accompanied by the pain of restructuring in exchange for operational improvement.The nation`s competitiveness in agriculture and service falls is behind that of manufacturing. The opening of the market is the only way to enhance the nation`s competitiveness in these sectors. Especially, agriculture, education, finance, medical and public service require a new change to be reborn as future growth industries.The problem is that a myriad of regulations and the government`s interference overlap each other in these sectors and interest groups try to keep their exiting rights, using the closed environment. Provision of excessively protective measures or taking deferred actions is as good as giving up the benefits of the door opening. It is a right attitude to push ahead with the opening of the market, while taking measure to make up for possible loss, in determination to build higher competitiveness.The opening of the market will do good to both consumers and general public.The Korea-U.S. FTA will provide a good opportunity to renew the nation`s dilapidated industrial structure. There are concerns about the loss of jobs in such a process. However, jobs like those are likely to be the ones that have already lost competitiveness, and barely existed with the government`s protection. They only pose a heavy burden to taxpayers. Jobs that are created in the process of the door opening and competition are sound and good-quality ones.The opening of the market is beneficial for the economy. It is the way that should be adopted by a free market economy. Negotiations concerning the opening of the mutual markets cannot be advantageous for one party. There can`t be a loser in that game. We should not let anti-U.S. demonstrators or interest groups stand in the way of the FTA. It is time that the Government should take a more positive and firm attitude in the FTA negotiations with the U.S. to maximize the effect of the opening of the market.The writer is a fellow at the Center for Free Enterprise. The views expressed here are his own. He can be reached at choi3639@hotmail.com - Ed.

title: Is There a God?
content: [OhMyNews Bright B. Simons] After a dozen years of strenuous reflection, of analysis in solitude, and much intense dribbling on paper, the French Philosopher Rene Descartes came to the conclusion in 1641 that He existed. But now He needed a world in which to exist. So back to bed he retreated for further contemplation, until he had come up with what became known as the ontological proof of God. Which proclaims that the origin of universal discontent must lie in some ideal of perfection which lures and drives men to strive for the unattainable, and that this ideal being of perfection, possessing of all that is good and noble, must also be endowed with existence. Further contortions of this premise gave him his much desired world.His proof will come to complement the older cosmological proof, submitted a thousand years earlier by the Philosopher-Saints of the Great Catholic Church, to demonstrate that a complex world such as ours must start from a principle that is self-sufficient in itself. Down the centuries, these two proofs were the target of much scholarly venom. But modern philosophy gives the impression that they have been demolished, and the crumbling of philosophy in the face of the rise of science further cements this notion, rendering the question of their relevance, at best, moot. The supposed demolition, when one looks critically at it however, seems confined to the semantics of "proving existence," though there is hardly any doubt that this is a general affliction of all scholarly systems of reality. One may say that "proving existence" is the very bane of philosophy. When the brilliant, if a bit self-full, mathematician Alfred Whitehead set out in 1913 with the famous British philosopher Bertrand Russell to prove the existence of the objects of mathematics, the effort had them heaving and puffing through one long-winded argument after another, on end. After about a thousand pages of gymnastics they managed to prove the existence of "1." As for the other elements of the mathematical system, as far as one can tell, they appear to have abandoned the quest, perhaps heading off after that final triumph to a serene terrace somewhere for tea and oatmeal biscuits, after the fashion presumably of distinguished Cambridge Dons. But quite apart from a possible tacit acknowledgment that "proofs of existence" are notoriously difficult to conjure, it also seemed that a mild accommodation, one of benign mutual neglect, had been reached between science and religion after the unrelenting assaults of the Darwinian system and the rationalist excesses of the late Enlightenment. For most of the past century, this accommodation has by and large been maintained, with decreasing enthusiasm. 2006 has been a year of reckoning, for the uncomfortable Detente between Science and Religion ever since the Great Einstein, to paraphrase a contemporary, transferred the Vatican of Science from the Old Rome of Europe's Gottingen to the New World of the American Ivy League. Einstein, a believer in a "Divine Principle" of sorts, was to many people symbolic of the hope that coexistence between science and faith was possible; but even before his death the seismic events wrought within science by the new quantum physics had been steadily unraveling this nominal pact of tolerance.In the past few months a number of books have been published laying claim to the feat, in varying tones of certitude, of having settled the issue of God's existence, and thus the basis of cohabitation between science and religion.Of these books, the one that particularly impelled me to write on this subject is Richard Dawkins' "The God Delusion." In this book, the avowed atheist makes a wide range of claims all related to the impossibility and total implausibility of a notion of an actually existing God.In an interview with the British broadcaster Jeremy Paxman, he repeats what can be plausibly described as the central premise of his argument in "The God Delusion," that the existence of God is a hypothesis, for which the burden of proof lies on believers. I have tried above to demonstrate that the concept of "proving existence" always quickly descends to the philosophical, and then the metaphysical, before making a turn for absurd, and Dr. Dawkins  knows this very well. It is not only proving God's existence that is a thoroughly difficult thing to do, it is trying to prove the existence of pretty much anything.But Dawkins raises this point in such a profoundly comprehensive manner that such a glib response won't do. If I am going to comment on his weighty tome, I might as well at least try to engage with it holistically. So forgive me if this article runs on for longer than is typical in this forum.The first thing one notices about the "God Delusion" is that Dawkins makes a half-hearted attempt at enunciating the differences between deism, theism and atheism. He politely asks agnostics to declare their hand. What this article is going to focus on is that by "theism," he erroneously encompasses monotheism with other forms of "generic theism." I will make the point that "monotheism" belongs to an entirely different order of religious project altogether.But first, I admit that I sympathize with Dawkins on his frustrations with Deism. I believe the famous Russian essayist, Leo Tolstoy gave us the classic definition of deism when he described "true religion" as "a relationship established with God, in conformity with reason and contemporary knowledge, and which alone pushes humanity forward to its desired aim." The mechanistic deisms of the likes of Voltaire, Descartes and Antoine Arnauld are all watered down versions of this classic claim.This claim, it seems to me, Dawkins does a rather good job of attacking. On the basis of limited reason, as we are all variably endowed, and on the strength of "contemporary knowledge," I also find it difficult to see how the claims of omniscience, omnipotence and omnipresence as define the attributes of God can be substantiated. The God Delusion is replete with paradoxes aimed like wrecking balls against some of the mundane "proofs" of God's "relationship" with man. If God is omniscient, then he should know his future state of mind, so that whatever will happen is essentially fixed and he can not omnipotently alter it without making his prior knowledge of it false. But if he cannot alter it, then he is not omnipotent after all.One can see Dawkins smirking and smugly whistling all the way through as he typed away at his favorite typewriter. But his smugness is as a result of much self-indulgent "strawman argumentation" as I hope to show.Now we move on to Theism. Dawkins knows perfectly well, though he prefers not to dwell on it, that there has never been a harsher critic, historically, of theism -- the belief in the supernatural as a necessary part of reality because of the awesomeness of nature, the limitations of man, the fear of death and the psychological incentive of hope in the face of natural adversity-- than the advanced monotheistic projects. The author of the "God Delusion" needs to return to the Jewish scriptures and read over and over about how the prophets and spokespeople of advancing monotheism dealt with beliefs about the supernatural. The Jewish Prophet Isaiah writes of the classic theist: "He cuts down a piece of wood, warms himself with the fire he makes of part, satiates his hunger with the bread he bakes on part and of the remainder he carves an idol, and bows down before it, to worship it, though this graven image can neither hear nor speak."We moderns may scoff, but this way of thinking represented such a conceptual advance that the spokespersons of monotheism were sometimes forced every now and then to recoil from the full implications of what it meant. The notion that mighty storms, plagues, pestilence and other terrifying phenomena of nature are not themselves of a divine essence was a paradigm shift of momentous significance, such as we living in the modern world can never appreciate.But it is in such beginnings that the path from standard theism to monotheism has its origins. From the era of Moses' Yahweh, barely distinguishable from the pseudo-monotheisms of Egypt's Aten and the Chaldean astrologers, to the Sadducees of Jesus' time, who rejected belief even in angels and spirits, and thereon to St. Paul's conversations with the Greeks about his metaphor of an "unknown God," we see a grand march from simple compatibility between belief and basic reason to a desire to grasp complex realities that are beyond the reach of everyday reason, everyday commonsense. Deism, thus, is not an attempt to redeem monotheism; it is actually a retrogression. It restrains the drive of monotheism to carry the human intellect into epic voyages of discovery, such as will extend the horizons of reason, and confines its interest to shriveling monotheism to fit into the "contemporary state of reason and knowledge."Monotheism, fully developed, however aims to tread loftily over mere reason. It denigrates the "current state of knowledge," arguing that God cannot be the "anthropomorphic" beings of Greek and Pagan cosmogonies. He must not be encloaked in idioms that ''common sense'' and ''basic reason'' can effortlessly handle. God cannot be the philandering Zeus or the regal Ra, even much less the irascible Thor. He is over and beyond such  magnification of human essences. To understand the monotheistic God who must push ourselves towards and then over the edge of reason.But crucially, monotheism does not on the other hand say that God is "outside" reason, that we are unable to "reach out" to God by means of intellect at all. That way of thinking belongs to the realm of sorcery, magic and superstition. Monotheists rejects cowardly resignation to ritual and dogma. This is the point Pope Benedict had tried to make at Regensburg, but sadly was missed in the furore over less central aspects of his lecture.So, high above mere animism and beyond the anthropomorphism of commonplace rationality -- i.e. the treatment of God as one possessed of vastly magnified human traits -- strives monotheism.We see this in the early Church Fathers' desire to make a companion of Plato, that other monotheist who raged against the anthropomorphic polytheism of his native Athens. It is the occasional successes of thinkers like Plato that Greek civilization stands out as a monument to man's quest for perpetual intellectual advancement. As a testament to man's ability to resolve not to be bound to the confinements of mundane reason. This is the social sentiment at the root of critical reflection, and proceeding from that of science and enlightenment.These days we are wont to dismiss the roots of the European Renaissance in monotheistic thinking, but it is not for nought that of the invaders of the Near East, only the Arab Muslims and the European Christians managed to revive the classical learning of the Greeks. The Huns and Mongols arrived and departed empty-handed.For, to repeat, monotheism is the belief in the super-rational, a deep yearning for what the current level of reason can barely hint at; it is the striving after the unattainable. In fact, as Karl Popper points out, the super-rational co-exists with the transcendent. It is exemplified by Socrates' claim that his religion compels him to question all authority. For this "impiety," he was prepared to die. His God had said to him that "all men know nothing." Empty therefore is the "current state of knowledge."This, one may presume, Dawkins is likely to dismiss as another rewording of classic Deism. I disagree. It is something else entirely. It is not accommodating an untested premise of God within the bounds of "present knowledge." It seeks rather to offer to mankind the heart-wrenchingly exacting task of fathoming the essence of such a transcendent concept as "God" as a driver to the intellectual limits of "knowing." It is holding out the possibility that the bounds of knowledge may be elastic. Perhaps it is this hope that Dawkins glimpses but quickly dismisses as a "delusion."In using that word, he is of course merely re-echoing Freud in the latter's famous declamation about religion:"The whole thing is so patently infantile, so incongruous with reality, that to one whose attitude to humanity is friendly it is painful to think that the great majority of mortals will never be able to rise above this view of life."Surely by "incongruity with reality," he means reality as "presently understood"? For I will venture that if one was to cycle back to the middle ages and present the ''view of reality'' as we accept it today, that out of a vacuum sprang the universe, that matter was at a certain point coupled to light, the most learned thinkers in their cloisters will dismiss it as another pagan fantasy.Indeed consider the statement: all matter, energy, space and time exploded out of a point. Consider that this is what science can tell us today about the origin of reality, which by mighty leaps in our scientific consciousness, we can treat as rather workaday, even when translated to everyday language as above, and made to sound as absurd as the first line in a creation myth from the East. Therefore, at the risk of sounding like an echo chamber, I repeat: one cannot judge monotheism by the very standard it rejects: that the state of knowledge and the level of reason should limit the exploration of intellect and constrain belief.But Dawkins had not concerned himself with the claims of religion merely to score academic points. He states that his mission is to "convert" theists into atheists. Obviously he is alarmed by the resilience of religion in the face of overwhelming odds. Seven decades of communism had sought to abolish all belief in what Marx called the "opiate of the masses," but what do we see in 2006? The Russian Orthodox Church has arisen again as a pillar of the Russian state, and even the Chinese are openly musing about actively promoting Judaeo-Christian Monotheism to supplant the role of what they perceive as passive atheistic faiths such as Taoism and Confucianism in Chinese Society.Dawkins contends that because Religion is a delusion, it tends to irrationality and furthers the most destructive obsessions, paranoia and passions. Naturally, he points to the bible belt in the USA, Al Qaeda fanatics and Creationists interfering with the educational prospects of young Americans.By so doing, he carries "The God Delusion" to a whimpering anti-climax. For this is the Achilles heel of his argument: he confuses the ideal with the practice. By Dawkins' own token, we should similarly dismiss science as a delusion because it fostered the craniologists of the 18th century who begun the spurious thesis that physiognomy can yield insights into intelligence and paved the way for today's authors of the Bell Curve. Apart from the notion that intelligence is racially distributed, science also gave us Mengele and his SS researchers, along with their "genetic" experimentation on humans and their technical enhancements of the gas chambers. Not to mention atomic bombs and novel forms of torture. But can we really look for absurdities in science's history or its present, point to them, and declare that they constitute an inseparable aspect of the overall scientific experience? When Jacob Moleshott wrote in the 19th century, according to Paul Johnson's account, that thought is a process facilitated by phosphorus, he no doubt saw himself an upholder of scientific truth in a swamp of superstitious foolery. Today, we know better. The error resides in seeing either Science or religion as "settled." Science in 2006 is definitely not the science of bloodletting, amputation and hypnotism of yesteryears. And definitely the monotheism of coming years shall not be the monotheism practiced by the Jewish Patriarchs and the Medieval inquisitors. Monotheism, more so than any other form of faith, has proved beyond all doubt that it is more than a set of settled dogmas. No other religion outside the monotheistic projects has spawned offshoots on point of doctrine. Political struggle, migration or royal intrigues, yes; but never on points of doctrine. Yet, just take a brief scan of the history of Christianity, for instance. Consider the contentions over the heresies, Martin Luther insisting "back to the scriptures" and the Jesuit-led counter-reformation. All this depict my central thesis: monotheism is not a settled fount of dogma. It is an expression of the inner craving to push the limits of reason, to undermine the bounds of knowledge and to exercise our powers of persuasion beyond our customary capacity for logic and understanding.What a spoilsport Richard Dawkins and his ilk are! This desire to "settle" the God Hypothesis once and for all is a most depressing sentiment. It is the desire to quell every hankering after the unattainable. It is to toss over to the fireplace of commonplace rationality this dandy morsel of the ages; this teaser of the intellectual appetites that has so driven so many to ponder the unponderable. Whether in the guise of the search for extraterrestrial intelligence or a unified theory or physics, God-seeking touches all humanity, but is most profound in monotheism, wherewith it sprang. The God Hypothesis must not be settled! For insofar as we now understand that beavers build dams, that social insects form societies and porpoises have emotions and cognition, habilis and sapiens can no longer distinguish Homo; they cannot satiate the species' hunger for unattainable perfection. Delusion? Not at all; I will settle for enthrallment.To all intents and purposes, and pardon my Latin, man can take consolation in only one appellation: Homos Deocogi. We are in perpetuity, and should make no apologies for it, the fathomers of God. - ⓒOhMyNews International (http://english.ohmynews.com) -

title: Minister hints at front-loading `07 budget
content: Kwon says the Korean economy is in a virtual recession By Yoo Soh-jung The government may front-load its budget spending in the first half of next year if uncertainty stemming from North Korea`s nuclear test damps consumer sentiment and slows economic growth, Finance Minister Kwon O-kyu said yesterday."Economic growth in the second half is slowing, and this will pose a burden on the first quarter of next year," Kwon told a breakfast meeting with businessmen. "This indicates a need for front-loading our budget spending." The chief economic policymaker said that the Korean economy is expected to grow 5 percent this year, but the gross national income is estimated to be limited to 1.5 percent. "This shows that the economy is in a virtual recession," he said.Kwon underlined that the current macroeconomic policies need adjustment because the country is overshadowed by uncertainty deepened by the North Korea nuclear issue.Kwon said plans for front-loading the budget spending will be completed by mid-December and be ready to be adopted by January.Asia`s third-largest economy has been attempting to completely revive weak domestic consumption after a credit bubble burst in 2003. It left nearly 4 million people mired in debt, driving the economy to nearly a three-year slump.But improving consumer confidence last year has boosted spending, pushing the government to set a target of 5 percent growth this year, the fastest pace in four years.Kwon said Korea`s economy probably expanded 4.6 percent in the third quarter and will likely expand 4 percent in the fourth quarter."This will ensure the economy meets the government`s target for 5 percent growth in 2006," he said.A slowdown in private spending, high crude oil prices and the won`s gain against the dollar and the Japanese yen pose as risks to economic growth.While a weaker won against the greenback has helped "ease the burden" on the economy, Kwon said, the won`s gains against the yen threatens Korean exports."The yen exchange rate affects Korean exports because the two countries compete in the export markets," the minister said. He assured that the government will roll out measures in November for smaller exporters to help them compete with the won`s rise against the yen.The two countries compete in such key areas as chips, automobiles and ships.The won fell 1.2 percent to 8.08651 against the yen this week after rising on Oct. 16 to the strongest since November 1997.South Korea posted its slowest growth in more than a year in the second quarter, the Bank of Korea said on Sept. 1. The central bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged on Oct. 12 at 4.5 percent for the second straight month.The Korea Development Institute on Tuesday said that the economy is expected to expand 4.3 percent next year because of a slowdown in export growth and weakening consumer spending."We`ll try to share the recognition with the Bank of Korea about the macro-economy based on the future analysis of economic trends, inflationary pressure and downward risks on the economy," Kwon said.Kwon added that a free trade agreement Korea is now pursuing with the United States would help stabilize foreign investor sentiment in the Korean economy."The FTA with the U.S. will not only help improve our productivity, but will be an effective tool to reduce uncertainty in our economy after North Korea`s announcements," he said.(sohjung@heraldm.com)

title: Fighting Chinese patriotism
content: Kang Jun-young The author is a professor of Chinese studies at Hankuk University of Foreign Studies and the head of the Center for International Area Studies. BTS, a contemporary global cultural icon and the symbol of Hallyu, was attacked by Chinese internet users. They claimed that BTS’ remark on the Korean War and Korea-U.S. relations ignored China’s “national dignity.” The Global Times, a leader in creating public opinion in China, lit up patriotism by reporting Chinese netizens’ anger.    The attack on BTS as a way to vent out anger on U.S.-China relations could not garner empathy, as China’s core interests like sovereignty were not involved. In the end, anti-Chinese sentiment about China’s narrow nationalism, the unpredictable political landmine, “Chinazi” and “Ugly Chinese” spread globally and China backed off. The Chinese Foreign Ministry seems to be aware of the aggravating international atmosphere and Korea’s leaning toward the United States, and things calmed down as the ministry mentioned the friendly future development of Korea-China relations.    On the surface, the BTS controversy may seem like a blip in international relations, but the Chinese authorities showing off its status as an international power and Chinese netizens armed with patriotism remain the same. Just as in the Thaad case, the attacks on BTS show China’s view on history and its excessive patriotism, including ignoring other countries, based on international strategy. It is a repetition of the typical patriotic pattern of brandishing its “weaponized economic power” to Korea and creating an intimidating mood against China.     [YONHAP]     China’s distorted patriotism is not new, but Korea’s response is inconsistent. It is true that dealing with the Chinese giant is a challenge, but the stance has not been consistent, as some say that China’s pride should not be hurt and others say the government should actively address the China problem. In the course of establishing ties with China, views on North Korea and the Korean War were not narrowed, and after establishing diplomatic relations, the focus has been on economy-oriented external growth, and the two countries haven’t been able to build a consensus on historic facts and North Korean issues related to the Korea-U.S. alliance or Korea-China relations. But problems cannot be solved by avoiding them.    As the controversy revealed, Chinese netizens’ attacks on BTS were escalated into attacks on China by Western media, and we need to be wary that it could evolve into another factor in the U.S.-China dispute. The government’s hasty response could be problematic, but China’s unreasonable claims should not be accommodated. The government needs to have a clear principle, even with a low-key response, and intellectuals should develop and advocate arguments against China’s distorted historic view and self-centered double standards. When the government and the private sector join, true diplomatic power can be displayed.    Business concerned with the Chinese market find it harder. Companies remember the pains in the aftermath of Thaad, and as soon as the problem arose, they took down postings and promotions related to BTS, pledging not to be a victim of China’s patriotic craze. But excessive preemptive responses only affirm economic weaponization. They could be seen as embracing Chinese netizens’ offense, and in the long term, could lose originality in the Chinese market.    Of course, it is desirable for China to stop the self-centered behavior of pressuring other countries. But that won’t happen naturally. It takes courage to speak up and respond based on accurate and factual analysis, and we should not get caught up in the repeated public opinion war and psychological warfare.

title: [WT논평]Pre-empting Iran''s ambitions
content: with some sort of showdown with Iran over its nuclear ambitions looming on the horizon, a divisive new foreign policy debate has sprung up in Washington. At issue is whether the United States can and should carry out a pre-emptive attack on Iran’s numerous nuclear facilities.  So far, these discussions have generated a good deal of heat, but precious little light. Proponents of military action contend that the United States is capable of quickly and effectively neutralizing Iran’s nuclear program through a few surgical aerial strikes. Detractors, meanwhile, say that such steps are not feasible, and if attempted will create catastrophic regional consequences.  The truth, as usual, lies somewhere in the middle. Few doubt that the United States has the operational capability to carry out such a strike. But “pre-empting” Iran’s nuclear program is likely to be an elaborate and costly affair ― and one with very real risks for the United States and its allies in the Middle East.  The first set of variables that requires consideration is targeting. A limited American strike could indeed be done “in one night,” as some commentators have suggested. But simply bombing Iranian nuclear facilities is likely to be profoundly self-defeating. Amilitary strike on Iran’s nuclear complex, therefore, can be expected to slow down Iran’s nuclear program, perhaps even substantially, but it will not eliminate the threat completely. Just as significantly, it would require the Bush administration to throw its weight, and its resources, behind an explicit goal of regime change, rather than simply nuclear rollback.  The second set of variables relates to internal dynamics. Some observers have predicted that because of differences in ethnicity, culture and national identifications, a large segment of the Iranian population will not rally around the flag following an attack on Iran’s nuclear installations. But this analysis skirts the fact that Iran’s atomic drive is by all indications a wildly popular domestic issue, supported both by ordinary Iranians and by regime hardliners (albeit for very different reasons). This sentiment, moreover, appears to cut across both ethnic and cultural lines. All of which means that American planners must assume that military action will prompt an upsurge in nationalist sentiment within the Islamic republic, and strengthen ― rather than weaken ― the current regime’s grip on power. (FRI.)서서히 모습을 드러내는 이란의 핵 야망을 놓고 이란과 모종의 대결을 벌이는 것에 대해 워싱턴에서는 의견이 엇갈리는 외교정책 논쟁이 새로이 불거지고 있다. 미국이 이란의 수많은 핵시설을 선제공격할 능력과 당위성이 있느냐가 논쟁의 초점이다. 현재까지 이러한 논의가 상당히 열띤 분위기를 조성했으나 귀중한 빛은 별로 찾지 못했다. 군사행동에 찬성하는 사람들은 미국이 몇 차례 정밀공습을 통해 이란의 핵계획을 단시간에 효과적으로 무력화시킬 수 있다고 주장한다. 한편 이런 주장에 이견을 제기하는 사람들은 그런 조치들이 실용성이 없을 뿐 아니라 시도할 경우 중동지역에 갖가지 재앙적인 결과를 초래할 것이라고 말한다. 늘 그렇듯이 진실은 중간 어디엔가 있다. 미국이 그러한 공격을 실행할 작전 능력을 지니고 있다는 것을 의심하는 사람은 거의 없다. 그러나 이란의 핵 프로그램에 대한 ‘선제공격’은 공이 많이 들고 값비싼 과업일 뿐 아니라, 미국과 중동의 우방국들에 대단히 실질적인 위협을 초래하게 될 것이다. 첫째로 고려해야 할 변수는 공격목표 선정이다. 제한된 미국의 공격은 일부 논평가들의 견해처럼 실제로 ‘하룻밤’에 단행될 수 있다. 그러나 단순한 이란 핵시설의 폭격은 패배를 자초할 가능성이 있다.그러므로 핵시설 단지에 대한 군사공격은 이란의 핵계획을 늦출 수 있고 어쩌면 상당한 수준으로 늦출 수 있을지 모르나, 핵 위협은 완전히 제거하지는 못할 것이다. 조지 부시 행정부가 단순한 이란 핵 억제 정책보다는 정권을 교체한다는 명시적인 목표에 힘과 자원을 집중할 필요성 역시 중요하다. 둘째로 고려해야 할 변수는 이란 국내의 역동성과 관련돼 있다. 일부 관측통은 종족·문화·국가 정체성의 차이점들로 인해 이란 국민의 다수가 자국의 핵시설 공격에 뒤이어 국기 아래 뭉치지 않을 것이라고 예측한다. 그러나 모든 징표로 판단할 때 이란의 핵 개발 추진이 매우 다른 여러 가지 이유 때문이기는 하나, 이란 일반 국민과 정권의 강경파가 모두 지지하는 매우 인기 높은 국내 현안이라는 사실을 이런 분석은 비켜가고 있다. 뿐만 아니라 이러한 정서는 종족이나 문화적 노선을 모두 초월하는 것으로 보인다. 이 모든 것은 군사행동이 이슬람 공화국 내부에서 민족주의 정서의 고조를 촉발하고 현정권의 권력장악력을 약화시키기는커녕 강화시킬 가능성을 미국 정책 입안자들이 가정해야 한다는 것을 의미한다.역주=오성환 외신전문위원 suhwo@segye.com▲showdown: 대결▲divisive: 불화를 야기하는▲detractor: 중상자    ▲variable: 변수▲rollback: 통제에 의한 물가억제 정책ⓒ 세계일보＆세계닷컴(www.segye.com), 무단전재 및 재배포 금지<세계닷컴은 한국온라인신문협회(www.kona.or.kr)의 디지털뉴스이용규칙에 따른 저작권을 행사합니다.>

title: [번역]Consumer confidence worst in 3 1/2 years 소비심리, 3년 반만에 최저...
content: The Bank of Korea`s consumer confidence index sank to its lowest point in 3 1/2  years during the second quarter, further confirmation that the nation`s economic recovery will be postponed.The index which gauges the six-month outlook of consumers on their living conditions sank to 80 during the April-June period from 84 in the first quarter.It was the lowest reading since the last quarter of 2000 when the index figure was 68.A score below the benchmark 100 means that among the 2,500 households surveyed, the number of respondents expecting their situation to worsen was greater than those seeing an improvement."A set of recent figures showing domestic demand is not yet picking up, household debt overloads and credit delinquencies that are still haunting consumers, and the recent dip in real estate and stock markets altogether impaired people`s sentiment," said Kim Chul of the central bank`s survey team.Another index measuring consumer prospects for spending over the next six months also tumbled from 111 to 102, suggesting Koreans will be reluctant to open their wallets."Still, the spending index manages to remain above the key 100 mark because people must keep buying necessities. If the current negative factors continue, however, it will soon fall below," Kim predicted.Koreans tightened their purse strings after a nationwide spending boom put millions of people deep in hock. More than 8 percent of the country`s 48 million population is at least three months in arrears on their debt payments.An earlier survey by the National Statistical Office showed that consumer sentiment deteriorated in May due to a range of uncertainties at home and abroad."It seems strong global oil prices and weak job market figures, which determine household income levels, are keeping consumer indexes from improving," said Kim Hyeon-wook, an economist at the Korea Development Institute.Backing up the analysis, the central bank`s sub-index of future price levels stood far below the 100 reading at 53, indicating a majority of respondents expect prices to rise going forward.Another sub-index on the employment situation during the next six-month period also fell from 68 to 66 in the second quarter.(jihoho@heraldm.com) "People appear to be worried that a job market slump will undercut their real income, consequently denting the overall consumer confidence," explained Kim.(jihoho@heraldm.com)   By Kim Ji-ho     한국은행이 집계하는 올 2분기 소비자 신뢰지수가 3년 반만에 최저수준으로 떨어져 한국의 경제회복이 지연될 것이라는 사실을 더욱 체감케 하고 있다.6개월 후의 생활형편에 대한 전망을 가름하는 이 지수는 1분기의 84에서 2분기에는 80으로 하락했다.이는 이 지수가 68이었던 2000년 4분기 이후 최저수준이다.기준이 되는 100 이하가 되면 조사대상인 2,500가구 중에서 생활형편이 악화될 것으로 예상하는 응답자의 수가 나아질 것으로 예상하는 사람보다 많다는 것을 의미한다.“최근 일련의 수치들이 내수가 여전히 살아나지 못 하고 있음과 가계부채 적체와 아직도 소비자를 괴롭히고 있는 신용불량을 나타내고 있는데다 최근 부동산과 증시의 폭락까지 겹쳐 국민의 소비심리가 위축됐다”고 한국은행 통계조사팀의 김철씨가 말했다.향후 6개월 동안의 소비자 소비 전망을 나타내는 지수 역시 111에서 102로 떨어져 한국인들이 지출을 꺼리고 있음을 보여 주었다.“국민들이 생활필수품은 구입해야 하기 때문에 소비지수가 어쨌든 100선은 상회하고 있다. 하지만 지금과 같은 부정적인 요소가 계속된다면 곧 100 이하로 떨어질 것”이라고 김씨는 전망했다.전국적인 소비지출 붐으로 수많은 사람이 부채의 늪에 빠지자 한국인들은 지출을 삼가고 있다. 4,800만 인구의 8퍼센트가 부채 상환을 최소한 3개월 이상 연체하고 있다.이보다 앞서 실시된 통계청 조사에 따르면 5월에는 국내외적인 불확실성으로 인해 소비심리가 악화되었다고 한다.“국제유가가 오르고 가계의 소득수준을 결정하는 고용시장이 취약하여 소비지수가 개선되지 못 하고 있다”고 한국개발연구원의 김현욱 연구원이 말했다.이러한 분석을 뒷받침하듯이 미래 물가수준을 나타내는 중앙은행의 하위지수가 100에 훨씬 못 미치는 53으로 응답자의 대다수가 물가 상승을 예상하고 있음을 나타냈다.향후 6개월 동안의 고용사정을 나타내는 하위지수 역시 2분기에 68에서 66으로 떨어졌다.

title: [EDITORIAL]Weak economic recovery
content: In its latest quarterly economic report, the Korea Development Institute said the downward trend of the overall economy appeared to be ending. The state-run think tank said the economy might have already hit the nadir in March and might be bottoming out in the second quarter. A similar view was expressed by the LG Economic Research Institute, which said the economy would hit rock bottom and start to turn around in the current quarter.Especially, the KDI provided an analysis of the puzzling dissonance between rapidly improving consumer and business confidence and stagnating or even worsening economic data. This year, the consumer expectation index and the business sentiment reading have been surging. However, industrial output and wholesale and retail data have not been improving noticeably. This discordance led some experts to raise the possibility of a "double dip," a downturn of the economy which follows a short-lived upswing on the heels of a previous downturn.According to the KDI, this disparity is a typical phenomenon when the economy reaches the bottom of a business cycle. The institute identified a three-step recovery of the Korean economy - first a slowdown in the decline of the coincident index; second an increase in the consumer expectation index; and then a rise in the coincident index. The KDI said the first phase already occurred last September, while the third one has yet to come about. Until this February, the coincident index had continued to decline.The KDI`s explanation eased concerns about the general direction of the economy. If the economy turns around as expected, it will be the third upturn since August 2000. The two preceding expansions, which peaked in September 2002 and March 2004, were short-lived and hence could not reverse the long downward trend of the economy, now in its 56th month.However, the KDI analysis did not say much about the strength of the expansion this time. Many analysts say the coming upsurge is likely to be stronger than the two previous ones because domestic consumption is beginning to recover and corporate investment is increasing. However, there are risk factors that could undermine the recovery process. For instance, continued rises in oil prices, the value of the Korean won and U.S. interest rates could all slow recovery by curbing growth in domestic and external demand.If the coming expansion is not powerful enough to break the long downward slide, we cannot rule out the possibility of the Korean economy being trapped in a Japanese-style slump. To avoid this possibility, concerted efforts are needed to make the coming upswing more than a simple technical rebound. In the short term, policymakers are advised to ease the household debt overhang to boost domestic demand and implement various state-promoted investment projects as planned.In the long term, they should focus on enhancing growth potential and addressing structural weaknesses of the Korean economy. To expand growth potential, drastic measures should be taken to encourage corporate investment. The government should take the lead in large-scale research and development projects to induce corporate investment. At the same time, it is necessary to enhance overall economic efficiency by consistently promoting market competition.

title: Consumers turn bearish on economy
content: By Sim Sung-tae Staff reporterKorean consumers turned bearish on the economy in October and plan to cut spending in the coming months, a survey by the National Statistical Office (NSO) showed yesterday.The NSO's consumer sentiment index fell to 97.1 in October from 103.9 in September, down for the fourth consecutive month and below the 100-point benchmark for the first time since November 2001.The index registered 96.7 in November 2001.A reading above 100 indicates a majority of consumers surveyed plan to increase their spending and expect economic conditions to improve in the six months ahead. Conversely, a reading below 100 means more respondents intend to cut back on their spending and are pessimistic about economic prospects.Consumers' outlook on the economy deteriorated sharply. The sub-index for that category dropped to 87.8 in October from 105.9 in September.A reading below 100 shows that more people expect the economy to worsen in the coming months rather than improve."It's not a good sign," said Min Kyung-sam, an official of the NSO's Statistical Analysis Division. "But, the sub-index for future spending is still above 100, which means people are not going to cut their spending immediately due to their gloomy outlook."The sub-index for spending plans also dropped to 106.8 from 107.5 in the period.The sub-index for durable goods purchases fell to 93.6 last month from 97.2 in September, while the sub-index for spending on entertainment and dining out declined to 93.4 from 98.Meanwhile, a separate index measuring current spending levels and economic conditions also continued to fall, to 86.8 in October from 97.2 in September. A reading below 100 means more consumers believe the economic conditions and their spending levels weakened, compared with six months ago.With regard to household savings, 13.1 percent of those surveyed said their savings increased from the preceding six months, up from 12.5 percent the previous month, while 20.1 percent said their debts increased, up from 15.8 percent.Also, 19.5 percent of those surveyed said their household income rose from six months ago, up from 16.6 percent, while 27.3 percent said their income dropped, up from 21.2 percent. The statistics office complies its monthly report on consumer sentiment based on face-to face interviews with married people over the age of 20 in 2,000 households nationwide. (saintsim@koreaherald.co.kr)

title: Korean economy recovering from prolonged slump
content: By Kwon, Soon-wooIt seems that the nation's economy has been recovering since the fourth quarter of 2001 from a prolonged slump, in spite of the aftermath of the recent terrorist attacks in the U.S. Especially, consumer sentiment is recovering fast as shown by the fact that the consumption of durable goods such as automobiles and TVs, has risen. For example, department store sales rose 18 percent year-on-year in December 2001, the highest record of the year. Alongside the recovering consumption, it looks like the domestic semiconductor industry, the nation's major exporter, has begun to climb out of its slump, as chip prices have been exhibiting a steep upward trend and domestic manufacturers are increasing production. Owing to these positive factors, the nation's GDP growth rate for the fourth quarter of 2001 is expected to reach around 4 percent year-on-year, significantly up from the 1.8 percent year-on-year growth of the third quarter of 2001.Growing concernsDespite these positive developments in the domestic economy, there remain many potential dangers. For instance, the increasing expectations for economic recovery, along with the ample liquidity and record low interest rates caused by the central bank's overextended easy monetary policy, have boosted the housing and stock markets. However, these markets' gains seem to be excessive, giving rise to fears of overheated markets. As evidence, apartment prices in Seoul increased by 14.5 percent in 2001, posting the highest increase rate since 1991.Especially, the southern parts of Seoul saw apartment prices rise by as much as 16 percent with a more than two-fold increase being common. In addition, the KOSPI (the Korea Stock Price Index), which once nose-dived to the 469-point level after the terrorist attacks in the U.S., has rocketed to 744.0 as of January 14, 2002, jumping 58.7 percent in only three months. If these gains turn out to be a bubble, and the bubble bursts suddenly, then the effects will not be insignificant.Furthermore, there is much uncertainty surrounding the domestic economy. On the domestic front, the upcoming presidential and local government elections raise the specter of heightened political influence on national economic policies. And on the global scene, the weakening yen and deteriorating Japanese economy is likely to have many negative effects on the Korean economy. Moreover, the major export market of the nation, the U.S., has been losing its status as a market for goods from every country due to the prolonged stagnation of its economy. Even the chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, has recently taken a cautious attitude regarding the recovery of the U.S. economy. Thus, the outlook for the Korean economy is simply not that clear, and an analysis of industrial trends and economic prospects may be quite appropriate at this time.Semiconductors and PCsIn the semiconductor industry these days, DRAM (dynamic random access memory) chip prices have been rising steeply, as shown by the almost three-fold jump in the unit price of 128M DRAM chips, from $1.47 last November to $3.44 as of January 12.Yet more time may be needed for a recovery to begin in earnest. Indeed, some experts have noted that the latest rise in chip prices resulted from supply side factors like industry restructuring rather than from an increase in demand. Another reason for caution is the dependence of the domestic semiconductor industry on the global economy. Accordingly, even though chip prices are on an upward trend for the time being, it is difficult to judge if the industry is truly in a recovery phase, especially since demand for chips by PC manufacturers has not been increasing much. On a brighter note, demand for new PCs to replace older models is expected to invigorate PC sales from the second half of 2002.Thus, the semiconductor industry may begin its recovery in earnest after the second quarter of the year.Shipbuilding and telecommunicationsTwo of the nation's other major industries, shipbuilding and telecommunications, whose relatively strong performances last year contributed greatly to domestic economic growth, are likely to continue to post gains. Although the contraction of the global sea transportation industry and the weakening yen may cause a decline, temporary if at all, in orders, the shipbuilding industry's operations are secure with backlog orders taken for the next two years and more. For its part, the domestic telecommunications industry will likely expand further as CDMA 2000 1x, dubbed the "2.5G" mobile phone service, starts to be in full service in some major countries, including the U.S. and China, creating significant export demand for the handsets of domestic makers. Additionally, changing consumer preferences for newer models will ensure domestic demand for handsets. Automobiles, home appliancesFor its part, the domestic auto industry performed better than expected in 2001 in both domestic and export markets. However, its prospects in 2002 are not so strong in foreign markets. A contracted global market and the weakening yen may hinder domestic manufacturers' exports. As for the domestic market, there are a few favorable factors including the following: cuts in the special excise tax on automobiles, an anticipated temporary consumption boost due to the nation's co-hosting of the World Cup with Japan, and the introduction of new models. To conclude, it is highly likely that the domestic auto industry will see only a mediocre year in 2002, as relatively fine domestic sales are offset by stagnant foreign sales.By comparison, the home appliance industry suffered from the global economic slump and the effects of the terrorist attacks in the U.S. in 2001.But it has recovered rapidly since November of 2001 in terms of both domestic demand and export. Specifically, the global market, which marked a negative growth rate of ??2.1 percent in 2001 for the first time in ten years, is expected to rebound and post positive growth this year. At the same time, the domestic market will likely receive a boost, especially regarding digital home appliances like digital TVs, from the introduction of digital broadcasting and the co-hosting of the World Cup. To sum up, the nation's major industries seem to have improved from the fourth quarter of 2001.But due to still stagnant exports, the extent of the recovery has not been significant. The second half of 2002 is expected to represent an inflection point for the earnest recovery of those industries. However, if events such as the further depreciation of the yen occur, those industries, including shipbuilding, automobiles and home appliances, will be greatly hurt.Economic prospectsConsidering the current state of industrial activities and their prospects, the most likely possibility is that the nation's economy will recover, but not on a V-shaped path. First of all, domestic demand-factors such as consumption and construction investment are expected to show a much slower increase this year. Especially the prospects for consumption, which has been supporting the economy during the current slump, will be weighed down by the fact that household debt rose steeply last year. In this regard, the average amount of household credit extended by domestic financial institutions soared to 22 million won per household as of the end of September 2001, up 25 percent from the same period of the previous year. Also, in the construction industry, the distribution rate of houses (the number of houses divided by the number of households) has been reaching near 100 percent. As a result, housing demand will grow less and less. Moreover, the recent introduction of the government's anti-speculation measures, in response to the fast-rising prices of houses toward the end of last year, may discourage demand even further.In the construction industry, the distribution rate of houses (the number of houses divided by the number of households) has been reaching near 100 percent. As a result, housing demand will grow less and less. Moreover, the recent introduction of the government's anti-speculation measures, in response to the fast-rising prices of houses toward the end of last year, may discourage demand even further.The Samsung Economic Research Institute (SERI) Quick Index also supports the prospect of a mild recovery of the national economy. (The SERI Quick Index predicts economic trends five months into the future, by combining leading economic indicators such as stock prices, the consumer sentiment index, chip prices and the won-yen exchange rate.) The index has increased rather slowly from 96.7 for November 2001, to 97.4 for April 2002.The slow speed of increase indicates that the recovery hereafter will be slightly upward sloping. In the construction industry, the distribution rate of houses (the number of houses divided by the number of households) has been reaching near 100 percent. As a result, housing demand will grow less and less. Moreover, the recent introduction of the government's anti-speculation measures, in response to the fast-rising prices of houses toward the end of last year, may discourage demand even further.Given all these factors, the domestic economy will likely recover somewhat moderately in 2002, with a GDP growth rate of around 4.5 percent year-on-year, lower than the economy's estimated growth potential of 5.1 percent.The writer is a researcher at Samsung Economic Research Institute. - Ed

title: True value of debate in Korean society
content: Debate is a process and an activity that has a long history in democratic countries. Ideas of free speech are rooted in the belief that society functions best when thoughts are freely exchanged, creating a marketplace of ideas. In Commonwealth countries this has taken the form of debates modeled on parliamentary procedure, while in America the debates are generally founded on a congressional model of action.In both cases high school and college students regularly participate in debating competitions that give them the opportunity to exchange ideas in an educational and competitive environment. These competitions represent the very best in democratic ideals and principles. It is safe to say that debate has become a worldwide phenomenon. At the recent World University Championships in Singapore students participated from every region of the globe: Africa, Asia, Europe, the Americas, the Middle East and Australia.In 1994 the first All Asian Intervarsity Debating Championship was held in Singapore at Nanyang Technological University. The initial tournament consisted of university teams from Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines. This competition marked the official beginning of English-language debate in Asia. Since 1994 the competition has grown to include students from Japan, Indonesia, Pakistan, India, Bangladesh, China and Hong Kong.What is most striking about the list of participants in the All Asian competition is that there has never been a participant from a Korean university. This is remarkable because Korea is a world economic leader. It is safe to say that Korea is being left behind the rest of Asia as debate grows and more universities begin participating in this activity at a regional and international level. The lack of reasoned discussion and debate is something that political commentators have noted as a deficiency in the growth of political and civil culture in Korea.In "The Koreans: Who They Are, What They Want, Where Their Future Lies," Michael Breen wrote, "It has always been logical for the opposition simply to oppose and hinder government in whatever way it can, without bothering to develop rational arguments. Subsequently, the growth of a democratic culture to support Korea`s democratic government has not happened. The failure to take rational positions on issues undermines popular sentiment toward politicians and has retarded the growth of rational, democratic thinking."  There could be no better example of Breen`s commentary than the spectacle that took place in the parliament building during the impeachment proceedings. These events vividly demonstrated the dire necessity of creating cultural space for rational decision-making based on reasoned debate in Korea.Recognizing that disagreement does not automatically mean disrespect is an imperative for Koreans. Intelligent people frequently disagree about issues, yet that disagreement need not degenerate into personal attacks and hatred.If Korea is to remain a country that symbolizes the future of democracy in Asia and to be a world model, it must find a way to integrate an appreciation of critical analysis and debate into its everyday life. The first step in this process is the development of debate and debating societies at the university level.Debate can be uniquely valuable to Korean society for a host of reasons. Currently, Koreans spend millions, if not billions, of won yearly to teach their children English. A student who debates must not only articulate ideas in a public forum, but must defend those ideas. In short, students who can debate in English will have no trouble expressing themselves in a clear and coherent manner.The competitive nature of the activity provides a unique motivation to understand and express complex linguistic concepts and ideas. The growth of debate in Asia can be directly attributed to its utility as a tool for learning the language. This is especially true in countries such as Japan. Additionally, debate is unique among extracurricular and competitive events because it demands critical thinking. Students are asked to evaluate and examine complicated social issues from multiple sides and to argue for and against positions that they may or may not believe in.This process requires that students be well versed on a variety of social issues. However, most importantly, it requires that they not only understand and know information, but that they do something with that information. Debate demands that people go beyond simple regurgitation into a critical analysis of thoughts and ideas. This is the foundation upon which future democratic leaders and policymakers are created.Over the next few months a cooperative effort to promote debate in Korea will take place among students from Kyung Hee University, Yonsei University and Ewha Womans University. These students will participate in a series of public lectures and debates on social and political issues. On March 31 at 6 p.m. the first of these events will take place at the Yonsei Global Lounge. This event will mark the formation of the Korea College Debate Association. It is hoped that these events will attract students from additional universities in Seoul to create a vibrant debating community similar to those that exist in other Asian countries.While the project may not change cultural attitudes overnight, it will contribute a bright ray of hope to the current political climate. Ultimately, the future leaders of Korean society need opportunities such as this to foster the cultural change necessary to sustain a functioning democracy.(debatekorea@hotmail.com)    The writer is a senior fellow at International Center for Speech and Debate and professor at the Graduate School of Journalism and Communication, Kyung Hee University. - Ed.By Jason L. Jarvis Contributing writer

title: Terrorist attacks' impact on the economy
content: By Lim Say Boon The Straits Times Asia News NetworkTuesday's attacks on the United States have made a global recession almost inevitable.Yes, there is a slim chance that rapid and aggressive action by the Federal Reserve and other central banks may avert or, at least, cut short the recession.There was speculation that the Fed might even act over the weekend, ahead of Monday's reopening of U.S. equity markets, to cut the Fed funds rate by another 50 basis points.There is little doubt that the killers who destroyed the landmark World Trade Center towers have also blown a hole in the world's already-weakened economies.Singapore's market has gone into a tailspin, frustrating hopes that rebounds on the key European bourses may fuel at least a small technical rebound here.The STI has broken a support level of 1430 and looks headed for 1350.This, in part, recognizes our dependence on exports to the United States and our sensitivity to oil-price hikes.The market is partly pricing in our vulnerability to further cuts in consumer spending. But beyond that, the already-thin institutional support for our market has left it vulnerable to selling from leveraged retail players who have little holding power. Further, so-called "prop traders," sensing a second wave of selling triggered by margin calls, have cut their long positions and reversed into short-selling. I was already contemplating a global recession when I wrote last Monday - my main concern then being the negative wealth effect of the continuing slump in U.S. equity prices and increasingly edgy consumers.After the initial shock of the attacks, European markets rebounded, gold and oil prices edged back down, and the U.S. dollar regained some of its earlier losses. But you would not want to be complacent.In the short term, you can expect a lot more turbulence. The surreal sight of jet planes slamming into landmark towers, the horror of fire and disintegrating buildings, the audacity of the attack on the Pentagon: These must all have been calculated to burn into the American psyche. And they will - taking with them consumers' confidence. To begin with, there would have been considerable loss of activity as Americans stayed at home, glued to their television sets for a week. The streets would have been a lot quieter, as would restaurants, bars and shops. The wholesale disruption to air travel would have added to the toll on the economy.Pile on top of that the longer-term fallout - from a nervous public possibly choosing to stay away from crowded malls, decreased domestic tourism as Americans avoid New York for fear of more attacks, and lower airline revenue as a result of lingering fears of hijackings.The result is almost inevitably considerable cutbacks in consumer spending. For an economy already on the brink of a recession, that would be the final straw.A week before the attacks, a surprise surge in last month's U.S. Purchasing Managers' Index had analysts wondering if this was a sign of imminent recovery. That analysis was optimistic; with Christmas coming, there was probably a seasonal factor involved.My prognosis then was that consumer sentiment was wavering. Indeed, data released on Thursday confirmed my suspicions that consumer confidence was already giving way by late last month. The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index, based on surveys conducted just before the attacks, plunged sharply from 91.5 last month to 83.6.This was hardly surprising given the lengthening unemployment queues, as confirmed by the higher-than-expected, first-time jobless benefits figures released last week.Now, given the scale of the tragedy visited on the United States, it would be hard to imagine this Christmas being anything but a low-key, somber, family affair, with much less of the usual spending.There is also the possibility of another surge in oil prices as the United States takes retaliatory action. The fear is that military action could disrupt oil supplies, causing a temporary spike in prices. If that occurs, consumers will pull back spending even more sharply.Over the medium term, however, there is hope. The Bush administration will have the sort of massive policy leverage associated with a wartime government.It will encounter very little political opposition to tough policies to shore up the United States on the economic and military fronts. This may indeed set the trigger for a sharp economic recovery next year and a market rally before that.And as tragic as Tuesday's events were, the expected increased government spending on reconstruction, airport security and anti-terrorist capabilities will add further stimulus to the economy.But I repeat: Do not be complacent. In the short term, the world has become a much more dangerous place - and our economies and markets will not be spared the discomfort.The writer is director of OCBC Investment Research. The views expressed in this article are his own. He contributed this article to the Straits Times. - Ed.

title: [번역]`Economy on track to recovery` 국내경기 회복 국면
content: Ministry cites falling inventories, rising shipments, brisk overseas business    The Korean economy bottomed out in the third quarter of this year before heading toward recovery, according to the government`s analysis of recently released industrial output statistics.In its statement the Ministry of Finance and Economy cited several factors - including falling inventories, improving shipments and the brisk activities of local businesses on overseas markets - as the reason for its favorable appraisal of the economy.This came after earlier this week the National Statistical Office unveiled its monthly report on the nation`s industrial production for October, which showed production and facility utilization improving, indicating to many that the economy is on the road to recovery.The inventory growth rate slowed in October to 7.3 percent from the previous 9.2 percent, while shipments growth accelerated to 6.7 percent from 5.1 percent over the cited period, the ministry said.Adding more weight to the ministry`s bright outlook for the economy, a separate government report showed that the trade surplus in November was $2.87 billion, the highest since December 1998.The nation`s outbound shipments were valued at $18.62 billion, up 22.5 percent from a year earlier, largely driven by brisk exports of cars and semiconductor products, the report explained."Domestic demand and facility investment remain in a slump but several other economic factors such as production and inventories are improving, which bode well for the nation`s economy down the road," a ministry official said.Observers noted that a ministry release of an analysis report on monthly economic data is rare, forcing them to conclude that the government seems to be trying to firm up consumer sentiment, which is showing incipient signs of its own recovery on the back of a series of improving economic indicators.By Koh Byung-joon (kokobj74@heraldm.com)    최근 발표된 정부의 산업활동동향 분석에 따르면 국내 경기가 3분기 저점을 찍고 회복 국면에 들어선 것으로 나타났다.재경부는 보고서에서 경기를 낙관하는 이유로 재고 감소, 출하량 증가, 해외 시장에서 국내 기업의 활발한 활동 등을 꼽았다.이러한 발표는 이번주 초 통계청이 발표한 10월 산업생산 동향에서 생산과 설비가동률이 증가한 것으로 나타난 이후 나온 것이다. 이는 국내 경기가 본격 회복세로 진입하고 있음을 시사하고 있다.10월 재고증가율은 지난 9월 9.2%에서 7.3%로 둔화된 반면 출하증가율은 지난 9월 5.1%에서 6.7%로 상승했다고 재경부는 밝혔다.재경부의 낙관적인 경제 전망과 더불어 별도의 정부 보고서에 따르면 11월 무역흑자가 28억7천만달러로 1998년 12월 이래 최고치를 기록한 것으로 나타났다.올해 우리나라의 수출은 자동차와 반도체의 수출 호조세에 힘입어 전년대비 22.5% 증가한 186억2천만달러를 기록했다고 보고서는 설명했다.재경부 관계자는 “내수와 설비투자가 부진한 모습이지만 생산, 재고 등 생산 관련 지표와 각종 경기지수가 개선되고 있어 국내 경기가 현재 회복 국면에 진입한 것으로 보인다”고 진단했다.경제 전문가들은 정부가 공식 보고서를 통해 경기 저점 시기를 언급하는 것은 매우 이례적인 일이라며 정부가 소비 심리를 강화시키려 노력하는 것으로 보인다고 언급했다. 현재 소비 심리는 일련의 경제 지표 개선에 힘 입어 회복 기미를 보이고 있다.

title: KT\&G gears up for privatization; State-owned company becoming top candid...
content: For a company as large and lucrative as state-owned Korea Tobacco & Ginseng Corp. (KT&G), the notion of privatization was unthinkable ? that is until recently. But times have changed and KT&G, one of the oldest of Korea's state-owned companies, is putting on a new business outfit. The first shape of a new state-owned giant is going to be in the form of selling off 25 percent of its shares to foreign and domestic investors later this year. Kim Jae-hong, the president of KT&G says the corporation will issue $200 million to $300 million worth of depository receipts later this year.
